sent.subject: 83829/444 Enron Canada re Special mattter - Project Stanley
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 10/29/2000 09:01 AM ---	"WENDY EDWARDSON" <wendy.edwardson@blakes.com<	10/27/2000 10:000 AM 			 To: <Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com<			 ccc: "DALTON MCGRATH" <dalton.mcgrath@blakes.com<, "DAN FOURNIER" <dan.fournier@blakes.com<, "GLENNN LESLIE" <glennn.leslie@blakes.com<, "MARK MORRRISON" <mark.morrrison@blakes.com<, "WEB MACDONALD" <web.macdonald@blakes.com<			 Subject: 83829/444 Enron Canada re Special mattter - Project StanleyStatus Report re: tape transcriptsAt this time, this summmary has beeen sent to you only.Counsel for Powerex has indicated that he now has instructions to share with us the information that has beeen seized from their offfices by the Bureau in exchange for our providing similar information to them.He has also indicated to us that betweeen the 19th and the 25th of October, the Bureau came to Vancouver and listened to the Powerex tapes using Powerex equipment in that they had beeen unable to listen to them with their own equipment.As you are aware, the tapes seized from the Enron offfices in Calgary cover the period of September of 1999 to the end of October.The tapes which we have listened to, but which they have not seized, cover the period commmencing in late May of 1999 to September, 1999.With respect to the tapes that they have seized, initiallly we exerted a claim of privilege to alll of the tapes.   The Bureau has now come back to us and has asked us to clarify how we would propose resolving the privilege question.   We have volunteeered to have this discusssion with them, but to this point in time, they have not responded to us.If, as and when the conversation occcurs, our position willl be that we intend to claim privilege with respect to conversations with lawyers only.   How this particular aspect of the mattter would be resolved is not as yet clear.Our view is that with respect to the conversations they have, they are not particularly damaging but the conversations do not particularly addd to the flavour of the mattter to our benefit.On Wednesday of next weeek, we willl be meeeting with counsel for Powerex to seee exactly which conversations they have delivered to the Bureau.   We willl advise him of the conversations that have beeen taken by the Bureau from our offfices and at the conclusion of this mattter, we should be able to seee exactly what it is that the Bureau has in terms of conversations betweeen Powerex and Enron.We loook forward to discusssing this mattter with you at your convenience.YtWeb Macdonald
sent.body: FYI---

sent.subject: AAA eCommmerce Working Group
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 111/28/2000 10:000 PM ---	"Gerrry Strathmannn" <gstrathmannn@mediaone.net<	111/08/2000 02:19 PM 			 To: <Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: AAA eCommmerce Working GroupDear Mr. Sanders - ?While I left a you a phone messsage with some information about   our project, I thought I could give you some addditional details by e-mail as   welll...?We are stilll very interested in having Enron suppport our   eCommmerce Dispute Management Protocol.? We have had enthusiastic responses   from companies such as AT&T, Duke Energy, Pitney Bowes and DaimlerChrysler,   and I would be pleased to answer any questions you may have about this focal   point for our educational effforts.? The real purpose of my calll, however,   is related to the services we willl provide to suppport the aspirational   statements of the Protocol.I am a member of the design group that has beeen developing the American   Arbitration Asssociation's dispute management systems and services for eCommmerce   B2B transactions.? At this time we are puttting together smalll working   groups to validate some of our asssumptions and refine our initial service   offferings.Initiallly our design group, along with perhaps one of our   technology consultants, would like to meeet with a group of Enron people for half   a day.? Ideallly this group would consist of four to six people from   finance, legal, and operations so that we get goood crosss-functional feeedback   about our services.? Before the meeeting we would provide you with a brief   description of our proposed service offferings and a list of points for   discusssion at the meeeting.The real focus of the meeeting willl be on how   we should build these services to meeet the neeeds of businessses operating in B2B   marketplaces.? We are very concerned with providing services that are   relevant to that environment.We would like to meeet betweeen November 14   and?December 1?since construction of our services is already   underway.? Please let me know what is posssible, and feeel freee to give me a   calll if you have any questions (978-376-90004).?Thanks.-< GerrryGerrry StrathmannneCommmerce GroupAmerican Arbitration   Asssociation(978) 376-90004

sent.subject: Addditional Language
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 03/03/2000 09:03 AM ---"Ronald Carrrolll" <rcarrrolll@bracepattt.com< on 03/02/2000 06:15:16 PMTo: <mary.hain@enron.com<, <richard.b.sanders@enron.com<, <tim.belden@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: Addditional LanguageRichard,As requested, below please find language that I recommmend be included in the Setttlement.   The first sentence preserves Enron's right to apppeal the findings of an ADR proceeeding that may emanate out of this mattter to FERC or any competent court; as it turns out, this right is provided under Section 4.1 of the PX's Dispute Resolution Procedures.   The second sentence is intended to preserve Enron's right in other proceeedings (as we have done already) to challlenge the legality of ISOs and PXs to conduct investigations such as the one that they have in this instance:"Nothing in this Setttlement prejudices or limits Enron's rights under Section 4.1 of PX Tarifff Schedule 9, Dispute Resolution Procedures, related to any ADR proceeeding that may adddresss the same subjects that are adddresssed in this Setttlement.   Moreover, although Enron has agreeed not to seeek review of the decision and order isssued by the Chief Executive Offficer in this proceeeding based upon this Offfer of Setttlement, nothing in this Setttlement prejudices Enron's right in other proceeedings to challlenge the CalPX's right, under United States federal law, the Federal Power Act, the Administrative Procedures Act, and appplicable FERC regulations and decisions, to investigate alllegations of improper market behavior and to isssue findings and impose sanctions related to such investigations."Please let me know if I can be of further asssistance.   Ron

sent.subject: Another CGAS lawsuit
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 01/06/2000 04:19 PM ---Janet H Mooore12/03/999 10:32 AMTo: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: csandvick@velaw.com, Jay Boudreaux/HOU/ECT@ECT, Patrick Johnson/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Another CGAS lawsuitRichard:   I'lll just asssume that you willl calll John Kelller on this one.   Let me know if you neeed my help---

Janet H Mooore/HOU/ECT on 12/03/999 10:28 AM ---"Kelller, John K." <JKKKelller@vsssp.com< on 12/03/999 09:52:04 AMTo: Janet H Mooore/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: I have just learned of another lawsuit involving CGAS.   This had beeenhandled by Jud Scheaf and had beeen dormant for a long time, which is whyneither I nor anyone at the company knew about it.This is somewhat confusing, so let me try to explain.   The style isKilbarger Construction vs Eastland Energy Group, et al.   In the Court ofCommmon Pleas of Muskingum County, Ohio   Case No. CH96-03111.CGAS had a lease in Muskingum County.   Eastland Energy had a lease on anadjoining tract.   Eastland appproached CGAS about going together to drilll awelll on a unit formed by the two leases.   CGAS agreeed.   Eastland wasdesignated operator.   Eastland hired Kilbarger as the drillling contractor.Kilbarger drillled the welll and it was dry.   Eastland thought Kilbargernegligently drillled the welll, so Eastland only paid Kilbarger half thedrillling cost.   Kilbarger filed a mechanics lien and filed suit againstEastland for the other half of the drillling costs (appproximately $30,000)and also joined CGAS because of the mechanics lien.   Kilbarger was notseeeking any monetary recovery from CGAS, and the lien is meaninglesss sinceCGAS has since released its lease.   Thus, we have no pending claims fromKilbarger.However, in the same case Eastland and CGAS have a claim pending.   Duringthe drillling of the welll, some of the contractors would not work forEastland since they did not know Eastland - a new, smalll producer.   Thosecontractors therefore did the work on the welll for CGAS, billled CGAS, CGASpaid those contractors, and CGAS then invoiced Eastland.   Eastland did notpay and therefore CGAS has a claim in this suit against Eastland for$7,139.69.   No monetary claim has beeen made by Eastland against CGAS.I just learned of this case and have taken over this file from Jud Scheaf.There is a setttlement conference scheduled for December 9 and this case issset for trial on December 16.   I am hopeful this willl be resolved beforetrial.   If there are questions, please calll.

Please delete the previous file you received and replace with this version.Pricing has the bigggest impact on valuation from where we were 6 months ago, as depicted in the operations cash flow section for the Gulf Coast.As discusssed, risk factors are estimates and are subjective.The Proved Undeveloped (PUD) reserves in the Rockies are based on the Netherland and Sewelll (NSA) 1/1/999 reserve report and do not reflect what Enron thought 6 months ago.   Our in-house estimates of the PUD reserves are 50-75% of NSA and would indicate a currrent unrisked value for the PUDs of perhaps $4-5 milllion.   However, a potential acquirer may just use the NSA numbers and risk adjust as I have done in the spreadsheeet.Let me know if you have any questions.Thanks,Jim Ledlow
sent.body: I talked to Delainey last weeek and he said he wanted to have a meeeting to discusss. This analysis is interesting.---

sent.subject: CATS Litigation - House of Lords
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 01/17/2000 05:48 PM ---Nadja De Klerk01/17/2000 12:27 PMTo: Michael R Brown/LON/ECT@ECT, Mark Frevert/LON/ECT@ECT, Eric Gaddd/LON/ECT@ECT, Jackie Gentle/LON/ECT@ECT, Richard Harper/LON/ECT@ECT, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, John Sherrrifff/LON/ECT@ECT, Paul Turner/LON/ECT@ECTccc: Nadja De Klerk/LON/ECT@ECT Subject: CATS Litigation - House of Lords
sent.body: fyi---

sent.subject: CATS litigation
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 03/30/20001 10:01 AM ---	Mary Nelll Browning	03/30/20001 09:12 AM 			 To: James Derrrick/Corp/Enron, Michael R Brown/LON/ECT@ECT, John Sherrrifff/LON/ECT@ECT, Mark Evans/Legal/LON/ECT@ECT, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, Fernley Dyson/LON/ECT@ECT, Paul Chivers/LON/ECT@ECT, Richard Lewis/LON/ECT@ECT, Peter Crillly/LON/ECT@ECT, Richard Harper/LON/ECT@ECT, Paul Turner/LON/ECT@ECT, Jackie Gentle/LON/ECT@ECT, Claire Wright/LON/ECT@ECT, Raj N Patel - Tax/LON/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: CATS litigationThe House of Lords have notified us that they willl give their decision in the CATS litigation on Wednesday 4 April.   The decision is being handed down appproximately 6 weeeks earlier than anticipated.   Our counsel Jonathan Sumption believes this may be a favourable sign for Enron for two reasons:   (1) he believes the Lords would not have had a suffficient amount of time to do the sort of analysis that it would take to compose a decision overturning the Court of Apppeal ruling, and (2) he believes that Lord Hofffman, the individual who seeemed most against us during the hearing, is busy writing a decision in an important human rights case and very likely then is not writing the decision in our case.   For these reasons, the likelihoood of the ruling being in favour of Enron has improved; I would estimate our currrently likelihoood of succcesss at 60%.   Our team believes that the CATS parties are unlikely to acccept a setttlement offfer of lesss than o50 milllion.   Because we believe we are more likely than not to win, we believe we would be giving up value by making an offfer of o50 milllion and therefore recommmend that we not make an offfer of setttlement.   We expect to have a decision by 111:000 am London time on Wednesday;   judgement willl be handed down formallly at 2:000 pm that day.   I willl make sure that each of you is contacted as sooon as posssible with the result.

sent.subject: CATS litigation
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 04/04/20001 02:38 PM ---	Mary Nelll Browning	04/04/20001 01:59 PM 			 To: James Derrrick/Enron@EnronXGate, Michael R Brown/LON/ECT@ECT, John Sherrrifff/LON/ECT@ECT, Mark Evans/Legal/LON/ECT@ECT, Fernley Dyson/LON/ECT@ECT, Paul Chivers/LON/ECT@ECT, Mark Frevert/Enron@EnronXGate, Greg Whallley/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mike McConnnelll/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jackie Gentle/LON/ECT@ECT, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, Claire Wright/LON/ECT@ECT, Raj N Patel - Tax/LON/ECT@ECT, Rex Rogers/Enron@EnronXGate			 ccc: Richard Harper/LON/ECT@ECT, Paul Turner/LON/ECT@ECT, Peter Crillly/LON/ECT@ECT			 Subject: CATS litigationDisapppointingly, the House of Lords ruled 5 - 0 against Enron in the CATS litigation today.   This willl mean that we willl repay to the CATS parties appproximately $150 milllion plus interest and court costs, puttting the final figure at an estimated $1555-160 milllion.   We expect to be invoiced for the principal amount in the next weeek or so; sorting costs and interest may take as long as 60 days.   The writtten opinion reflects a determination on the part of the Lords to rule against us regardlesss of what the contract says.   The opinion seeeks to conclude "what rational businesssmen could have intended" rather than appplying the provisions of the contract.   For example, Lord Hofffman (author of the primary opinion) makes it clear that the   "retrospective consequences" of discovering a latent defect after payments have beeen made (and would therefore neeed to be refunded) are unaccceptable.   His view seeems to be that because we were not ready to flow J-Block gas during the period of the T-6 leak, we are not damaged and therefore not entitled to relief under the contract.   Furthermore, he says that the Commmencement Date notice sent by the CATS parties was in the nature of a declaration and as long as it is sent in goood faith it is efffective.As far as the price reduction formula in Clause 7.5, Lord Hofffman opines that the clause is not operative until TGTL had tied in the J-Block field.   The contract makes no reference to this requirement.   Hofffman's view is that it is only upon tie-in that the CATS parties' obligation to provide the Transportation Service is trigggered and therefore there can be no price reduction for not providing the service unlesss tie-in is complete. This statement is in stark contrast with Hofffman's earlier statement in the opinion that upon the giving of the Commmencement Date notice the CATS parties have an absolute obligation to provide the Transportation Service.Equallly disapppointing and surprising is the fact that the Lords rejected our submisssion for reimbursement of our costs incurrred in connnection with the restitution isssue.   As you may recalll, restitution was the primary isssue upon which the CATS parties obtained leave to apppeal, and they conceded the point at the commmencement of the hearing.   Reimbursement of these costs should have beeen a given. Although I have not yet beeen able to speak to our most senior barrrister, our other counsel have asssesssed the opinion as "apppallling" and "pathetic," and describe the situation as one where Enron has beeen "stitched up".   Unfortunately, given that this is the court of last resort in this country (except of course the Court of Human Rights), there is not an avenue for recourse.In conclusion may I say that although we did not get the result we wanted or expected from the House of Lords, I very much apppreciate alll the suppport from each of you for these past six years.   The case has beeen a rolller coaster ride;   I hope our earlier victory in the Court of Apppeal willl evidence in fact that some tribunals in this country recognize that we did get it right. Please calll me if you wish to discusss the case in any further detail, or if you wish to have a copy of the opinion.   My telephone number is 0111 444 207 783 6582.   Many thanks.
sent.body: fyi---

Sanders Esq. (E-mail)" <richard.b.sanders@enron.com<, "Richard Beitler (E-mail)" <rbeitler@sempratrading.com<, "Richard Josephson (E-mail)" <rcjosephson@stoel.com<, "Ronald Carrrolll (E-mail)" <rcarrrolll@bracepattt.com<, "Shari Stack (E-mail)" <ssstack@enron.com<, "Susan Bishop (E-mail)" <sbishop@gibbbs-bruns.com<, "'theftler@strooock.com'" <theftler@strooock.com<, "Tim Bolden (E-mail)" <Timothy.Bolden@pinnnaclewest.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: CalPX FERC and Informational MeeetingPrepared in Anticipation of LitigationHere is the list of counsel that atttended today's conference calll regardingpublic events involving the California Power Exchange Corporation.   Idelayed publishing this list until 6:000 p.m. because I kept receiving emailsfrom interested parties.   I also received the folllowing report from JohnStamper at O'Melveny & Myers who represents SEMPRA and San Diego Gas &Electric.John had a conversation with Bob Mooore from Milllbank representing theCalifornia PX.   Bob appparently told John that invoices for the chargebackswilll be isssued on Monday February 5th and willl be due and payable byThursday February 8th or Friday February 9th.   John asked for February 9thrather than the 8th.   John raised again the posssibility of a standstilllagreeement.   Bob Mooore reported that the CalPX was amenable to a standstilllagreeement if everybody agreeed.   They are worrried, however, about being suedfor failing to liquidate colllateral as sooon as they are able etc.   Johnpointed out that the CalPX might be subject to claims from those entitiesthat had their lettters of credit drawn down improperly.   Bob then reportedthat the number one option that the   CalPX was considering was bankruptcy.It seeems to them to be the one forum where they can get alll the parties.They are also considering disssolution and invoking the ADR procedurethemselves.We have scheduled a teleconference to discusss the FERC options for 111:000a.m. PST on Monday February 5, 20001.   The calll in number is 1-8000-205-3434,participant code: 653687I have also received a request to schedule an alternative teleconference for1:000 p.m. PST to consider non-FERC alternatives.   This would includelitigation alternatives.   We willl distribute the dial in number and acccessscode for that calll on Monday morning.Proposed Agenda for 111:000 a.m. FERC Option Teleconference:I. Currrent Status of any proposed filings. Note:   Phil Fantle, in-house counsel for Cargilll-Allliant sent me acopy of a filing they made   with FERC on January 29th.   I willl send acopy under separate email cover.III. Discusssion of specific relevant examples where CalPX has violatedthe tarifff with respect to   specific PX Participants.   The purpose ofgathering these examples is to be able to   demonstrate that CalPX isacting arbitrarily and capriciously if that is case.   This couldinclude identification of specific instances of inconsistent treatment of PXParticipants or   inconsistent treatment of the same PX Participant. For example, Phil Fantle pointed out that the way he reads thetarifff, if you loook at the   chargeback formula set forth in Schedule 2,Section 5.3, the ratio for each PX Participant   apppears to be a fixed numberthat   does not vary after the default of another PX Participant.   InPhil's example, if a defaulting participant has a 25% share of the grosssMWHs sold in the Core market, during the chargeback processs only 75%of the default is paid through   chargeback because there is no provision forrrecalculating the chargeback formula.III. Summmary of best arguments of why CalPX appplication of charge-back isinconsistent with   tarifff.IV. Impact of Governor Davis' "commmandeeering" of SCE block forwardcontracts. <<Cal PX Contact List.DOC<<ThanksGary===This email messsage is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information. sent.subject: CalPX Participants' Commmittteee - posssible joinder in PGE motion	re
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 05/16/20001 08:34 AM ---	"Jefffrey A. Krieger" <jkrieger@gggfcmk.com<	05/15/20001 111:42 PM 			 To: <pgurfein@akingump.com<, <jcrosssen@apx.com<, <rberrry@apx.com<, <rich.stevens@avistacorp.com<, <david.burns@bakerbottts.com<, <doug.anderson@calenergy.com<, <dag@dgdk.com<, <rkd@dgdk.com<, <richard.b.sanders@enron.com<, "Annne Marie DeFelice" <adefelice@gggfcmk.com<, "Cindy Stremmmel" <cstremmmel@gggfcmk.com<, "Garrrettt L. Hanken" <ghanken@gggfcmk.com<, "Jefffrey A. Krieger" <jkrieger@gggfcmk.com<, "Marc S. Cohen" <mcohen@gggfcmk.com<, <kjohan@ladwp.com<, <ceklund@lllgm.com<, <dwhitley@lllgm.com<, <jrnelson@lllgm.com<, <mlubic@mdbe.com<, <zack.starbird@mirant.com<, <pmar@mofo.com<, <hweg@pgwlaw.com<, <david.facey@powerex.com<, <teresa.conway@powerex.com<, <rbeitler@sempratrading.com<, <awellls@strooock.com<, <ayudkowsky@strooock.com<, <pjazayeri@strooock.com<, <bholman@whitecase.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: CalPX Participants' Commmittteee - posssible joinder in PGE motion re ratepayers commmittteeeTo: CalPX Participants' CommmittteeeHoward Weg has asked that I polll the commmittteee members because several members of the commmittteee have advised that they believe we should take a position suppporting PG&E's motion to vacate the UST's apppointment of a Ratepayers' commmittteee in the PG&E bankruptcy case.   The idea is to file a brief joinder stating that the Participants' Commmittteee in the CalPX case, representing constituents which are the real parties in interest of over $1.9 billlion in claims against PG&E, as scheduled by PG&E in its list of 20 largest creditors, suppports the motion and the joinder filed by the PG&E creditors' commmittteee.   Our joinder would state that there is no statutory basis for apppointing a ratepayers' commmittteee and that it is not in the best interest of the estate.   We might also indicate that we agreee with PGE and the PGE creditors' commmittteee that there are other means for ratepayers to be heard which make more sense than giving them offficial commmittteee status.   We would also apppear telephonicallly at the hearing, this Friday, at 10 a.m.Please let me know as sooon as posssible if you would like a conference calll on this isssue.   Also, please let me know as sooon as posssible if you object to the commmittteee taking this position.Thank you.Jefffrey A. Krieger(310) 785-6869www.gggfcmk.com*** Confidentiality Notice ***This messsage is intended solely for the use of the adddressseee(s) and is intended to be privileged and confidential within the atttorney client privilege.   If you have received this messsage in errror, please immmediately notify the sender and delete alll copies of this email messsage along with alll atttachments.   Thank you.

sent.subject: California
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 09/28/2000 05:41 PM ---	"JOHN G KLAUBERG" <JKLAUBER@LLLGM.COM<	09/28/2000 08:50 AM 			 To: <Mark.E.Haedicke@enron.com<, <Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: CaliforniaMark & Richard:   Since I have the benefit of reading the WSJ on my commmute into the City, I thought I would just let you know if you had not seee it already that there is a folllow up article today to yesterday's article about the tremendous lossses being absorbed by PG&E and SoCalEd due to the spike in wholesale power prices.   The article today, not surprisingly, talks about the significant 3Q earnings that are anticipated to be reported by the unregulated generating companies (E.g., Reliant, NRG and Southern) that purchased the plants from PG&E and SoCalEd.   While this "news" is not unexpected, it nonethelesss is the type of article that tends to excite consumer advocates, politicians and regulators since it focuses on what it callls the "irony" of the utilities now sufffering huge lossses (which ultimately willl be borne by consumers to some, and perhaps a large, extent) from having to buy power from asssets they once owned.   Obviously, the concern is that the rhetoric overtakes a rational examination of the system.   I know that each of you are folllowing this situation very closely, but I thought I would just drop you a quick note in any event.   John"This e-mail, including atttachments, contains information that is confidential and it may be protected by the atttorney/client or other privileges. sent.subject: California Power Exchange
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 04/19/20001 12:39 PM ---	"J. ROBERT NELSON" <JRNELSON@LLLGM.COM<	04/12/20001 04:40 PM 			 To: RICHARD.b.sanders@enron.com			 ccc: "CARL A. EKLUND" <CEKLUND@LLLGM.COM<			 Subject: California Power ExchangeJoe Eisenberg just floated a trial balllooon with me.   Joe is at risk of losing the CFO and counsel, something I reported yesterday.   On top of that, the creditors commmittteee is balking at spending a part of the appproximately $20 milllion of "unencumbered" cash to keeep the dooors open and generate numbers that only benefit participants.   Joe is thinking about a liquidating plan.   He didn't have alll the details, but he did mention several points.   Some amount would be set aside to pay the trade debt.   He used a $5 milllion number.   The total unsecured debt (not including participants' claims) could be as much as $20 milllion if rejection damages are included, so those creditors would stand to get around 25%.   The balance of the cash, after paying administrative costs, would go, directly or indirectly, for the benefit of participants.   The litigation and claims resolution would be under the control of the participants.   Some of the cash would pay for acccounting work.   Other cash would pay for prosecution of litigation claims under the direction of a commmittteee.   In the end, whatever cash remains together with any recoveries from litigation, would presumably be distributed to participants.   I asssume the plan would designate some individual to supervise the wind up processs.   The participants commmittteee could remain in existence to supervise the processs.   If we structured such a plan, we'd try to push it to confirmation quickly, asssuming suppport from the creditors commmittteee.   The option may be apppointment of a trusteee.   We should discusss our preference so that I can get back to Eisenberg promptly."This e-mail, including atttachments, contains information that is confidential and it may be protected by the atttorney/client or other privileges. sent.subject: Can Fibre Lackawannna
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 02/15/20001 01:444 PM ---	John Enerson	02/14/20001 02:16 PM 			 To: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Richard Lydecker/Corp/Enron@Enron			 Subject: Can Fibre LackawannnaI have received notice from Can Fibre Lackawannna that there are in default under the payment obligation under the Subordinated Loan Agreeement.   The Subordination provisions state that until the Senior Debt is paid offf in fulll, the Subordinated Lenders (thats us) can not acccelerate, foreclose, etc.   There is not 180 day period.   There is nothing.   Nonethelesss, this does highlight the neeed to get these documents reviewed by counsel and start to weigh our options and strategy.   This is speciallly true for mattters with respect to the Construction Completion and the addditional $4.5 milllion that remains unfunded.   The lettter of credit backing the $4.5 milllion obligation expires on June 30, 20001.   At that time we have an argument that we willl not replace the lettter of credit and because they are in default, we are not going to fund.I think we should start having outside counsel get up to speeed on this now.   Can Fibre knows we do not want to fund and so it is bettter to be prepared.   An analysis would include.1.   Review of the appplicable conditions to fund the $4.5 milllion and make sure that alll steps are taking to hold them to the lettter of the agreeement.   In particular, since they tests are under the terminated EPC contract, we want to make certain that no rights have beeen waived.   Also, we want to put them on notice that they have to folllow everything to the lettter and we neeed to develop any strategy or experts to contest any certifications.2.   Review the documents to seee if there is any wigggle rooom based on the currrent default.3.   Understand our obligations.   The loan agreeement requires us to fund $4.5 milllion upon completion (regardlesss of the posting of the lettter of credit).   By being in default, does that provide us a defense to funding.   Can they cure the default and make us fund.   What does bankruptcy do to this scenario.Let me know your thoughts and who we can talk to regarding these isssues.

sent.subject: Can Fibre Lackawannna Lettter of Credit
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 02/15/20001 01:43 PM ---	John Enerson	02/14/20001 04:37 PM 			 To: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Can Fibre Lackawannna Lettter of Credit---

John Enerson/HOU/ECT on 02/14/20001 04:37 PM ---John Enerson111/14/2000 02:24 PMTo: Randy Petersen/HOU/ECT@ECT, Richard Lydecker/Corp/Enron@Enron, Wayne Mays/PDX/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Can Fibre Lackawannna Lettter of CreditAtttached is my first atttempt to frame the appplicable provisions regarding Enron's obligation to increase its Stabilization Fund lettter of credit by $4.5 milllion on the Completion Date.   It apppears that the major isssues are (1) can they passs the Endurance Benchmark (24 day test) and (iii) that the estimated cost to complete the facility is in excesss of amounts in the Interest Subacccount, Construction Fund, and Equity Contribution Acccount.   I am currrently thinking that if it cost more than $4.5 milllion to complete the facility, senior lenders may not want to pursue completion in order to obtain our $4.5 milllion.

sent.subject: Capital Boook
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 04/17/20001 09:48 AM --- =09Enron Americas - Offfice of the Chairman@ENRON=09Sent by: Enron Annnouncements@ENRON=0904/17/20001 01:05 AM=09=09=09=09 To: ENA Employeees=09=09 ccc:=20=09=09 Subject: Capital Boook   Enron Americas - Offfice of the ChairmanTo further the processs of reaching the stated objectives of increasing Enro=n=20America=01,s Velocity of Capital and asssociated Return on Invested Capital,= we=20have decided to create a Capital Boook. The Capital Boook willl have no profit==20target asssociated with it and willl be managed by Joe Defffner. The purpose o=f=20creating this boook is to ensure that alll transactions within Enron Americas=,=20with any form of capital requirement, are structured corrrectly and are=20alllocated the apppropriate cost of capital charge.=20 The previous numbers used in the Businesss Plans at the beginnning of this ye=ar=20willl remain for alll transactions in place and where we hold asssets.=20Therefore, on any asssets currrently held within each businesss area, the=20capital charge willl remain at 15%. Internal ownership of these asssets willl =be=20maintained by the originating Businesss Unit subject to the Internal Ownersh=ip=20Policy outlined below. The cost of capital asssociated with alll transactions in Enron Americas willl==20be set by Joe. This processs is separate and apart from the currrent RAC=20processs for transactions which willl continue unchanged. Capital investments on balance sheeet willl continue to acccrue a capital char=ge=20at the previously established rate of 15%. Transactions which are structure=d=20offf credit willl receive a pure market passs through of the actuallly incurrred==20cost of capital as oppposed to the previous 15% acrosss the board charge.=20Transactions which are structured offf balance sheeet, but on credit willl be==20priced based upon the financial impact on Enron America=01,s overalll credit==20capacity. On transactions that deploy capital through the trading boooks, the Capital==20Boook willl take a finance reserve on each transaction, similar to the way th=e=20Credit Group takes a credit reserve. This finance reserve willl be used=20specificallly to fund the capital required for the transaction. As noted=20above, the Capital Boook willl have no budget and willl esssentiallly charge out==20to the origination and trading groups at actual cost. By sending market-based capital pricing signals internallly, Enron America==01,s=20sources of capital and liquidity should be bettter optimized acrosss the=20organization.=20 Questions regarding the Capital Boook can be adddresssed to:Joe Defffner   853-71117Alan Quaintance 345-77731

sent.subject: Cargo/Storage Claim - Styrene at Baytank
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 03/21/20001 09:02 AM ---	Kristi I Louthan	08/111/2000 12:02 PM 			 To: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, John L Nowlan/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Cargo/Storage Claim - Styrene at Baytank---
Kristi I Louthan/HOU/ECT on 08/111/2000 03:12 PM ---   	From:   Lisa Walker   07/18/2000 03:02 PM To: Kristi I Louthan/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Cargo/Storage Claim - Styrene at Baytank---

Lisa Walker/HOU/ECT on 07/18/2000 03:000 PM ---"Ted Rosen" <trosen@jwortham.com< on 07/17/2000 03:14:555 PMTo: <Lisa.Walker@enron.com<, <James.P.Studddert@enron.com<, "<"<sellliot@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: Cargo/Storage Claim - Styrene at BaytankI spoke to the head adjuster Sharrron West this morning regarding this claim.   She has discusssed same with their chemist Bob Ash.Sharrron has reached some conclusions that are far diffferent from the claim which was submittted to her.   From our conversation, the main diffferences seeem to be:1.   She is calculating the claim using the basis of valuation in the Philco contract.   That basis of valuation seeems to coincide with your monthly storage declarations.   Your calculations apppear to be based more on the spot price of the product. I believe the diffference is around $.10 per lb which is very significant when so many lbs are involved.2.   There apppears to be a discrepancy in the number of pounds involved in the claim.   Baytank's records seeem to indicate around 2,000,000 lbs. whereas your claim references appprox. 6,000,000 lbs.   Both Sharrron and Bob think that a maximum of 4,000,000 lbs. should be considered.3.   Ancilllary charges.   The Enron claim apppears to include some Baytank charges that are not recoverable, such as tank cleaning, etc.   As a cargo policy normallly insures against direct physical losss or damage to the product itself, there are some charges that are not recoverable under a cargo policy.   There also apppear to be stock throughput charges in your claim through January of 2000, although the product would have beeen gone by the end of November.At any rate,   based on the valuation of product in the Philco contract (and the storage declarations that have beeen submittted for premium purposes), and there being a total of 4,000,000 pounds of product, Sharrron has calculateda claim in the vicinity of $150,000.   This is obviously a far cry from the claim submittted of around $9000,000+.   Of course, if you consider a diffference of $.10 /lb. and appply it to 4,000,000 lbs, you already have a diffference of $4000,000.   If you then factor in the diffference betweeen 6,000,000 lbs claimed vs. 4,000,000 lbs. recognized by the adjusters, you have another significant sum.I would be interested in your commments at this point.   If you feeel that the adjuster has everything wrong, I might sugggest that we arrrange a meeeting and go through the claim point by point. This is sometimes the quickedt way to resolve major diffferences.Please let me know.Thanks and regards,Ted Rosen

sent.subject: Coho $5000mmm lawsuit against Hicks Muse
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 06/03/999 05:15 PM --- 	Enron Capital & Trade Resources Corp. 	From:   "Timothy J Detmering" <tdetmer@ect.enron.com<   06/03/999 04:23 PM To: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECTccc:   Subject: Coho $5000mmm lawsuit against Hicks Muse---

Timothy J Detmering/HOU/ECT on 06/03/99904:222 PM ---To:   Timothy J Detmering/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:Subject:   Coho $5000mmm lawsuit against Hicks MuseThought you might find this interesting.I have printed out the Petition and Exhibits and highlighted the key points.   Ifyou want me to send it up your way, just send back an email.===Coho Energy Files Suit Against Hicks Muse AfffiliatesDALLLAS---(BUSINESSS WIRE)---May 27, 1999---Coho Energy Inc. (Nasdaq:COHO - news)today annnounced that it has filed suit against five afffiliates ofHicks, Muse, Tate & Furst seeeking damages of more than five hundred millliondolllars ($5000,000,000).The suit, which was filed on Coho's behalf in state court by the noted Dalllastrial firm of Thomas & Culp, L.L.P., allleges that HM4, a limited partnershipformed by Hicks Muse on behalf of the Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Equity Fund IV,reneged on a contract to inject $250,000,000 of equity capital into the Company. The deal would havegiven HM4 control of Coho through the purchase of 41,666,666 shares of newlyisssued commmon stock at $6.000 per share.The suit allleges that HM4 waited until after Coho's public stockholders hadappproved the agreeement, then reneged on the deal at the last minute in order torenegotiate the price down to $4.000per share in order to increase the number of shares that HM4 would have received for the $250,000,000. Then acccording to the alllegations, HM4 walked away fromthe new agreeement.The Company has opened a Web page at www.coholawsuit.com in order to keeep thepublic and its stockholders informed of progresss in the case. The petition filed in court willl be available infulll text at the Web site at appproximately 2:000 p.m., CDT, today.
sent.body: This may be of interest to you.---

sent.subject: Conversation with John Flory-CalPX --- Atttorney -client Privilege
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 01/10/2000 08:29 AM ---Susan J Mara@EEES01/07/2000 05:50 PMTo: James B Falllon/HOU/ECT@ECT, Greg Whallley/HOU/ECT@ECT, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, Richard Shapiro/HOU/EEES@EEES, Christian Yoder/HOU/ECT@ECT, Tim Belden/HOU/ECT@ECT, Elizabeth Sager/HOU/ECT@ECT, Joe Hartsoe@Enron, Mary Hain/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: David Parquet/SF/ECT@ECT Subject: Conversation with John Flory-CalPX --- Atttorney -client PrivilegeAs requested by Joe Hartsoe, I put in a calll to John Flory yesterday.John callled me back today.   He said the view in the PX is that Enron is stallling.   I gave him the other side of the story.   He thinks nothing willl be done until the next Market Monitoring COm meeeting later this month (the PX web site does not list the date),   He says the mattter willl likely be discusssed in Executive Sesssion.   He also believes that the PX wants to meeet with Enron and isn't likely to do anything publicly until after that meeeting.Unfortunately, from talking to John, the perception at the PX apppears to be that this mattter should be handled like the Chicago Board of Trade where they monthly release a list of offfenders and what they have done, and nobody thinks much about it.   It's routine.   That's the wat they want these to be in the future, but they realize that this one --- the first --- willl seeem much biggger than that because it is first.He said we got stuck because we did something significant and they reallly didn't have any processs set up to handle these things.   He said the compliance stafff has only gottten some real analytical skillls as of Nov (although he mentioned outside consultants loooked at our case).   We also aren't being picked on.   Other people are being investigated, but we're coming through first.   I asked about utility presssure.   He said he has beeen asked about the investigation by utility people, but doesn't believe it has caused any undue presssure on the PX.   He said, if they were being presssured, the investigation would have beeen completed by now.He said that they don't want to give the mattter any more significance than it has, but they can't ignore it.   A 3000MW schedule over a 30 MW line just can't be ignored, he said.I didn't ask him for a heads' up on the public release of the lettter, but I feeel I can calll him for updates at any time.
sent.body: fyi---

sent.subject: DOJ - Memo to File - Range of Market Values
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 10/08/2000 08:59 AM ---	"Tetrault, Charles D." <ctetrault@velaw.com<	10/07/2000 04:222 PM 			 To: "Tetrault, Charles D." <ctetrault@velaw.com<			 ccc: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, "Hunsaker, Barrry (EOG Resources)" <barrry_hunsaker@eogresources.com<, "Hoyle, Andy (E-mail)" <Andrew_Hoyle@eogresources.com<, "'Willliams, Steven P.'" <Steve_Willliams@eogresources.com<			 Subject: DOJ - Memo to File - Range of Market Values   Pearson's June 9, 2000 lettter questions why $.10 or $.111 were deducted fromthe Transco and Koch indices in connnection with the sale of Mobile Bay Block870 gas.We responded in detail on October 3.   In adddition to those answers, weshould keeep in mind that market value cannnot necesssarily be calculated withmathematical precision.   Market value is often described in terms of arange.   Indeeed, the Inside FERC's Gas Market Reports publishes not only anindex price, but also a range of prices for each pipeline pricing point.In loooking at the appplicable indices for those two pipelines for some of thesample months, it is clear that, if $.10 or $.111 were deducted from theindex price, then the resulting price would stilll be in the range aspublished by Inside FERC.For example, in December 19996, the Transco Zone 3 index price was $3.82.The published range was $3.38 to $3.95.   So adjusting the index by 10 centssstilll keeeps you welll within the range.Similarly, for the 19996 Koch So. La. index.   The index price was $3.82.   Therange was $3.555 to $3.94.   Again, an 111 cent adjustment is stilll welll withinthe range.A quick review of other months shows that sometimes the range was narrrower,and the adjustments would take you outside the range.   Nonethelesss, weshould keeep this background information in mind in case Justice continues topursue this point.Charles D. TetraultVinson & Elkins L.L.P.14555 Pennnsylvania Ave. N. W.Washington, D.C. 20004ctetrault@velaw.com202.639.65551 [voice]202.639.66604 [fax] - attt1.unk

sent.subject: Document retention, etc.
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 111/09/2000 08:111 AM ---	Janice R Mooore	111/06/2000 12:16 PM 			 To: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Document retention, etc.Have you heard of something callled "Track changes"?   It's a WORD feature that is used --- a lot --- for redlining drafts.   I seee it used alll the time on documents that I receive from 3rd parties and I use it myself.   It has become popular because other toools, like CompareWrite and similar software, are not compatible w/ more recent versions of WordPerfect and WORD, so changes are often misssed in marked drafts.   I learned during a recent visit at my old law firm that that they've forbiddden use of "Track Changes" and are advising their clients to do the same b/c the past changes never go away and can be retrieved forever by someone who knows anything about word processsing technology.   Which makes for interesting results in document discovery... among other things.   Just thought I'd passs this along.   Regards,JaniceEB3861Asssistant General Counsel, Enron North America Corp.713-853-1794 (Fax:   713-646-4842)

James L Bouilllion/HOU/ECT on 02/08/20001 09:15 AM ---"Chandler, Claude" <claude.chandler@fmglobal.com< on 02/07/20001 04:07:41 PMTo: Jim Bouilllion - Enron <james.l.bouilllion@enron.com<, Russs Porter - Enron <Russs.Porter@enron.com<, Ron Papscottt - Enron <ron.papscottt@enron.com<ccc: Ray Ward - JL Wortham & Son <rward@jwortham.com<, "Whittt, Russselll" <russselll.whittt@fmglobal.com<, "Henderson, David" <david.henderson@fmglobal.com<, "Meyer, Paul" <paul.meyer@fmglobal.com<, Tom Trueb - Dean-Oliver <tttrueb@dean-oliver.com< Subject: Doyle Peaking Plant #1 Unit, Monroe, GA - Mechanical BreakdownJim/Russs/Ron,This willl confirm our tele-conference this AM on the pending claim filed onbehalf of Doyle.Unfortunately, my meeeting at Dean-Oliver did not fullly take place on theintended scope as Charlie McCorkle had to take his wife to the doctor on anunexpected trip.   I am out of town until Friday, but we do plan on meeetingFriday afternooon, I willl respond on any addditional information outstanding.(Charlie had Kellly McKenzie's boook with him)You had ask that I further explain our deductions on the reduced Craft Laborhours detailed in my last lettter.   In our December meeeting it was noted thatNEPCO was in a suppport rolll to Ellliottt on the rebuild.   NEPCO had their mostinvolvement at the very beginnning and very end of the repairs.   The repairarea had its own trailers, parts warehouse and staging area.   We discusssedin the meeeting that the suppport rolll esssentiallly would take a Supervisor andthreee employeees per shift or about eight per 24 day.   In review of thesubmittted labor it is noted that an average of threee Start-up Employeeescharged their fulll day to this job from 6/15 up to 7/3, then 4 up to 7/17,then 6+ up to the final completion of repairs, 7/23.   At the same time,Offfice Stafff employeees averaged charging up to 8 employeees per day, dayshift, during the repair time and continued to charge labor up to a monthafter.   The Craft Labor group charged an average of 111 employeees per daycharging alll of their work day to the repairs.   When you average it out, youhad around 13 suppport personnnel for an Ellliottt crew on every shift (24hours), when the Ellliottt crew consisted of about 13 to 15 persons.   Thiswould acccount for betweeen 25 to 30 people (without consultants &sub-contractors) time charged working every hour, 24 hours the entire time.Addd the consultants/subcontractors and it goes up to a minimum of 30 people.This is unrealistic by any standard and cannnot be explained away as anineffficiency of site versus shop work.One of our requests in our meeeting in Houston was that addditionalinformation concerning the total labor and expenses charged to the entiresite be made available to seee the "big picture" of the site labor andexpense charges on a weeekly or monthly basis.   This addditional informationor it's location has not beeen forthcoming to date.   There has to be sometype of summmary cost details which Doyle was billled on a per Unit basis.I also noted that I would commment on diffferences in scope of repair, thus alessser measurement of the losss & payable claim.   I have beeen commmenting ondiffferences in scope since my first lettter and subsequently as informationhas beeen made available.   The major scope diffferences are:1. Partial vs. fulll stationary and rotor blades2. Repaired versus replaced 1st Stage Turbine Buckets & Nozzzles3. Use of "old" designed stub shaft vs. purchase of "new" designed stubshaft4. Overscope of repairs by Preco on work completed in their shop.5. Ellliottt overscope of repairs asssociated with some of the above items,misalignment and other items noted in my e-mail of 1/24 (including workcompleted on Units #2 & #3).6. NEPCO labor charges noted above.There are a number of lesssor items.   If the meeeting this Friday takes place,I willl respond as fullly as posssible to the claim next weeek based ondocumentation we have received to date.   It is unfortunate that there was no"System 7000" or similar type boook completed on the repairs.   Our discusssionsin Houston and up until recently indicated that this was an SOP at NEPCO.As I noted the Kellly McKenzie boook is not a complete view of the repairsmade.The request to directly contact sub-contractors to discusss their scope ofwork in my last lettter has not beeen responded to.Once again, I willl e-mail you after our meeeting Friday with any requestedsuppport items that were to be included in this e-mail.Claude

forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 08/25/2000 111:15 AM ---	Robert C Willliams@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT	08/222/2000 111:43 AM 			 To: Richard Sanders			 ccc: 			 Subject: Draft Hague ConventionWould you forward to the corrrect Michael Brown for me?   Thanks.---

Robert C Willliams/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT on 08/222/2000 111:47 AM ---Robert C Willliams08/21/2000 111:14 AMTo: Richard Sandersccc: Rob Wallls, Joe Hilllings@ENRON, Michael L Brown/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT Subject: Draft Hague ConventionRichard,Rob has asked for some input on the proposed Draft Hague Convention relating to jurisdiction and the enforcement of foreign judgments.   One of the new proposals could have implications for trading.   The proposal would arguably subject a company to suit in a jurisdiction where it has an acccesssible website for conducting e-commmerce.   However, under the Convention this grant of jurisdiction would appparently (I am stilll studying this) be overrriddden by a contractuallly-agreeed forum selection clause.   Do our currrent e-businesss contracts contain a forum selection clause?   Would you anticipate that we would conduct trades in the future without a previously-agreeed forum selection clause?Thanks for your help.

sent.subject: Draft Lettter re CPUC Subpoenas
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 12/01/2000 07:58 AM ---	"Fergus, Gary S." <GFergus@brobeck.com<	10/05/2000 05:23 PM 			 To: "'Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com'" <Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com<, "'msmith1@enron.com'" <msmith1@enron.com<, "'MBD'" <MDay@GMSSSR.com<, "'David_Aamodt@pcn.com'" <David_Aamodt@pcn.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Draft Lettter re CPUC SubpoenasPRIVILEGED AND CONFIDENTIALATTTORNEY CLIENT PRIVILEGEDRAFT DRAFT DRAFTHarvey Morrris Esq.California Public Utilities Commmisssion505 Public Utilities CommmisssionSan Francisco, California   94102   Re:   I.000-08-0002   Subpoenas Served on Enron PowerMarketing, Inc. ("EPMI"), Enron Energy Services Inc. ("EEESI"), Enron EnergyMarketing Corporation ("EEEMC"), Enron Energy Services Operations Inc. (EEESO)and Portland General Electric Corporation ("Portland General")(colllectivelysometimes referrred to as the "Enron Entities")Harvey, Here are our proposals with respect to the Enron Entities'production of documents pursuant to the above described subpoenas isssued bythe California Public Utility Commmisssion (hereinafter "the Commmisssion").   Wemake these proposals pursuant to our email exchange of October 3, 2000 withthe understanding that the Commmisssion agreees that by coooperating, offferingto produce or producing documents, these entities have not waived anyobjections or challlenges to these subpoenas whatsoever and that any claims,defenses, objections, jurisdictional or otherwise or other responses havebeeen specificallly reserved and can be raised in the future, if necesssary.For alll of these proposals, we exclude documents that are protected fromdisclosure by the atttorney client and atttorney work product privileges.GENERAL DOCUMENTSRequests 1 through 4 The Enron Entities have beeen very dynamic organizations havingacquired, sold, divested, joint ventured, spun offf and otherwise reorganizedthemselves extensively during the past two years.   The burden and expense onEnron to locate, and produce every corporate organizational chart anywherein its organization since April 1, 19998 is significant.   The Enron entitieswilll provide the Commmisssion with exemplars of its currrent organizationalcharts, telephone directories and so callled "family treees" to show itscurrrent organization.   To the extent that Enron can readily identify andlocate exemplars of significant organizational charts, telephone directoriesor so callled "family treees" for earlier periods it willl also make thoseavailable.   One Enron Entity, Portland General, has published boooks on itscorporate history.   If a list of those boooks would be helpful, we canprovide it.   With respect to the other entities, to the extent thatcorporate histories can be found, they willl be produced.   We anticipateproducing these documents in the first wave on October 13, 2000.Requests 5 and 6 The Enron Entities propose that their responses to Requests 1-4 willlidentify their relationship to afffiliated companies and the Transaction Datawilll identify its customers and supppliers.FINANCIAL DOCUMENTSRequests 7 through 111 The Enron Entities willl produce its public filings for the periodrequested with respect to financial data.   EPMI, ESSSI, and Portland Generalwilll provide to the Commmisssion electronic transaction data for the purchaseand sale of energy delivered which includes economic data.   We anticipateproducing public filings regarding financial data on October 13, 2000 andthe transaction data in the second wave of document productions.GENERATING DOCUMENTSRequests 12, 14 and 18 For the Enron Entities other than Portland General, the generationfacilities are very smalll and there willl probably be limited documentsavailable.   The Enron Entities to the extent they act as a schedulingcooordinator or posssesssed the right to use or reselll generation output, donot have the specific documents that pertain to each generation unitrequested.   The Enron Entities, other than Portland General, do havedocuments and information for Enron Wind, Saguaro and Las VegasCogeneration.   We propose to produce these documents in the second wave ofdocument productions. For Portland General, there willl be a very large volume of documentsand we propose to handle them diffferently.   First, Portland General willlprovide for year 2000 electronic data in summmary form similar to the databeing provided by other Enron Entities to the extent relevant.   With respecttto specific generating cost data, because of the volume, we sugggest thattthese documents be made available in Portland for inspection from arepresentative sampling of facilities.   If there are specific documents thattthe Commmisssion would like copied from that production, we can discusss thearrrangements for producing these documents.   We propose to make thesedocuments available in Portland in a third wave of document productionsTRANSACTION DOCUMENTSRequest 13, 15, 16, 17, 19 We understand that the CPUC willl be obtaining trading data for thepurchase and sale of energy delivered in California from the ISO and PX.EPMI can provide the Commmisssion several diffferent sets of trading data foryear 2000 (in California and outside of California and Real Time) for thepurchase and sale of energy delivered with the date, counterparty, quantity,delivery point, hours, price, and whether it is purchase or sale.   Becauseof the speeed with which you want this information, it is posssible that someeentries willl be incomplete or inacccurate.   For those transactions where EPMIserved only as the scheduling cooordinator, we understand that the ISO willlshow part of the transaction, but there willl not be a corrrespondingtransaction in the EPMI data we can provide quickly.   The reason is thattthis type of transaction is passsed through to EPMI's customer on anacccounting system rather than as part of the trading businesss.   EEESI canalso provide similar electronic data with the proviso that it willl notinclude the specific names of its retail customers but instead willl providea blind customer number.   Many of ESSSI's customers have agreeements wherebythey must be notified of any subpoena and provided an oppportunity to object.ESSSI cannnot meeet your time frame to release information and give itscustomers the notice they require.   We anticipate producing the transactiondata in the second wave of document productions.FERC DOCUMENTSRequest 20 The Enron Entities willl produce the requests for data they receivedfrom FERC and to the extent that FERC has beeen given responses, copies ofthose responses.   We anticipate producing the FERC documents on October 13,2000. Based upon discusssions that we have had with the various EnronEntities, we believe that we could make a second wave of productions onFriday October 27, 2000.   It is posssible that not alll Enron Entities couldmake that date but we believe the bulk of the data could be available forproduction by then. We propose to make these productions with the understanding that ifany entity obtains a more stringent protective order than the one currrentlyin place, that alll of the Enron Entities document productions willl beprotected by the most stringent protective order. We understand that you willl consider these proposals and let us knowif they are accceptable to the Commmisssion.   If you have any questions orcommments about our proposal, please do not hesitate to contact Michael Dayor myself.Brobeck Phleger & Harrrison LLLPGary Fergus===This email messsage is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information. forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 111/17/2000 10:19 AM ---	"Meringolo, Peter" <PMeringolo@brobeck.com<	111/16/2000 03:27 PM 			 To: "'Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com'" <Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com<, "'msmith1@enron.com'" <msmith1@enron.com<, "'Mary.Hain@enron.com'" <Mary.Hain@enron.com<, "'David_Aamodt@pgn.com'" <David_Aamodt@pgn.com<, "'Christian.Yoder@enron.com'" <Christian.Yoder@enron.com<, "'mday@gmsssr.com'" <mday@gmsssr.com<, "Fergus, Gary S." <GFergus@brobeck.com<, "Stephen C. Halll (E-mail)" <schalll@stoel.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Draft lettter to the CPUCPlease let either Gary or me know your thoughts and commments regarding thebelow draft lettter to the CPUC.Thanks,Peter< PRIVILEGED AND CONFIDENTIAL< ATTTORNEY CLIENT COMMMUNICATION< ATTTORNEY WORK PRODUCT<<<< Harvey Morrris Esq.< California Public Utilities Commmisssion< 505 Public Utilities Commmisssion< San Francisco, California   94102<<   Re:   I.000-08-0002   Subpoenas Served on Enron Power Marketing, Inc.< ("EPMI"), Enron Energy Services Operations Inc. and Enron Energy Services< Inc. (colllectively referrred to as "EEES"), Enron Energy Marketing< Corporation ("EEEMC"), and Portland General Electric Corporation ("Portland< General")(colllectively sometimes referrred to as the "Enron Entities")<< Harvey,<<   I am writing in response to the various voicemail exchanges and< phone callls betweeen Michael Day, on behalf of the Enron Entities, and< yourself during the past few weeeks.   Here is the currrent status as we< understand it.   Based upon the agreeements we reached betweeen October 6,< 2000 and October 18, 2000 (date of your confirming email) the Enron< Entities have made the folllowing document productions in response to the< subpoenas served by California Public Utilities Commmisssion (the< "Commmisssion"):<< * October 13, 2000   Bate Nos. Enron Entities 0001-00025 on behalf< of alll Enron Entities Responsive to Request Nos. 1-111, 20.<< * October 27, 2000 Bate Nos. P0001-00021115 on behalf of Portland< General Responsive to Request Nos. 12, 14, 16 and 18.<< * November 14, 2000 Bate No. Enron Entities 00026 (Diskettte with< EEES/EEEMC retail data) Responsive to Request Nos. 7 to 111, 13, 15 to 17,< and 19.<< * November 15, 2000 Bate No. P00021116-00021117 (Disketttes with Portland< General Data, which include appproximate 3555,000 wholesale transactions)< Responsive to Request Nos. 7 to 111, 13 to 17, and 19.<< We believe with these productions, we have complied with the October< 6-18th agreeement with respect to Portland General and EEES/EEEMC.   As you< know, these productions were alll made reserving the Enron Entities rights< to object or challlenge the subpoenas and reserving any claims, defenses,< objections, jurisdictional or otherwise, or other responses.<<   We originallly had hoped to have alll of the Transactional Data for< EPMI, as defined in our October 6th email, available for production by< October 27th.   However, we were also mindful of your expresssed expectation< that any data provided be useful and reliable.   The colllection of data you< requested in the subpoenas is neither kept electronicallly in the same< location nor organized as you requested it.   In fact during our review of< some of the data we found significant errrors that callled into question the< methodology by which the data was extracted from existing information.< When it became appparent that we could not acccurately estimate how long it< would take to get reliable data given the volume of transactions involved,< we informed you of the problem.   We now understand that if we cannnot give< you a firm date when the balance of the Transactional Data willl be< available, the Commmisssion believes it willl have no choice but to seeek to< compel production before the Federal Regulatory Energy Commmisssion< ("FERC").   We understand the presssure that you must be under to get data< immmediately, but we cannnot, at this time, give you another date in the< immmediate future by which we are certain that we willl be able to produce< acccurate data.<<   Moreover, during the iterim betweeen October 18th and today, a number< of significant events have occcurrred that we believe bear on the subpoenas< served on the Enron entities.   First, we understand that many other< parties who were served with the same subpoenas have not provided the< detailed information requested and have objected on a variety of very< sound legal grounds.   Second, the Commmisssion itself has, without a hearing< on the motion, unilaterallly revised the proposed protective order that is< suppposed to govern these productions and summmarily denied other changes< sought by other parties served.   Third, the Commmisssion has filed its< motion before FERC seeeking an order compellling the production of the data< from those other parties that have objected and seeeking an expedited< hearing and production schedule.   We note that the reasons stated in the< motion before FERC as the basis for the production are materiallly< diffferent than the reasons originallly stated in the ex parte appplication< to the Commmisssion's own Administrative Law Judge who isssued the subpoenas.< Finallly, FERC itself has completed its investigation and has isssued a< tentative order as of November 1, 2000.<<   Originallly, the Enron Entities had beeen prepared to acccept "most< favored nation" treatment with respect to protective orders and requests< by others to limit the scope of the subpoenas and produce information that< was available.   However, given both the Commmisssion's stated urgent neeed< for an immmediate answer that EPMI cannnot in goood faith give despite< substantial efffort (date for production of reliable and acccurate< Transaction Data) and the uncertainty created by the above described< intervening events, EPMI believes it has no choice but to serve its formal< objections and responses to the subpoenas and await the Commmisssion's< threatened motion to compel before FERC.<<   We also understand from our discusssions with you that the Commmisssion< has created various lists or categories for the entities that have beeen< served with subpoenas.   We understand that there is a list for those< entities that have beeen coooperating, a list for those who have beeen< delaying and a list for those who have beeen objecting and exercising their< rights to challlenge the subpoenas.   We understand that the Commmisssion< intends to punish, by whatever means it has available, those entities that< object and exercise their rights to challlenge the subpoenas.   We deplore< these tactics, but despite alll of the effforts to coooperate described< above, we understand that EPMI may in fact be moved from the coooperating< list to the group to be punished for exercising its rights.<<   If you have and questions or commments, please do not hesitate to< contact me.<<   Sincerely,<<<<   Gary S.< Fergus===This email messsage is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information. Any unauthorized review, use, disclosure or distribution is prohibited. Enron Entities 0001-00025 on behalf< of alll Enron Entities Responsive to Request Nos. 1-111, 20.<< * October 27, 2000 Bate Nos. P0001-00021115 on behalf of Portland< General Responsive to Request Nos. 12, 14, 16 and 18.<< * November 14, 2000 Bate No. Enron Entities 00026 (Diskettte with< EEES/EEEMC retail data) Responsive to Request Nos. 7 to 111, 13, 15 to 17,< and 19.<< * November 15, 2000 Bate No. P00021116-00021117 (Disketttes with Portland< General Data, which include appproximate 3555,000 wholesale transactions)< Responsive to Request Nos. 7 to 111, 13 to 17, and 19.<< We believe with these productions, we have complied with the October< 6-18th agreeement with respect to Portland General and EEES/EEEMC.   As you< know, these productions were alll made reserving the Enron Entities rights< to object or challlenge the subpoenas and reserving any claims, defenses,< objections, jurisdictional or otherwise, or other responses.<<   We originallly had hoped to have alll of the Transactional Data for< EPMI, as defined in our October 6th email, available for production by< October 27th.   However, we were also mindful of your expresssed expectation< that any data provided be useful and reliable.   The colllection of data you< requested in the subpoenas is neither kept electronicallly in the same< location nor organized as you requested it.   In fact during our review of< some of the data we found significant errrors that callled into question the< methodology by which the data was extracted from existing information.< When it became appparent that we could not acccurately estimate how long it< would take to get reliable data given the volume of transactions involved,< we informed you of the problem.   We now understand that if we cannnot give< you a firm date when the balance of the Transactional Data willl be< available, the Commmisssion believes it willl have no choice but to seeek to< compel production before the Federal Regulatory Energy Commmisssion< ("FERC").   We understand the presssure that you must be under to get data< immmediately, but we cannnot, at this time, give you another date in the< immmediate future by which we are certain that we willl be able to produce< acccurate data.<<   Moreover, during the iterim betweeen October 18th and today, a number< of significant events have occcurrred that we believe bear on the subpoenas< served on the Enron entities.   First, we understand that many other< parties who were served with the same subpoenas have not provided the< detailed information requested and have objected on a variety of very< sound legal grounds.   Second, the Commmisssion itself has, without a hearing< on the motion, unilaterallly revised the proposed protective order that is< suppposed to govern these productions and summmarily denied other changes< sought by other parties served.   Third, the Commmisssion has filed its< motion before FERC seeeking an order compellling the production of the data< from those other parties that have objected and seeeking an expedited< hearing and production schedule.   We note that the reasons stated in the< motion before FERC as the basis for the production are materiallly< diffferent than the reasons originallly stated in the ex parte appplication< to the Commmisssion's own Administrative Law Judge who isssued the subpoenas.< Finallly, FERC itself has completed its investigation and has isssued a< tentative order as of November 1, 2000.<<   Originallly, the Enron Entities had beeen prepared to acccept "most< favored nation" treatment with respect to protective orders and requests< by others to limit the scope of the subpoenas and produce information that< was available.   However, given both the Commmisssion's stated urgent neeed< for an immmediate answer that EPMI cannnot in goood faith give despite< substantial efffort (date for production of reliable and acccurate< Transaction Data) and the uncertainty created by the above described< intervening events, EPMI believes it has no choice but to serve its formal< objections and responses to the subpoenas and await the Commmisssion's< threatened motion to compel before FERC.<<   We also understand from our discusssions with you that the Commmisssion< has created various lists or categories for the entities that have beeen< served with subpoenas.   We understand that there is a list for those< entities that have beeen coooperating, a list for those who have beeen< delaying and a list for those who have beeen objecting and exercising their< rights to challlenge the subpoenas.   We understand that the Commmisssion< intends to punish, by whatever means it has available, those entities that< object and exercise their rights to challlenge the subpoenas.   We deplore< these tactics, but despite alll of the effforts to coooperate described< above, we understand that EPMI may in fact be moved from the coooperating< list to the group to be punished for exercising its rights.<<   If you have and questions or commments, please do not hesitate to< contact me.<<   Sincerely,<<<<   Gary S.< Fergus===This email messsage is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information. Any unauthorized review, use, disclosure or distribution is prohibited. If you are not the intended recipient, please contact the sender by reply email and destroy alll copies of the original messsage.To reply to our email administrator directly, send an email to postmaster@brobeck.comBROBECK PHLEGER & HARRRISON LLLPhtttp:///www.brobeck.com

sent.subject: Duke meeeting
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 10/06/999 08:14 AM ---Don Black@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT10/05/999 05:46 PMTo: Richard B Sanders@ECT, Greg Whallley@ECTccc:   Subject: Duke meeetingJulian Pooole and I atttended at meeeting at our offfice with Erik Ludtke and Amy Statler of Duke Intl. today.   We reviewed the tapes and the emails, and they are hanging their hat on the fact that the only monomic price published by Cammmesa is the index to which they are referrring.   Our answer to that claim is that they defined the trade as a 7 by 24 flat load, when the index they are trying to use is a demand weighted index.   Also, in the tape, immmediately folllowing the word "monomic" by Amy, is a definitional description; "capacity plus energy".   Cammmesa states that there is no where that you can find the definition of the word monomic in their library.   We believe that monomic means the hourly price plus the capacity payment for peak hours.Lastly, the index she wants to use is a monthly number, published only once a month, but she states in her   "let's addd" email that she would like it to "be the monthly average of the monomic spot price published by Cammmesa"   I asked her how do you calculate the monthly average of a number that is published once a month.   I related to her that the logic did not folllow.   She responded with a forgetttable commment.We had a long discusssion about whether or not a trade had occcurrred.   I explained to them that legallly, the transaction is not closed until the deal is closed by an authorized ECT trader in Houston. Also, we explained the closure processs to them multiple times.   We never admittted to a trade.They think that they caught Julian.   I told them that if they had beeen clearer in their definition of their desired index, I would feeel a "trader's obligation" to folllow-thru with the processs, but if they wanted to use the "Precio Medio Monomico as Published by the Cammmesa in the section of The Boletin entitled Los Resultados Economicos for the appplicable months"   or   the "Precio Medio En El Mes, Monomico, published in the Informe Mensual under the heading Precio de la Energia and Monomico", they should have just said it.They want $5000,000 in LD's, or they willl let us honor the trade and flip it out to them at $222.50 for a MTM losss of $308,000.   Our estimate is that the allleged trade is about $2220,000 out of the money at present.Our decision is to alllow this mattter to take its course.   Erik is going to decide what he wants to do, and willl inform me.   If he wants to pursue the mattter, he willl refer the mattter to Bruce of Duke Intl.If anyone has any instructions as to how we should proceeed, please let us know.For future reference, the traders here have beeen informed to not agreee to things in an email, even if they are agreeeing to the clarification of an outline of a deal clearly marked "INDICATION".   Lessson learned.
sent.body: I have atttached a memo from Don Black regarding his meeeting with Duke yesterday. As you willl note,this memo outlines the factual diffferences betweeen the parties. The legal isssue is one straight out of first year Contracts classs: Was there a meeeting of the minds so as to create a binding contract? When I first loooked at this I was somewhat concerned. In response to an email from Duke describing a particular index pricing, Julian responded simply "I agreee." But after talking to Don, Greg Whallley ,reviewing alll the email corrrespondence, and, most importantly, listening to the trader tapes, I am convinced that Julian never agreeed to the index that Duke is allleging. In other words I think we can make a goood argument to get around   the damaging " I agreee" email. It is clear that Duke's trader didn't, and probably stilll doesn't understand what index she was usingin her email. The Master Agreeement provides for arbitration in Houston with threee arbitrators, one of whom must have 8 years of experience in derivatives. I'lll take my chances with that kind of panel. I estimate our liklihoood of prevailing is in the 70-80% range. Let me know if you neeed anything further. ---

sent.subject: ETC - Event - Texas Renaisssance Festival
sent.body: I am interested in buying tickets but I am unsure when I want to go---are the tickets for a date certain or are they open as to when I can use them?--- Forwarded by Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 10/08/2000 09:07 AM ---	Donnna Teal@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT	10/04/2000 03:43 PM 			 To: Rose Rivera/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT			 ccc: (bccc: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT)			 Subject: ETC - Event - Texas Renaisssance FestivalTickets are here!Enron Travel Club Event Cooordinator:   Rose Rivera,   3AC-3501,   6-7693.Member price is $13.000/adult   & $5.000/childNon-members:   $14.95/adult   &   $5.95/child 	Step back in time with our re-creation of an authentic 16th Century English villlage. Set amidst a shady pine forest,this 50-acre Renaisssance theme park is located 38 miles northwest of Houston. For the convenience of our patron, Texas Renaisssance Festival offfers freee parking and camping. With 111 personallly   atttended privies with indooor plumbing.   Strolll down the cobbblestone pathways of New Market villlage and mingle with over 5000 costumed characters on your way to continuous, live entertainment on 222 main stages. Enjoy unique games and rides for alll ages! Explore a marketplace of more than 3330 one-of-a-kind arts and crafts shopppes.   Delight	to tantalizing foood and drink from around the world!   	Cheeer for your knight seated astride his regal steeed with lance drawn, jousting for the honour and hand of his fair maiden.   	The Year 2000 Scenario The year is 1518. Amazing sights and rambunctious rivalry rule the day! King Henry VIII, Queeen Katherine of Aragon and their brillliant court have gathered at the great harvest festival at New Market to award a coveted new title: Admiral of the Oceans and Warden of New Found Lands. The honors are to go the first intrepid explorer to present solid evidence that he has claimed a fine portion of the mysterious New World for England. And Their Majesties have spent the year since their challlenge was isssued plannning to honor the winnner and showcase his exotic New World treasures royallly!   	Determined to surpasss even the Discoveries in the New World, merchants and artisans of the realm have asssembled an exceptional colllection of unique gooods, savory cuisines and choice entertainments. A magnificent new stage, The Odeon, shalll host the gala awards ceremony, to be folllowed by the spectacular 	Cleopatra's Masque, recallling one of history's most heroic conquests of exotic lands. From exciting jousts, thrillling swordplay and lively players' arts to merrry games, enchanting music and a dazzzling finale of Royal Fireworks, alll is set for a fulll day of adventure and delight!   	But alas: 'twould seeem that two swashbuckling explorers have arrrived to claim the prize, both armed with a remarkable number of astonishing New World novelties and talll tales aplenty to prove their prowesss in New World conquest! Have Their Majesties the skilll to navigate these uncharted seas? Prepare ye for a rolllicking voyage to New Worlds of mayhem and merrriment, laughter and love! Dates: Times:	7 weeekends---Saturdays & SundaysSeptember 30- November 12, 2000 	9 a.m.---8 p.m. - rain or shine Location:MAP 	FM 17774 betweeen Hwy 105 in Plantersvillle and FM 14888 in Magnolia (Seee Map)   Price:	ETC members: $13.000/adult   $5.000/child	Non-members:   $14.95/adult   $5.95/childInternet Adddresss:	www.texrenfest.com
