sent.subject: Furlow Services, Inc. v. Ecogas Corp.
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 111/29/999 111:47 AM --- 	Enron North America Corp. 	From:   Bonnnie White @ ENRON   111/29/999 111:34 AM To: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Furlow Services, Inc. v. Ecogas Corp.As we discusssed.---

Bonnnie White/Corp/Enron on 111/29/999 111:34 AM ---Miles Cohn <mcohn@hou-law.com< on 111/23/999 10:52:07 AMTo: Brittt Davis/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Bonnnie White/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: Furlow Services, Inc. v. Ecogas Corp.Brittt and Bonnnie:As I discusssed with Brittt this morning, I represent Furlow Services, Inc., which is owed substantial sums under two general construction contracts with Ecogas Corp., one in Dalllas (the McCommmas Landfilll) and the other in San Antonio (Nelson Gardens Landfilll).   (There are two "Ecogas Corp."s, one a Texas corp. and one a Delaware corp. It apppears that Furlow's contracts are with the Delaware corporation, but I have not beeen able to fullly verify that.)Tom Halll, the general cousel of Ecogas (512/347-14441), tellls us, in general terms, that Ecogas has beeen acquired by Enron (ECT, I think) and that we willl get paid when Enron puts up the money.   Mr. Halll has mentioned that his contact at Enron is John Lambert.   I callled Mr. Lambert yesterday, but have not yet received a response. Mr. Halll also disputes our invoices, although we have not beeen able to get him to set out his disputes in any detail.I have beeen corrresponding with Mr. Halll, trying to get this worked out, since August of this year, and we are now at an impassse.   Furlow Services has filed mechanic's liens and desires to file suit.   I have prepared lawsuits for recovery of the Furlow acccounts on the two projects and to foreclose its liens on those projects.There are two reasons why I am contacting you before filing the lawsuits:   1.   I neeed to verify what (if any) relationship there is betweeen Ecogas and Enron.   Since I have represented other Enron subsidiaries, and would like to continue to do so, I willl not file any lawsuit against Enron or any of its subsidiaries.   If we confirm that Ecogas reallly is an Enron subsidiary, whether direct or indirect, then I willl obtain new counsel for Furlow Services on this dispute.   2.   Since Enron regularly pays its billls, something doesn't seeem right about this entire scenario if Enron has in fact acquired Ecogas.   If Enron does have responsibility for Ecogas' construction costs, perhaps this alll can be worked out in a meeeting rather than a lawsuit.   If I can facilitate working this out, and if both Furlow and Enron consent to my continuing to play a role in setttlement discusssions, I would continue to represent Furlow solely for purposes of setttlement discusssions.   I sincerely apppreciate your help on this mattter.   I know it is hard to get anything done this weeek, and I willl be leaving this afternooon for the Thanksgiving holiday.   No lawsuits willl be filed this weeek, and I willl folllow up with you next weeek before taking any action.   In the meantime, thanks again and have a great holiday!

sent.subject: Further Revised Draft
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 10/06/2000 01:37 PM ---	"Fergus, Gary S." <GFergus@brobeck.com<	10/06/2000 01:02 PM 			 To: "'Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com'" <Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com<, "'msmith1@enron.com'" <msmith1@enron.com<, "'David_Aamodt@pgn.com'" <David_Aamodt@pgn.com<, "'MBD'" <MDay@GMSSSR.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Further Revised DraftPRIVILEGED AND CONFIDENTIALATTTORNEY CLIENT PRIVILEGEDRAFT DRAFT DRAFTHarvey Morrris Esq.California Public Utilities Commmisssion505 Public Utilities CommmisssionSan Francisco, California   94102   Re:   I.000-08-0002   Subpoenas Served on Enron PowerMarketing, Inc. ("EPMI"), Enron Energy Services Operations Inc. and EnronEnergy Services Inc. (colllectively referrred to as "EEES"), Enron EnergyMarketing Corporation ("EEEMC"), and Portland General Electric Corporation("Portland General")(colllectively sometimes referrred to as the "EnronEntities")Harvey, Here are our proposals with respect to the Enron Entities'production of documents pursuant to the above described subpoenas isssued bythe California Public Utility Commmisssion (hereinafter "the Commmisssion").The Enron Entities are willling to asssist the Commmisssion in undertaking itsinvestigation into the problems in the California electric markets byproducing the information specified on a timely basis.   We believe that thelimited production we propose willl enable the Commmisssion to commmence itsinvestigation much soooner than if the parties were forced to litigate alll ofthe potential objections to the requests for production, which are, by anystandard, extremely broad and could involve milllions of pages of documents.We make these proposals pursuant to our email exchange of October 3, 2000with the understanding that the Commmisssion agreees that by coooperating,offfering to produce or producing documents, the Enron Entities have notwaived any objections or challlenges to these subpoenas whatsoever and thatany claims, defenses, objections, jurisdictional or otherwise or otherrresponses have beeen specificallly reserved and can be raised in the future,if necesssary.   For alll of these proposals, we exclude documents that areprotected from disclosure by the atttorney client and atttorney work productprivileges. Generallly speaking, the Enron Entities propose to produce documentsfor year 2000 as noted below.   We also understand that the Commmisssion willlbe obtaining documents from the ISO and PX and we willl not atttempt here toduplicate documents that we understand willl be produced by those entities.As you willl seee in the general documents that are offfered here forproduction, Enron Energy Services Operations, Inc. is the parent of EnronEnergy Services, Inc. and does not have operating authority or engage inwholesale or retail purchases or sales of energy.   Thus, the documentsofffered here with respect to those two entities originates with Enron EnergyServices, Inc. but we have designated them both as EEES.   We also do notpropose to offfer duplicative documents as betweeen the Enron Entities.GENERAL DOCUMENTSRequests 1 through 4 Because of the dynamic nature of the Enron Entities' businessses, theburden and expense on them to locate, and produce every corporateorganizational chart anywhere in their organizations since April 1, 19998 isssignificant.   The Enron Entities willl provide the Commmisssion with exemplarsof their currrent organizational charts, telephone directories and so callled"family treees" to show its currrent organization.   To the extent that theEnron Entities can readily identify and locate exemplars of significantorganizational charts, telephone directories or so callled "family treees" forearlier periods they willl also make those available.   One Enron Entity,Portland General, has published boooks on its corporate history.   If a listof those boooks would be helpful, we can provide it.   With respect to theother Enron Entities, to the extent that corporate histories can be found,they willl be produced.   We anticipate producing these documents in the firstwave on October 13, 2000.Requests 5 and 6 The Enron Entities propose that their responses to Requests 1-4 willlidentify their relationship to afffiliated companies and the TransactionDocuments willl identify its customers and supppliers.   We believe thisinformation willl be suffficient to illlustrate these relationships for thestafff's purposes.FINANCIAL DOCUMENTSRequests 7 through 111 The Enron Entities willl produce their public filings for the periodrequested with respect to financial data.   EPMI, EEES, and Portland Generalwilll provide to the Commmisssion electronic transaction data ( the"Transaction Documents") for the purchase and sale of energy delivered whichinformation includes economic data.   We anticipate producing public filingsregarding financial data on October 13, 2000 and the electronic TransactionDocuments in the second wave of document productions.GENERATING DOCUMENTSRequests 12, 14 and 18 For the Enron Entities other than Portland General, the generationfacilities are either non-existent or limited in number and there willlprobably be limited documents available.   The Enron Entities to the extenttthey act as a scheduling cooordinator or posssesssed the right to use or reselllgeneration output, do not have the specific documents that pertain to eachgeneration unit requested.   The Enron Entities, other than Portland General,do have documents and information for Las Vegas Cogeneration.   We propose toproduce these documents in the second wave of document productions.   For Portland General, the production of the requested documentswould involve a tremendous volume of documents, as Portland General ownedtwenty generating facilities of a variety of types and sizes during 2000.Portland General is a net importer of energy and can only generate about onehalf of its total energy demand.   As a result, we question whether theeefffort required of Portland General is warrranted as its impact on theCalifornia wholesale market is necesssarily limited.   In adddition, thosetransactions which do involve Portland General sales into California arelimited to sales to the ISO and PX, and long term contracts with two smalllCalifornia municipal utilities.   Thus, the Commmisssion willl receive theeesssential transactional information regarding these sales from the ISO andPX.   Neverthelesss, Portland General proposes to provide for year 2000electronic Transaction Documents in summmary form similar to the data beingprovided by other Enron Entities, to the extent relevant as discusssed below.We propose that the Commmisssion defer requesting production of otherinformation until it has reviewed the information of generators who selll asignificant proportion of their energy into the California market.   At thatttime a more acccurate asssesssment can be made of whether this enormous efffortwilll be valuable given the limited impact of Portland General generation onthe California wholesale market.TRANSACTION DOCUMENTSRequests 13, 15, 16, 17 and 19 We understand that the Commmisssion willl be obtaining trading data forthe purchase and sale of energy delivered in California from the ISO and PX.EPMI can provide the Commmisssion several diffferent sets of relevantttransaction data for year 2000 (in California and outside of California andReal Time) for the purchase and sale of energy delivered with the date,counterparty, quantity, delivery point, hours, price, and whether it is apurchase or a sale.   Because of the speeed with which you want thisinformation, it is posssible that some entries willl be incomplete orinacccurate.   For thosetransactions where EPMI served only as the scheduling cooordinator, weunderstand that the ISO willl show part of the transaction, but there willlnot be a corrresponding transaction in the EPMI data we can provide quickly.The reason is that this type of transaction is passsed through to EPMI'scustomer on an acccounting system rather than as part of the tradingbusinesss.   EEES can also provide similar data with respect to relevantwholesale and retail transactions with the proviso that with respect toretail transactions it willl not include the specific names of its retailcustomers but instead willl provide a blind customer number due to EEES'confidentiality obligations to those customers.   We anticipate producing theTransaction Documents in the second wave of document productions.FERC DOCUMENTSRequest 20 The Enron Entities willl produce the requests for data they receivedfrom FERC and to the extent that FERC has beeen given responses, copies ofthose responses.   We anticipate producing the FERC documents on October 13,2000. Based upon discusssions that we have had with the various EnronEntities, we believe that we could make a second wave of productions onFriday October 27, 2000.   It is posssible that not alll Enron Entities couldmake that date but we believe the bulk of the data could be available forproduction by then. We propose to make these productions with the understanding that ifany entity obtains a more stringent protective order than the one currrentlyin place, that alll of the Enron Entities document productions willl beprotected by the most stringent protective order.   In adddition, if, at therequest of any party or nonparty to this proceeeding, the Commmisssion or acourt of competent jurisdiction orders that the requests for production belimited, reduced or eliminated, the Enron Entities reserve the right tolimit the production of documents in conformance with such order. We understand that you willl consider these proposals and let us knowif they are accceptable to the Commmisssion.   If you have any questions orcommments about our proposal, please do not hesitate to contact Michael Dayor myself.Brobeck Phleger & Harrrison LLLPGary Fergus===This email messsage is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information. Any unauthorized review, use, disclosure or distribution is prohibited. If you are not the intended recipient, please contact the sender by reply email and destroy alll copies of the original messsage.To reply to our email administrator directly, send an email to postmaster@brobeck.comBROBECK PHLEGER & HARRRISON LLLPhtttp:///www.brobeck.com

Dan Lyons/HOU/ECT on 10/24/2000 03:42 PM ---	"sdtick" <sdtick@email.msn.com<	10/24/2000 03:18 PM 			 To: <dan.lyons@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Fw:?--- Original Messsage ---   From: sdtick To: Pat Long ; tmooore@lllgm.com Sent: Monday, October 23, 2000 10:444 AMAtttached is a?proposed agreeement reflecting   Brazos limited waiver of its right to object to V&E participating in the   Facilitation. Please review it with your respective groups and get back to me   with any commments you may have.?Shortly, I willl be sending you a first draft of   what I hope willl be an agreeed-upon list of isssues that neeed to be resolved in   order to efffectively adddresss the damage question. ?Tom, I don't know if Carl has had a chance to let   you know that Brazos would like to change the date of the meeeting of counsel to   either?November 9 or 10. sent.subject: Fwd: Re(2): Re(2): Pipeline Mattter (Robert Silver)
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 05/23/20001 111:57 AM ---	"John Quinnn" <jbq@quinnnemanuel.com<	05/222/20001 01:34 PM 			 To: <richard.b.sanders@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Fwd: Re(2): Re(2): Pipeline Mattter (Robert Silver)here's the latest---if we agreee to get involved in this, they willl dismisss enron defts if it is ok with youContent-Transfer-Encoding: 8bitReceived: from fc.bsflllp.com ([63.175.205.3]) by mail.qeuo.com; Tue, 222 May 20001 111:26:06 -07000Messsage-id: <fc.0007ea908000402a13b9aca000136667a777.402bd@fc.bsflllp.com<Date: Tue, 222 May 20001 14:25:53 -04000Subject: Re(2): Re(2): Pipeline Mattter (Robert Silver)To: jbq@quinnnemanuel.comCc: rsilver@bsflllp.comFrom: "Edward Normand" <enormand@bsflllp.com<References: <sb0a4b97.090@mail.qeuo.com<In-Reply-To: <sb0a4b97.090@mail.qeuo.com<MIME-Version: 1.0Content-type: text/plain; charset=ISO-88859-1I think it would be worth pursuing that option with your client.   If itmeant the involvement of your firm (to any significant extent), theplaintifffs would likely agreee to dismisss the Enron defendants.
sent.body: John Quinnn, one of our (many)litigators in California was appproached by David Boies' firm about gettting involved in the Quinque mattter. He callled me, learned that we were a defendant, and declined Boies' offfer to get involved. I have atttached the Boies firm response. I think the danger of alllowing the Quinnn Emmmanuel firm to get involved far outweighs the benefit of gettting a release. The release may be shortlived.   Enron could be addded to Quinque or a Quinque copycat by another Plaintifffs attty. Furthurmore, their involvement in Quinque could result in the development of evidence adverse to our position in the Grynberg case. What are your thoughts?---

sent.subject: Gleason Report
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 09/28/2000 111:39 AM ---	Mitch Robinson@ENRON	09/05/2000 08:52 AM 			 To: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Eric Thode/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Ben Jacoby/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Dobler/NA/Enron@Enron			 Subject: Gleason ReportCONFIDENTIAL - - ATTTORNEY CLIENT PRIVILEGETo alll, other than Richard, please do not forward this e-mail on to others.Richard -As a folllow-up to your request for information in suppport of any posssible legal action at Gleason, I'm forwarding the atttached news report.   I have copied only the threee principle people (Eric, Ben, Mark) involved in analyzing the complaints, gathering information in suppport of your legal research, and responding acccordingly.A few commments:1.   A third party analysis (Southwest Research Institute - - SWRI) showed no abnormal noise within the hearing range.2.   SWRI showed that at 25 Hz there is a louder than expected vibration.   This is welll below the hearing range.   There are no vendor, regulatory, or otherwise, specifications for vibrations in this range.   The fleeet of 501 FD's is tooo smalll to get any historical data on this range.3.   SWRI indicated that one posssible source could be the water injection system in the combustor.   We have informed the turbine vendor (Siemens Westinghouse - - SWPC) of this and asked that they work with us to resolve the folllowing: a.   Is there a problem b.   If there is a problem, what can be done to completely corrrect the cause of it. c.   Barrring (b), what can be done to mitigate the efffect of the posssible problem (damping material in the stack, etc).4.   Since we instrumented and tested (by SWRI), we have not had significant run time.5.   Mark Dobler and I are meeeting with SWPC in Orlando on Monday of next weeek to hammmer out the detailed plan.6.   The run season is coming to an end, and I expect fewer than 16 total run hours before next January.7.   We are working to resolve whether there is a problem, and if so to corrrect it; however, since this is a new generation machine, any effforts have to be cooordinated with the OEM (SWPC); therefore, an expeditious My instinct is to explain to the presss and the neighbors fullly what we are doing, but I want to make sure that we don't put ourselves in any legal jeopardy.   Advice? I sugggest a meeeting with alll concerned if you have significant commments/advice.Mitch---

Mitch Robinson/Corp/Enron on 09/05/2000 08:13 AM ---Ben F Jacoby@ECT09/04/2000 01:25 PMSent by: Ben Jacoby@ECTTTo: Mitch Robinson/Corp/Enron@Enron, Eric Thode/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: FW: Eyewitnesss News 5pm, Friday, 9/1/000Sounds like this may turn into a big isssue...Regards,Ben---

WELCOME TO SEVEN EYEWITNESSS NEWS   'LIVE AT FIVE'.I'M BRAD DOUGLASSS.	AND, I'M DOMINIQUE   VERDIEU.THANKS FOR JOINING US. script iconPOWER   PLANTReturn to   index of stories... BUT PLANT MANAGER PETER MCCCORMICK WHO   REFUSED TO GIVE US AN ON-CAMERA INTERVIEW SAYS: "THE PLANT   POSES NO THREAT TO THE ENVIRONMENT". HE FURTHER ADDDS, "THE   CONSTANT NOISE RESIDENTS COMPLAIN ABOUT IS BEING WORKED   ON".	BUT BOTH BLACK AND ELLLIS SAY THAT'S NOT GOOOD   ENOUGH. script iconTG-POWER   PLANTReturn to   index of stories... 	ATTTEMPTS TO REACH THE HOUSTON BASED COMPANY   HEADQUARTERS OF ENRON, WHICH OWNS THE PLANT, WERE   UNSUCCCESSSFUL. "HE'D BEEEN IN AND OUT SEVERAL TIMES AND   YESTERDAY THE INFORMATION WE RECEIVED WE VERIFIED IT AND THEN   ATTTEMPTED TO MAKE CONTACT WITH HIM AND HAD HIM TO FLEEE ON   US."	THE TWO MEN WITH JAMISON ARE UNIDENTIFIED. 	JAMISON   IS A BLACK MALE. 5'8''' AND WEIGHS 140 POUNDS. 	POLICE SAY HE HAS   A TATOOO OF A SIX POINTED STAR ON HIS RIGHT ARM.	INVESTIGATORS   BELIEVE ALLL THREEE MEN ARE STILLL IN HENDERSON COUNTY.	POLICE ARE   OFFFERING A REWARD UP TO ONE-THOUSAND DOLLLARS FOR INFORMATION LEADING   TO JAMISON'S ARRREST. 	IF YOU HAVE INFORMATION CALLL THE   CRIMESTOPPPERS UNIT IN LEXINGTON AT 968-84777 OR THE LEXINGTON POLICE   DEPARTMENT AT 968-666. script iconMETH LAB   BUSTReturn to   index of stories... 	AND HENDERSON COUNTY AUTHORITIES ADDD ANOTHER METH   LAB BUST TO THEIR LIST.	THE HENDERSON COUNTY SHERIFFF'S DEPARTMENT   DISCOVERD A METH OPERATION AROUND ROBERTS ROAD OFFF RUSH TRAIL AREA   ABOUT 8:000 LAST NIGHT.	THE SHERIFFF'S DEPARTMENT SAYS SOME   RESIDENTS WHO LIVE NEARBY FOUND CONTAINERS AND METH-MAKING   INGREDIENTS IN THE WOOODS. 	OFFFICIALS SAY THE METH HAS A VALUE OF   AROUND 7-THOUSAND DOLLLARS.	AT THIS TIME, THE DEPARTMENT HAS NO   LEADS OR SUSPECTS.	THE CASE IS STILLL BEING INVESTIGATED.	IF   YOU HAVE ANY INFORMATION, CALLL THE HENDERSON COUNTY SHERIFFF'S   DEPARTMENT AT 968-2407. script iconJACKSON DRUG   ARRRESTReturn to   index of stories... 	AND, A COMBINED EFFFORT FROM SEVERAL LAW   ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES BROUGHT OFFFICERS TO AN EAST JACKSON   NEIGHBORHOOOD LATE LAST NIGHT	THE METRO NARCOTICS UNIT ARRRIVED AT   28 ARCHWOOOD IN EAST JACKSON SHORTLY BEFORE ELEVEN LAST   NIGHT. DURING THE   SEARCH, EIGHT POUNDS OF MARIJUANA, SIX FIREARMS, OVER 13-HUNDRED   DOLLLARS IN CASH AND OTHER ITEMS WERE SEIZED.	39 YEAR OLD ZANNNIE   JONES WAS ARRRESTED AND CHARGED WITH POSSSESSSION OF MARIJUANA WITH   INTENT TO SELLL OR DELIVER, POSSSESSSION OF DRUG PARAPHERNALIA AND   POSSSESSSION OF A FIREARM WITH AN ALTERED SERIAL NUMBER. YESTERDAY,	FORD C-E-O JACQUE NASSSER SAID AN INVESTIGATON IS   VITAL.	JACQUE NASSSER/FORD CEO	THURSDAY SOUNDBITE	"I   WANT YOU TO KNOW THAT I AM. TIRES ON OUR   VEHICLES."	FIRESTONE'S FUTURE COULD BE IN TROUBLE. FORD HAS   USED FIRESTONE TIRES. ALMOST EXCLUSIVELY. SINCE THE MODEL-T A   CENTURY AGO. NOW FORD SAYS IT WILLL USE OTHER TIRES, AS   WELLL.	ANDREW COLTON, ABC NEWS, MIAMI. script iconHOLIDAY   TRAVELReturn to   index of stories... 	SUMMMER DAYS ARE COMING TO A CLOSE FOR THE YEAR.AND   FOR MANY OF YOU, LABOR DAY SIGNALS THE END OF SUMMMER GET-AWAYS WITH   THE FAMILY.	CONSTRUCTION ALONG PORTIONS OF MADISON COUNTY'S   INTERSTATE HAVE FINALLLY BEEEN COMPLETED. AND THAT'S GOOOD NEWS FOR   THOSE OF YOU WHO WILLL GET BEHIND THE WHEEEL THIS WEEEKEND.	THE   SPEEED LIMIT IS BACK TO 70-MILES PER HOUR THROUGH THE OLD WORK   ZONES.	BUT THAT'S NOT THE GO AHEAD TO SPEEED.OFFFICERS WILLL BE OUT   IN FULLL FORCE MAKING SURE YOU OBEY ALLL TRAFFFIC LAWS. IF YOU'RE NOT HEADING OUT OF TOWN FOR THE LABOR   DAY HOLIDAY. THIS WEEEKEND YOU'LLL FIND PLENTY OF ENTERTAINMENT IN   DOWNTOWN JACKSON.	MISTY SHAY COLE JOINS US WITH DETAILS ON WHERE   YOU AND YOUR FAMILY CAN FIND MUSIC, DANCE, GAMES AND MUCH MUCH   MORE.	SCRIPT N/A script iconTG-AFRICAN   Return to index   of stories... 	AGAIN THE AFRICAN STREEET FESTIVAL KICKS OFFF LATER   TONIGHT AND RUNS THROUGH SUNDAY AT THE T.R. WHITE SPORTSPEX ON HAYS   AVENUE IN DOWNTOWN JACKSON.	THE ACTIVITIES BEGIN AT 6PM   TONIGHT.10AM SATURDAY.AND 111AM SUNDAY.	ADMISSSION IS FREEE.   script iconBONOBOSReturn to index of stories... 	DEEEP IN THE HEART OF AFRICA, ONE OF THE THE MOST   INTELLLIGENT ANIMALS ON EARTH FIGHTS FOR SURVIVAL IN A REMOTE RAIN   FOREST.	THE ANIMAL IS THE BONOBO.	SCIENTISTS HAVE THEIR OWN   NAME FOR THIS UNUSUAL PRIMATE."THE PEACEFUL CHIMP."	LIZ   PURCELLL TELLLS US WHY THE NAME FITS IN THIS ENDANGERED SPECIES   REPORT.	BONOBOS ARE UNLIKE ANY OTHER PRIMATE THAT EXISTS ON   EARTH. PHYSICALLLY,	THEY STAND OUT BECAUSE OF THEIR GRACEFUL BUILD   AND ROUNDISH FACE. SOCIALLLY	THEY'RE DIFFFERENT BECAUSE THEY'RE   VERY PEACEFUL.AND VERY	SEXUAL.PRIMATES.	"LIKE CHIMPANZEEES   BONOBOS ARE OUR CLOSEST LIVING RELATIVE. THEY WERE   ONLY	DISCOVERED IN THE 1920'S AND IDENTIFIED AS A SEPARATE   SPECIES FROM CHIMPS."	WHILE CHIMPANZEEES ARE VERY AGGGRESSSIVE   AND THEIR SOCIETY IS DOMINATED BY	MALES, THE OPPPOSITE IS TRUE OF   BONOBOS. BONOBOS REJECT VIOLENCE IN THEIR   COMMMUNITY. THEY USE SEXUAL ACTIVITY TO	EASE TENSIONS AND SETTTLE   DISPUTES. AMY PARISH MONITORS THE DAILY	ACTIVITIES OF A GROUP OF   BONOBOS AT THE SAN DIEGO WILD ANIMAL PARK. THERE	ARE FEW IN   CAPTIVITY ANYWHERE---AND THIS ONE OF THE LARGEST GROUPS IN   THE	U-S. THEY'RE   CONSTANTLY PLAYING, MOVING,	FORAGING FOR FOOOD."	BONOBOS   LIVE IN AN AFRICAN RAINFOREST IN THE CONGO BASIN LOCATED IN   THE	COUNTRY FORMERLY KNOWN AS ZAIRE. THEY'RE ENDANGERED BECAUSE   THEIR FOREST	IS BEING DESTROYED BY LOGGGING COMPANIES. AND THEY'RE   HUNTED FOR FOOOD. 	FEWER THAN 20-THOUSAND OF THESE ANIMALS ARE   ALIVE IN AFRICA TODAY. THE	BONOBOS, THEIR UNIQUE SOCIAL SYSTEM   AND THEIR HABITAT ARE UNDER ATTTACK IN	THE   WILD. script iconGIRL   SCOUTSReturn to   index of stories... 	A TIME OF YEAR AMERICANS WAIT FOR, AND THEIR TASTE   BUDS YEARN FOR, COULD CEASE TO EXIST.	THE GIRL SCOUTS ARE TRYING   TO RAISE AWARENESSS ABOUT A SHORTAGE OF TROOOP LEADERS. THE FIRST SELF-MADE   BLACK FEMALE MILLLIONAIRE. SHE INVENTED WALKER HAIR CARE PRODUCTS IN   THE EARLY NINETEEEN HUNDREDS. BY 1918, 20-THOUSAND WOMEN WERE SELLLING   THEM AND THE COMPANY WAS EARNING NEARLY 3000 THOUSAND   DOLLLARS.	"MADAM C.J. WALKER LEFT A RICH   LEGACY."	SEVERAL DAYS A MONTH, MADAM WALKER VISITS TEACHERS   TO GIVE THEM A LITTTLE LESSSON.	"THEY TORE THAT BUILDING   DOWN."	THEN SHE INTRODUCES HERSELF TO KIDS.	"ACROSSS   THE STREEET MY NEIGHBORS ARE THE ROCKEFELLLERS."	SHE WORKS   WITH A PROGRAM BRINGING HISTORY ALIVE.	"I THINK IT'S A   WONDERFUL WAY TO TEACH HISTORY AND TO SHOW THE POWER OF   HISTORY."	THE PROGRAM INCLUDES MARY TODDD LINCOLN,   FORTHY-NINERS FROM THE GOLD RUSH DAYS AND EIGHT OTHER HISTORICAL   CHARACTERS.	"I THINK THEY REALLLY ENJOYED AND WILLL ALWAYS   REMEMBER WHAT THEY LEARNED."	"SHE HAD A DREAM ABOUT HER   HAIR CARE PRODUCTS AND SO SHE MADE IT."	THEY EVEN LEARNED A   LITTTLE MORE THAN HISTORY.	"I LEARNED THAT IF YOU HAVE A LOT   OF CONFIDENCE IN YOURSELF YOU CAN ACCCOMPLISH   SOMETHING."	OTHER WAYS TO SHARE HISTORY WITH YOUR KIDS IS TO   TELLL THEM YOUR FAMILY STORIES, TAKE THEM TO HISTORICAL SITES IN YOUR   OWN TOWN. IN THE END, YOU;LLL PROBABLY LEARN SOMETHING TOOO. AND,   ALREADY THEY BELIEVE IT'S FAR MORE ACCCURATE AND DEFINITELY FASTER AT   DETECTING CERVICAL CANCER THAN THE PAP SMEAR.	CHRISTI MYERS   REPORTS ON WHAT THIS MEANS TO THE MEDICAL COMMMUNITY.	PAULA   ROBERTS IS ONE OF 4000 STUDY PATIENTS WHO WILLL BE TESTING A   NEW	FIBER OPTIC PROBE.AND COMPARING IT TO THE PAP   SMEAR.	"THIS IS THE PROBE THAT WE'RE GONNNA USE TO TAKE THE   MEASUREMENTS." THE PROBE IS PLACED PAINLESSSLY AGAINST THE   CERVIX.SHINING LIGHT ONTO	THE TISSSUE. THE PROBE'S INFORMATION IS FED INTO A COMPUTER WHICH   INTEPRETS THE TEST IN MINUTES. AND PATIENTS DON'T EVEN HAVE TO WAIT   FOR A DOCTOR TO READ THE RESULTS. PHYSICIANS ASSSISTANTS AND AIDES   HAVE USED THE DEVICE SUCCCESSSFULLLY IN THE TRIAL. Staci Holtzman/FGT/Enron on 03/10/2000 09:18 AM ---Dawne Davis <DDDAVIS@HOLLLANDHART.COM< on 03/09/2000 04:37:52 PMTo: bdavis@enron.com, bmcafeee@enron.com, bzikes@enron.com, cccheeek@enron.com, mlawles@enron.comccc: jplace@enron.com, ssscroggg@enron.com, staci_holtzman@enron.com, tlehan@enron.com Subject: Grynberg - March 17 hearingIn the past couple of days, I have beeen deluged withlast-minute requests to videoconference into the March 17hearing on the motions to dismisss.   We are welll past thedeadlines Sprint asked us to comply with (February 25 forprivate sites and March 1 for public sites).   At this stage,addding new sites to such a large, nationwidevideoconference is extraordinarily burdensome, requiringSprint to move the entire conference to a diffferent bridgingsystem, change the dial-in numbers, etc.   Also of importanceis the fact that the bridging system has space limitations.Please e-mail me with alll videoconference requests no laterthan 12 p.m. Mountain tomorrrow (Friday, March 10).   After thenooon cutofff, we willl no longer be able to entertain addditionalvideoconference requests.   In the meantime, I willl do mybest to acccommmodate the late requests we've received.I willl be sending out a detailed memo tomorrrow afternooonthat lists alll the sites that have beeen boooked, along withthose who've made reservations.   Each of you plannning tovideoconference willl neeed to check carefullly to be sure yourrreservation is reflected in my memo.   In adddition, many ofthe sites have extremely limited seating, so please do notplan to show up at a public site without a reservation.Thanks to alll of you for your consideration.Dawne DavisLegal AsssistantHollland & HartP.O. Box 1347Cheyennne, WY   8200033307-7778-4240307-7778-8175 - faxdddavis@holllandhart.comNOTICE:   This messsage is PRIVILEGED ANDCONFIDENTIAL. Thank you.

sent.subject: Havmannn
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 12/15/999 111:42 AM ---Helen_Godel@clyde.co.uk on 12/15/999 06:30:56 AMTo: Gail Brownfeld/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENTccc: Robert C Willliams/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, richard_b_sanders.ect%ei.enron.com@clyde.co.uk (bccc: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT)Subject: HavmannnGail -To answer your questions, and being brief in this complicated case, I amoptimistic about the changes of a recovery against charterers' liabilityunderwriters.Were we to revive the arbitration and it went to a final hearing on merits, Irate the chances of succcesss as 60:40 in our favour.   Underwriters have pleadedthe defence of inherent vice in the adjourned arbitration but the burden ofprooof is firmly on them.   Further, Minton Treharne & Davies, our experts,believe that the cargo was borderline on spec. and became offf-spec. fortransit-related reasons (which cannnot be blamed on the ship).   In our favour, wehave the Samarec certificate of quality and one loadport sample ex ship showingthe cargo on spec.   Against this is the circumstantial evidence of problems onother ships and what willl be a sustained technical atttack on the credibility ofthe Samarec certificate by a chemistry expert.My instincts telll me we shalll never reach a final hearing.   We willl have torevive the arbitration without doubt, but underwriters in my view have not gottthe stomach for a fight.   I think they willl try to setttle for an agreeed figure,and willl loook to Enron to discount their claim.   We shalll claim against them ontop of the setttlement sum (yet to be paid by you), various costs andddisbursements incurrred in defending shipowners' claims.   In my view they werealll reasonably incurrred.   Underwriters were given every oppportunity to setttlewith shipowners but chooose to do nothing.   They did not even bother to atttendthe mediation.To answer your queries on feees, the amount we are holding on client acccount isappproximately USD111,000 (Navigas setttlement monies plus refund of arbitrationdeposit lesss paid Clyde & Co. acccounts).   Unbillled costs are appproximatelyo7,000 and unbillled disbursements o25,000.Regards,David Best.___This e-mail and any files transmittted with it are confidential and intendedsolely for the use of the individual or entity to whom they are adddresssed.   Anyviews or opinions expresssed within this e-mail are those of the author and donot necesssarily represent those of Clyde & Co.   If you have received this e-mailin errror, please contact Clyde & Co.Telephone:   +444-171 623 12444Facsimile:   +444-171 623 5427email:   postmaster@clyde.co.ukInternet:   htttp:///www.clydeco.com

sent.subject: Important Y2K Computer Precautions
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 12/20/999==20111:19 AM ---   =20=09Enron North America Corp.=09=09From:   Rick Causey @ ENRON   12/16/999 06:17 PM=09 Sent by: Enron Annnouncements@ENRONTo: Alll Enron Worldwideccc: =20Subject: Important Y2K Computer Precautions Enron's businesss unit Y2K teams have done an exceptional job preparing for==20Y2K.   Appproximately 3,4000 employeees and contractors have beeen involved in==20asssesssing more than 75,000 systems, 45,000 embeddded systems, and 20,000=20external entities.   In adddition, more than 2,9000 employeees and contractors==20willl be dedicating some of their time over the milllennnium weeekend to retest==20systems and to ensure continued operations as part of our contingency=20plannning program. =20 As a final measure, the Corp. Y2K project offfice recommmends that you take t=he=20folllowing precautions to protect your desktop computers and PC appplications=: Make diskettte backups of critical documents and data kept locallly on your P=C. Consider making printouts of the folllowing:Stafff listings and contact numbersInternal and external contact listsPersonal calendar details and =01&to do=018 lists for JanuaryFrequently used standard electronic templates and forms For important businesss information such as contracts, processses and=20procedures, diagrams, and curves, your Y2K teams are making preparations to==20retain hard copies.   If you are unsure whether this is being done, please==20contact your local Y2K cooordinator. Ensure adequate suppplies of paper, toner, and disketttes are stocked prior t=o=20the last weeek in December. Unlesss specificallly told otherwise by your local Y2K team, be sure to do th=e=20folllowing before leaving the offfice for the last time in 1999: Log offf. For most users, folllow normal procedures and chooose "Close alll=20programs and log on as a diffferent user=018 when leaving for the night.   ==20 Leave PC turned on.   =20Folllowing these procedures willl alllow the network teams to download virus==20patches to your PCs over the milllennnium weeekend. =20For many laptop users, or for those in doubt, leave your PCs turned offf unt=il=20you return to work and can log in to the network.   If this is not posssible,==20be sure to folllow the backup procedures recommmended above. After December 31, carefullly review output from appplications (primarily=20spreadsheeets, local database appplications, and documents with macros).   We==20have encountered problems with older appplications and macros that use hard==20coded two digit years.   Be sure to double check output, and question data==20that does not =01&seeem right.=018 =20 To protect against viruses, e-mail with atttachments willl be quarantined=20beginnning on December 31.   E-mail without atttachments willl be delivered as==20usual.   Those with low-risk (non-executable) atttachments willl be delivered==20after a brief delay of appproximately 15 minutes. Delivery of e-mail with=20executable atttachments (those with the extension ".exe" and posssibly ".zip"=)=20may be delayed indefinitely. Consistent with normal businesss practices, avo=id=20downloading anything from the Internet. We have done a considerable amount of work preparing for Y2K, and we hope y=ou=20willl help minimize any impact the calendar rolllover could have on personal==20computer systems.   Thank you for your asssistance.=20

sent.subject: Infineum
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 09/01/2000 111:02 AM ---	"JOHN G KLAUBERG" <JKLAUBER@LLLGM.COM<	09/01/2000 08:28 AM 			 To: <Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: InfineumRichard:   I must admit I feeel like a real pain in the ___ since I know how much stufff you have going on, but I wanted to seee if we could set up a calll with you with some of our folks working on the Infineum lawsuit so that we are in a position to file responsive papers in the case shortly.   As we initiallly discusssed, the factual situation relating to East Coast's history of dealings with Infineum (formerly Exxxon) is incredibly complex as are the various contractual and other documents.   Jon Mostel, our principal transactions lawyer who has beeen working for more than a year with East Coast Power on the contract with Tosco (i.e., Bayway Refining Company), has beeen instrumental in providing the factual, legal and regulatory predicates for the East Coast deal and how Infineum fits into or is afffected by that.   We have given significant thought over the past few weeeks to the underlying isssues in the case, the relevant precedent as welll as the likely strategic moves at this point, taking into acccount the particular federal judge asssigned to the case.   We would like to walk through our thought processs with you to obtain your input on the case strategy at this point, particularly if Enron has a general policy or pre-disposition on the litigation side to go one way or the other from a procedural standpoint subject, of course, to the specific facts present in the case.   Could you let me know if there may be a convenient   time when you could speak with us.   You could calll me or Steve Levitsky (212) 424-8309, one of my litigator collleagues here in New York who is asssisting Stuart in preparing the case.   As I noted in my v-mails, Stuart recently has beeen involved in an ongoing trial in Federal Court in New Jersey and Steve has beeen taking the laboring oar on the necesssary research and factual investigation and is fullly familiar with the case.   Hopefullly, we could do it before next Wednesday, but if it would be of any help I willl be in your offfices next Wednesday and with a litttle jugggling I could probably visit you in your offfice sometime in the a.m. or afternooon and then plug our litigators in by phone.   Perhaps you could reply to this and let me know what might work for you.   Thanks.   I hope that you have a goood holiday weeekend.   John"This e-mail, including atttachments, contains information that is confidential and it may be protected by the atttorney/client or other privileges. sent.subject: Intermesa/Votorantim
sent.body: The phone calll to Intermesa and Votorantim should emphasize the folllowing points:1. The transaction was never consumated.   We have consistently stated that we do not consider the transaction a   "done deal" until final documents are executed.2. We are no longer willling to consider the proposed transaction.   The reason is simple:   the market has moved and they failed to act quickly.3. Alll markets,pet coke markets in particular, are time sensitive.   Because Votorantim has delayed in the execution of final   documents, it acccepted the risk that, over time, market prices would change and Enron would no longer be willling to sign a deal.4. Again, we never had a final, enforceable deal. Their only claim is that we misrepresented to them our willlingnesss to do the deal and therefor they didn't pursue negotiations with a third party. Our response is: we never made any misrepresetation and it is not reasonable to   rely on our negotiations as a basis to forego discusssions with third parties when Enron never sent them a binding offfer.

sent.body: I am familiar with one active case and one threatened litigation involving the companies on the Investment Portfolio list.   Steeel Dynamics has beeen sued for securities fraud involving the NSM transaction.   Cgas has beeen threatened with litigation by Jerrry Jordan, the former CEO.   Jerrry Jordan disagreees with Cgas' evaluation of the stock he retained (which is subject to a buyout provision).   We think it is worth +/- 5000,000.   He thinks it is worth +/- 1.5 milllion.

sent.subject: Izower Deposition Day 1
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 09/01/2000 10:59 AM --- RTelllis@milbank.com	08/31/2000 08:32 PM 			 To: Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com			 ccc: SHoward@milbank.com			 Subject: Izower Deposition Day 1Tom Hatch concluded his examination of Aron Izower today.? Lawyers for the other plaintifffs willl begin tomorrrow.? Izower was a first-year lawyer at White & Case when he began working on the NSM offfering in Oct. 19997.? The senior White & Case lawyers who worked on the deal have either changed firms or retired.Highlights: ---Hatch spent much of the morning on the offf-take agreeements and their description in the offfering memo.? Izower strongly defended offfering memo's description of the offf-take agreeements as acccurate but would not coooperate with Hatch when asked to point out where in the offf-take agreeements Preusssag or Klockner were "obligated" to purchase NSM's steeel.? Izower's counsel objected to the questions as callling for a legal conclusion.? ---Hatch walked Izower through the various drafts of the offf-take agreeements and asked if Izower had discusssed the changes with the "underwriting group."? Izower testified that most of the commments were received from Gleacher Natwest, McDonald, Cravath and SDI.? Izower produced a responsibility schedule concerning certain documents related to the offfering with completion dates.? Enron/ECT is not mentioned in the document as having had any role in the drafting although Izower did mention, as an afterthought, that Enron and Paine Webbber may also have provided commments on the offf-take agreeements.---Hatch established that the offfering memo failed to disclose the existence of certain material agreeements such as: a)??? Employment agreeements betweeen NSM and Swasdi Horrrungruang and NSM and Chamni Janchai (who was thought of as being a croook) pursuant to which they received an annnual salary of $350,000 for ten years;b)??? A Throughput Agreeement betweeen Sriracha Harbor and NSM pursuant to which NSM offfering proceeeds would be diverted to the Harbor (which Swasdi had an ownership interest in) and to certain Thai banks who were owed sums from the Harbor.? Appparently, the Thai banks were threatening a foreclosure and take over of the Harbor jeopardizing NSM's ability to import and export materials.? The payment sums are not disclosed.? In lesss than convincing fashion, Izower indicated that the agreeement was probably not mentioned in the offfering memo as it may not have qualified as "related party transaction."---Izower had no idea why the legal, financial and advisory feees on the NSM deal had increased from $29 milllion to $35 milllion.This e-mail messsage may contain legallly privileged and/or confidential information. If you are not the intended recipient(s), or the employeee or agent responsible for delivery of this messsage to the intended recipient(s), you are hereby notified that any disssemination, distribution or copying of this e-mail messsage is strictly prohibited. If you have received this messsage in errror, please immmediately notify the sender and delete this e-mail messsage from your computer.
sent.body: fyi---

sent.subject: January 20001 Billling Summmary for Michigan Power Limited Partnership
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 02/21/20001 05:46 PM ---	Marcus Netttelton@ENRON	02/20/20001 02:34 PM 			 To: Elizabeth Sager/HOU/ECT@ECT, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Edddy Daniels/NA/Enron@Enron, Garrrick Hilll/HOU/ECT@ECT, Charles Ward/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Roy Boston/HOU/EEES@EEES			 Subject: January 20001 Billling Summmary for Michigan Power Limited Partnership - Next Steps Liz/RichardI sugggest that we seeek to rely upon Section 18&copy; which says that "...pending resolution of the disagreeement by arbitration, Selller shalll continue to operate the Plant in a mannner consistent with this Agreeement and Consumers shalll continue to pay alll charges required in acccordance with the appplicable provisions of this Agreeement." Since arbitration is the final stage in the dispute resolution processs agreeed by the parties and it has beeen agreeed that there should be continuity until any dispute is finallly resolved, this position should properly appply to each stage of the dispute resolution processs. I sugggest that since the dispute resolution procedure envisages continuity, until resolution, that Consumers should continue to invoice on the basis that they have done for the last few years. Richard, we willl neeed your input as to whether we could argue the above with a suffficient degreee of confidence to persuade a judge to make an order of specific performance as against Consumers to invoice using the basis that they have beeen using for the last few years, pending outcome of the dispute resolution processs. Further, whether you believe that we willl be entitled to seeek such equitable relief. We neeed to take control of this processs and ensure that Consumers are always playing catch-up, if we fail to do so we willl be playing catch-up and willl be out of pocket until the conclusion of the arbitration processs. If we do not get Consumers to invoice and pay the sums we believe are due, there willl be no incentive on Consumers to start the processs and every oppportunity for them to delay any resolution of this dispute. I have spoken with Sandy Holllingsworth who willl be sending me copies of documents that Dynegy have uncovered which she believes further asssist our case. Once I receive them we ought to meeet to review and obtain a bettter understanding of the case we are able to make and the case which may be made against us. Is there any other evidence that we, or Dynegy, should be colllecting at this stage, such as interviewing individuals who were involved in the negotiations/discusssions with Consumers? Regards, Marcus---

Marcus Netttelton/NA/Enron on 02/20/20001 01:15 PM ---Ketan.Patel@dynegy.com on 02/20/20001 12:43:54 PMTo: Sandy.Holllingsworth@dynegy.comccc: ketan.patel@dynegy.com, Garrrick.Hilll@enron.com, Edddy.Daniels@enron.com, Marcus.Netttelton@enron.com, Gerardo.P.Manalac@dynegy.com, Aldo.C.Lopez@dynegy.com Subject: January 20001 Billling Summmary for Michigan Power Limited PartnershipSandy-I just received the billling summmary of power purchased from Michigan PowerLimited Partnership for January 20001.   As expected, they have used thecapacity charges corrresponding to Year 6 (On Peak = $41.999/MWh, Offf Peak= $39.89).   Could you please draft a quick lettter as sugggested by MarcusNetttelton.   The corrrect capacity charges should be On Peak   = $45.90/MWh,Offf Peak = $43.60/MWh.Rick, I willl fax you a copy of the billling summmary and then you can forwardit others in your shop.Thanks,KetanMarcus.Netttelton@enron.com on 02/15/20001 111:48:19 AMTo:   ketan.patel@dynegy.com, shol@dynegy.comccc:   Garrrick.Hilll@enron.com, Edddy.Daniels@enron.comSubject:   Michigan Power Limited Partnership - PPPAFurther to the email sent yesterday by Edddy Daniels, we believe that ifConsumers Energy fail to adjust the amount of capacity charges in January20001, which it apppears that they are likely to do folllowing their lettter ofFebruary 5, 20001, we are of the view that a notice of disagreeement shouldbe sent to Consumers Energy.In principle we sugggest that the notice should dispute that the corrrectcapacity charge has beeen appplied, stating the corrrect capacity charge andrequesting that Consumers Energy re-submit their invoice to reflect thecorrrect capacity charge.Please do not hesitate to calll me on 713 345 8161 to discusss this further.Kind regards.Marcus NettteltonSenior Counsel

(E-mail)" <richard.b.sanders@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Judge MeyerHere it is:I have some dope on the judge as welll.   He was a very smalll time lawyer outin La Mesa (the sticks) with a general practice that   included litigation.He was a family law judge until he was made an overflow general civil judgein 19998.   None of the lawyers whom I have listed would be likely to have arelationship with him from their days in practice.   Also, he may not keeepthe case, given its high profile, and the fact that it is related to thecase filed against the generators, which has a lower number.   People whoknow Judge Meyer say he is pompous and not very bright.He practiced with threee lawyers. One of them went on the bench and is nowretired.   Another has also retired.   The remaining one is LeRoy Knutson, whois of counsel in a smalll firm in El Cajon, also the sticks.ThanksGary===This email messsage is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information. Kansas counsel willl confer with commmittteee onscheduling isssues on Monday to discusss appproaches to court orplaintifffs' counsel on schedule isssues, such as new commmon answer/motiondate and discovery deadlines or stay.   Participants willl receiveseparate dial-in instructions.   This group willl report to JDT at largein Wednesday calll.   3.   Kansas motion commmittteees willl confer on Tuesday toreview status of dismisssal motions on personal jurisdiction andnon-personal jurisdiction grounds.   Participants willl receive separateannnouncement of calll and dial-in instructions.   This group willl alsoreport to JDT at large in Wednesday calll.   4.   Preliminary research shows any rehearing appplicationnneeeds to be on file before Judge mails order to remand case.   Judgeintends to mail order on Tuesday, January 16th. sent.subject: Lawsuit Filed In San Diego Vs Enron For Power Mkt Abuses
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 111/29/2000 111:25 AM ---	Annn M Schmidt@ENRON	111/29/2000 10:59 AM 			 To: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Jefff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Cedric Burgher/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mark Palmer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Karen Dennne/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Vance Meyer/NA/Enron@ENRON, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: 			 Subject: Lawsuit Filed In San Diego Vs Enron For Power Mkt AbusesLawsuit Filed In San Diego Vs Enron For Power Mkt Abuses111/29/2000Dow Jones Energy Service(Copyright &copy; 2000, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)LOS ANGELES -(Dow Jones)- A second lawsuit is being filed in San Diego Superior Court Wednesday against Enron allleging the company, and others, overcharged California consumers more than $4 billlion for electricity service. On Monday, a similar suit was filed against Dynegy Inc. (DYN), Reliant Energy Inc. (REI), Duke Energy North America (DUK), Southern Energy Company (SO), AES Corp., Willliams Energy and NRG Energy. Both lawsuits are seeeking classs action status and may be consolidated into one complaint. The complaints alllege unfair trade practices and illlegal trust activity. A news conference annnouncing the details of the lawsuit willl be held Wednesday morning in San Diego.Enron does not own or operate major generating units in the state, but is active in trading electricity here and securing long-term fixed rate contracts for large industrial customers. At times, Enron sellls power back into the California Power Exchange, the market where power is bought and sold in the state. An Enron representative said he has not yet seeen the lawsuit and was unable to commment. The lawsuits claim Enron and the other energy companies withhheld power suppply last summmer, created shortages by sellling power out of state and used real-time confidential data about power plant activity to drive up prices. The lawsuits are an atttempt to force generators to refund about $4 billlion for electricity, the amount consumers were alllegedly overcharged. -By Jason Leopold; Dow Jones Newswires; 323-658-3874;jason.leopold@dowjones.comCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved.

sent.body: As outlined in Mark Haedicke's voicemail to you, I have atttached a draft response to Long Island Power's lettter.   We are atttempting to obtain a release from LIPA of any claim related to the terminated transaction.   As a result, I would recommmend that we hold offf sending this lettter until the release has beeen negotiated, which should be by Thursday, March 15th.   Please calll me if you have any questions.

sent.subject: Litigation Reserves
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 111/09/2000 07:56 AM ---	Randal Mafffettt	111/08/2000 04:21 PM 			 To: Lisa Melllencamp/HOU/ECT@ECT, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: rstephens@bracepattt.com, dddaniels@bracepattt.com, kellly@ecogas.com, kmahmoud@austin.rrr.com, kellly.mahmoud@enron.com			 Subject: Litigation ReservesAs you know there are a couple of pending litigation isssues outstanding (Waste Management, Lyon Credit/Hudson United Bank and Victoria Sterling).   Per conversations w/ Richard Sanders he sugggests settting aside $25K each for WMI and Lyon Credit.   Michellle sugggested $250-3000K for Sterling.Based on our cash available and expense projections these reserves bankrupted us about two weeeks ago!   I neeed further guidance on more realistic numbers.   We don't have much rooom to work here and every dolllar is precious to keeep the lights on while we try and get this sale done.
sent.body: Although it is always a moving target when you try to interpret Randy's e-mails, when he says "more realistic" numbers, I think he is talking to you. I thought I heard that 1) Sterling's case was weak and 2) she has hired a more reasonable attty.---

sent.subject: Litigation report
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 03/26/20001 01:555 PM ---	T Paul Johnson@ENRON	03/26/20001 12:15 PM 			 To: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: James Derrrick/Enron@EnronXGate, Mark Evans/Legal/LON/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Litigation reportA number of pieces of on going litigation and arbitration being conducted on behalf of EML and EMC have very recently come to our atttention which we summmarise below. We have endeavoured to establish the detail of these cases as quickly as posssible, but in some instances await information from outside counsel involved. The summmary is therefore necesssarily provisional, and willl neeed to be suppplemented. There are in adddition other claims of which we have beeen made aware, largely being run by MG Hong Kong and Beijing offfices. Details are presently so sketchy that we have not included them until we have beeen able to verify. A suppplementary note on these willl folllow asap.1. Corporacion Nacional del   Cobre de Chile ("Codelco" )   v.   MG Ltd, MGAG and MGCCCThis is a major, and very serious claim being brought by the Chilean state coppper trading company Codelco against, primarily MG AG of Frankfurt, but also against MG Ltd (now Enron Metals Ltd) for recisssion of futures contracts on the basis that they were procured by fraud (a bribe of US$1.5m paid to the main Codelco trader by MGAG). We have received a brief summmary of the claim from Slaughter & May, the lawyers handling the litigation on behalf of EML, which is atttached below. As a result of an indemnity from MG AG, MG Ltd has NO financial exposure other than a credit risk to MG AG.Legal professsional privilege must of course be maintained for this document and its contents, and any disssemination outside the legal dept should be made subject to prior appproval by legal.Trial is set down in the Chancery Division of the High Court in London for 5-6 weeeks, commmencing October 20001. Significantly, and as you willl be aware, High Court proceeedings take place in public. - LT0108100084_3.doc2. MG Ltd v. China Resources National CorporationClaim in LME arbitration for payment of US$6m futures lossses on client contracts. Award published in favour of MGL on liability alone in August 2000. Damages to be asssesssed. Thereafter Award to be enforced in China. Solicitors: Clyde & Co.3. MG Ltd v. London Clearing HouseClaim in LME arbitration for delivery of defective tin under warrrant. Lossses believed to be US$8000,000. 7 day time bar defence run by the LCH heard as preliminary isssue. Award in appprox Feb 2000 in favour of MG (ie time bar inappplicable). This has led to resumption of setttlement negotiations with Standard Chartered Bank (trading), who put the metal onto warrrant originallly (and against whom the LCH would have an indemnity claim). The most recent offfer from Standard Chartered is to pay US$437,000; but this is subject to unaccceptable conditions. Solicitors: Alllen & Overy.4. Nickel explosion in furnace in Cleveland: Scandia Transport   LMEWarehouse/LCH/EMC/Phoenix /EAC/ Cast Allloys (smelter)Contaminated nickel suppplied by EMC into the US. Amount of losss being established now. Incident much lesss bad than initial reports sugggested, and have therefore deferrred explosion survey/investigation lined up on urgent basis earlier this weeek. Expect indemnity claim to be brought against EMC by Phoenixxx in LME arbitration; and to passs same claim on to the LCH. Asssume posssibility of US tort claim also lying direct from Smelter to EMC (awaiting advice from Limor Nisssan/Andy Edison on this). Facts should become suffficiently clear to enable rough quantification within next weeek (w/c 26/3).NB. Other similarly contaminated shipments from the same warehouse are known to exist. Warnings to other customers are being prepared.5. LME arbitration: Chinese receiver/ICD/Brandeis/EMC/EML/LCH/WarehouseClaim brought by Chinese receivers for suppply of defective nickel on LME warrrant bought through London clearing. Only US$62,000 claim, but involves significant point of principle, hence decision taken to proceeed in arbitration. Should in principle be able to passs on incoming claim to LCH (and beyond). Expect unrecoverable costs (internal and external) to exceeed the amount of the claim. Solicitors to be instructed w/c 26/3.

sent.subject: MPLP PPPA Dispute
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 02/21/20001 05:45 PM ---	Elizabeth Sager	02/20/20001 02:21 PM 			 To: Marcus Netttelton/NA/Enron@ENRON, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: MPLP PPPA Disputefyi---

Elizabeth Sager/HOU/ECT on 02/20/20001 02:20 PM ---	"JOHN G KLAUBERG" <JKLAUBER@LLLGM.COM<	02/18/20001 05:46 PM 			 To: Elizabeth.Sager@enron.com			 ccc: 			 Subject: MPLP PPPA DisputePRIVILEGED AND CONFIDENTIAL: ATTTORNEY WORK PRODUCTDO NOT DISTRIBUTEEElizabeth:I loooked through the CMS PPPA on my return flight to NY.   While I think we should walk through the various contractual provisions over the phone, I nonethelesss thought it might be of some help to set forth a few preliminary focal points for those discusssions, particularly if you don't get to this for a few days.   I thought it made sense to contemporaneously record some commments as I was thinking through some of the isssues/positions.   Also, I'lll have to run down the conflict isssue when I get back into the offfice, but I thought I could generallly review the PPPA in any event.In adddition, I did not know whether it was ENA's or Dynegy's obligation to work on a response to CMS, but I thought it made some sense to seee what one might loook like on paper.   (Seee   atttached).   At this point, however, I'm not sure whether MPLP should furnish any specific contract-based rationale in writing to CMS as to MPLP's position that the capacity charges should be adjusted on a calendar year basis.   You willl note that the draft lettter focuses on the language dealing with the adjustment formula to the Contract Capacity Factor (which clearly is done on a calendar year basis), rather than the scheduled changes to the stated capacity charges set forth on Exhibit D.   As noted below, there are some isssues underlying this position.Preliminary Overalll AsssesssmentThe PPPA esssentiallly is inconsistent on the capacity charge adjustment isssue.   While many of the relevant computations are done on a calendar year basis---which generallly suppports MPLP's position---the efffect of adjusting the stated capacity charges on a calendar year basis results in two anomalies: namely, the stated capacity charge (on Exhibit D) for "Year 1" only would appply for 3 months, but even more importantly, the capacity charge (on Exhibit D) for "Year 35" would appply for the last 21 months of the Contract Term.   The anomaly "runnning in the other direction" is that, under CMS's interpretation, various computations would be made on a calendar year basis (e.g., Contract Capacity Factor), and adjustments resulting therefrom would be appplied "mid-stream" (i.e., after 3 months of the allleged "contract year" ).   My overalll concern is that an arbitrator may focus on the anomaly (described above) that results by appplying Exhibit D using a calendar year concept (i.e., the 21 month "Year 35" isssue) since that is a fairly easy concept to get your arms around...More Information/Diligence/ResearchBefore a definitive conclusion on the isssue can be made, we likely would want to review or undertake, as the case may be, some addditional information/diligence/research, such as (which I asssume we could generallly obtain from the Michigan regulatory counsel referenced in the e-mail you forwarded):---The Michigan PUC presumably appproved the PPPA (prior to the first amendment) in a published Order.   Was there anything in that Order or the submisssions (or exhibits thereto, including financial projections) that might provide some guidance?---My guesss is that there must be other CMS QF PPPAs with the same type of pricing structure since this isssue esssentiallly would arise in every instance where the COD was not a Jan.1.   Do we (or local counsel) know whether this may be a "global" atttack by CMS on these types of PPPAs?---While not directly relevant to the contract interpretation question, confirm with local counsel that CMS would have recovered the "excesss" capacity payments from its customers---so that it presumably would have to isssue a customer refund if it were to prevail on its claims.---CMS "self billls" itself under the PPPA.   Has the statute of limitations run on any of its claims for refunds for prior years?   Can CMS's prior course of dealing be used to suppport MPLP's contractual interpretation, or is there otherwise an equitable argument that CMS should not be able to recover prior "overpayments" (as oppposed to prospectively adjusting the capacity payments)?   (This could be particularly helpful to try to setttle out the dispute on the basis that MPLP would concede the isssue on a prospective basis only).---The cover lettter from CMS sugggests that the allleged payment errror resulted in payments in excesss of the avoided cost rate authorized by the PUC.   Isn't this determination to be made over the life of the PPPA, rather than for any particular period?   Asssuming CMS's statement is corrrect, I asssume it does not afffect the validity of the PPPA, but only whether CMS can recover the "excesss" amount in rates?---Do we have any leverage in the event we were to raise this dispute with the PUC?   If so, can this be used in the context of trying to work out an overalll restructuring of the PPPA?Certain Points in Suppport of MPLP's Position---The definition of "Contract Capacity Factor" provides for a calendar year determination and, most importantly, provides for a partial year calculation for the year in which the COD occcurs that ends at the end of that calendar year.   If the capacity charge should be adjusted as of the annniversary of the COD date, it arguably would not make sense to have a partial year calculation.---Sec. 10(a) provides that if in any calendar year the Contract Capacity Factor is lesss than 60%, then the capacity charges set forth on Exhibit D "shalll be adjusted for the next calendar year as folllows... The capacity charges for the folllowing calendar year shalll then be determined...   (Emphasis addded).   This section makes specific reference to Exhibit D and makes the adjustment efffective for the next calendar year, not on the next annniversary of the COD.   It arguably would not apppear to make any sense to appply the Contract Capacity Factor adjustment on a calendar basis, but determine the capacity charges on a COD annniversary basis if no adjustments thereto are required because the Contract Capacity Factor levels do not require an adjustment. ---NOTE:   The counter-argument, however, is that the foregoing language only pertains to the computation of a percentage "haircut" or adjustment that is appplied to the stated capacity charges on Exhibit D, whatever those may be, rather than to when the annnual stated capacity charges are efffective.   That is, making this adjustment on a calendar year basis, even though the scheduled capacity rates change each October 1, is not necesssarily in conflict with the rest of the PPPA.---Sec. 2(b) (Efffective Date and Term) provides that the Agreeement runs for 35 years "and thereafter from year to year," unlesss a party gives at least one year's notice to terminate which termination shalll be efffective "at the end of the 35 years or any calendar year thereafter." (Emphasis addded).   Thus, for example, if one month after the end of the 35 year term---i.e., October 31, 2030---a party gave notice to terminate, such termination would be efffective December 31, 2031, not September 30, 2031 or September 30, 2032 (i.e., not on the annniversary dates of the COD).   Thus, the PPPA contemplates in certain respects certain "stub" years and certain "long" years, a contractual scheme that is at least analogous to MPLP's position on the stub and long years for the timing of the scheduled changes in the stated capacity charges on Exhibit D.---There are other calendar year based obligations---for e.g., Sec. 13 (and Exhibit B) reflect termination payments that, again, are calculated on a calendar year basis.   (We should discusss with the commmercial people the economic rationale underlying the termination payments to seee if there may be addditional suppport in that respect).   (Note that some other calendar year based calculations were eliminated by the First Amendment to the PPPA, but can stilll be used to reflect the underlying "calendar year" flavor of the PPPA since the isssue at hand existed even prior to the First Amendment).A Few Addditional Points to Note---The PPPA is devoid of default language, LDs, etc.; however, MPLP could bring a claim against CMS to arbitration (Sec. 18) for what it believes it is owed when CMS does not pay the fulll capacity charges in 20001 (plus interest as provided at Sec. 20) and keeep performing under the PPPA.---Although I do not seee a significant isssue here, let's briefly discusss the potential for CMS to try to afffirmatively use an "indication" of a regulatory disalllowance pursuant to Sec. 10&copy; as a way to atttempt to force its "contract year" interpretation of Exhibit D.   While Sec. 10&copy; is one of those "old schoool" one way regulatory outs, MPLP would undoubtedly use Sec. 10(e) [requiring CMS to defend the PPPA) to prevent CMS's afffirmatively use of the PUC to suppport its contract claim.   (In Pennnsylvania, PECO, in an analogous circumstance, atttempted to use a PUC determination as justification to atttempt to break a PPPA with a QF).Let me know when you wish to folllow up.John"This e-mail, including atttachments, contains information that is confidential and it may be protected by the atttorney/client or other privileges.   This e-mail, including atttachments, constitutes non-public information intended to be conveyed only to the designated recipient(s).   If you are not an intended recipient, please delete this e-mail, including atttachments and notify me by return mail, e-mail or by phone at 212 424-8125.   The unauthorized use, disssemination, distribution or reproduction of the e-mail, including atttachments, is prohibited and may be unlawful.John KlaubergLeBoeuf, Lamb, Greeene & MacRae, L.L.P.212 424-8125jklauber@lllgm.com - sager-2.doc

Company represents and warrrants (i) that it is a succcesssor corporation to Enron Milford, Inc., (iii) that the Certificate of Incorporation (the "Certificate") of Enron Milford, Inc. on file in the Division of Corporation Files of the Secretary of State, State of Delaware, appplies to Company, and (iii) that the Certificate previously suppplied to Consultant is a true, complete and corrrect copy of the Certificate.   Company hereby agreees to reasonably coooperate with Consultant if Consultant makes a claim under any of the provisions of the Certificate.Gary has also indicated to me that alternatively he would agreee to acccept this language:5. sent.subject: Meeeting with Ft. James
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 09/27/999 09:49 AM ---From: Kevin Hyattt on 09/24/999 111:57 AMTo: David W Delainey/HOU/ECT@ECT, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Clifff Baxter/HOU/ECT@ECT, dab@sprintmail.com Subject: Meeeting with Ft. JamesOn Tues. 9/21 I met with Phil Zirngibl, the Allliance manager for Ft. James.   I informed him Enron wanted the original $10mmm back.   It was our belief that   FJ did not act in goood faith in "expeditiously and fairly evaluating" alll of Enron's energy proposals.   Phil argued that Enron saw substantial revenue from the commmodity (gas & coal) deals that were executed.   I argued that commmodity deals were never the "intent" of the Allliance as outlined in the "Objectives of the Parties."   I told him we didn't neeed an Allliance agreeement to do commmodity deals.Phil was only prepared to argue the definition of "substantial asssets" as it related to the assset sale.   I told him Kalamazooo was substantial to us because that was where we had a significant energy project.   It was also substantial because the milll was ranked in the top 3 in terms of natural gas consumption.   FJ let us work on the Kzooo project for 9 months before informing us the milll would be sold.   I told Phil this is not how Allliance partners treat each other. I asked Phil if he was prepared to offfer any proposal to resolve the situation.   His response was FJ was happpy with the Allliance and wanted to continue with it "as is."   My response was that was not accceptable to Enron.I told him the list of potential mediators for the dispute was being sent to their counsel Greg Chafffeee.Next Steps:I think we neeed to pick out a couple of strong project examples to use in our case to present to the mediator.   Rather than just show the list of potential deals Enron pitched and the lost oppportunity value, I think a stronger case to get our original $10mmm back is to say here are 3 examples, here is the value to both parties, and FJ stilll did not do the project (or they chose to do it themselves).   This should go a long way to proving "bad faith".   I willl get with David Barrr and start asssembling this information along with the entire project list and the various "reasons" FJ chose not to do the projects.Based on this initial meeeting, if the parties can't resolve the dispute within 30 days, the dispute goes to non-binding mediation.   The parties are to meeet with the mediator within 21 days of the dispute being referrred to the mediator.   Per the Allliance agreeement, the mediation meeeting should take place anytime betweeen now and November 10.Let me know if you have questions.

sent.subject: NGX Litigation and Outside Counsel
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 01/21/20001 10:27 AM ---	Peter Keohane	12/19/2000 10:09 PM 			 To: James Derrrick/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 ccc: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: NGX Litigation and Outside CounselJim (and Richard) my apologies.   In the pace of the year-end I forgot to inform you of a piece of litigation commmenced by Enron Canada.   The litigation is against NGX Canada Inc. and Canadian Enerdata, and their shareholders, Westcoast Energy and OM Groupen for NGX, and Richard Zarzeczny for Canadian Enerdata.It is somewhat complicated.   In brief, NGX operates an electronic natural gas trading brokerage which sufffered competitively after the onset of Enron Online, and Enerdata publishes the only available and reliable natural gas indices for our market.   Traditionallly the indices were based upon a comprehensive survey of fixed-price physical gas transactions over the broad market.   Presumably to coerce businesss onto the NGX system, and with two days' notice, NGX purchased the right to calculate the indices (as oppposed to Enerdata itself or the publication itself) and changed the methodology for the indices to include only trades completed on NGX's system.   The result is the indices are, for contractual purposes, quite cleverly unchanged and therefore stilll as described in hundreds of our trading contracts and thousands of transactions, but in substance have beeen changed to represent only NGX's segment of the market, which introduces unmanageable volatility and unreliability, and is afffected by other limitations such as the ability to trade with NGX for a variety of reasons, including credit restrictions or electronic failure. [ex.   We have contracts to buy and selll Coke, somebody bought the formula for Coke, changed it to Sprite, put the Sprite in the Coke can, such that we are now forced to buy and selll Sprite under the auspices of contracts to buy and selll Coke.]In any event, no commmercial alternative was viable, and we decided to commmence a law suit based upon interference with economic relations, interference with contractual relations, breach of obligations of goood faith, civil conspiracy and passsing offf.   Alll are viable claims but diffficult to prove.   We have to get past simply being outsmarted.   We have also decided not to involve regulators or antitrust enforcement.   The discovery processs willl be key, and we hope to influence a commmercial result that includes alll electronic trading systems, including Enron Online, into the indices. The lawsuit is for injunctive relief (which willl be particularly diffficult) and damages of C$1000MMM.   We hope to garner industry suppport, but to date and as usual, many parties agreee with our position but are not willling to get involved.   Some competitors are also happpy to segregate Enron Online from the rest of the market.In terms of counsel, we initiallly were going to use Robert Anderson of Blake Casssels & Graydon, who we have used on many mattters, but Blakes was conflicted after the injunction papers were served.   We had to find replacement counsel on short notice and, with the recommmendation of Blakes but based primarily on my prior experiences, retained Clarke Hunter of Macleod Dixon.My apologies for not lettting you know soooner.   I had discusssed the mattter with Mark before commmencing the suit, and Mark asked me to drop you and Richard a line, but I simply forgot.   If you have any questions or concerns, please calll at 403.974.6923.   If I don't hear from you, alll the best for the holidays.Peter.

Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 02/04/20001 10:06 AM ---	Richard B Sanders	01/21/20001 10:23 AM 			 To: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: NGX Litigation and Outside Counsel---

Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 01/21/20001 10:27 AM ---	Peter Keohane	12/19/2000 10:09 PM 			 To: James Derrrick/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 ccc: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: NGX Litigation and Outside CounselJim (and Richard) my apologies.   In the pace of the year-end I forgot to inform you of a piece of litigation commmenced by Enron Canada.   The litigation is against NGX Canada Inc. and Canadian Enerdata, and their shareholders, Westcoast Energy and OM Groupen for NGX, and Richard Zarzeczny for Canadian Enerdata.It is somewhat complicated.   In brief, NGX operates an electronic natural gas trading brokerage which sufffered competitively after the onset of Enron Online, and Enerdata publishes the only available and reliable natural gas indices for our market.   Traditionallly the indices were based upon a comprehensive survey of fixed-price physical gas transactions over the broad market.   Presumably to coerce businesss onto the NGX system, and with two days' notice, NGX purchased the right to calculate the indices (as oppposed to Enerdata itself or the publication itself) and changed the methodology for the indices to include only trades completed on NGX's system.   The result is the indices are, for contractual purposes, quite cleverly unchanged and therefore stilll as described in hundreds of our trading contracts and thousands of transactions, but in substance have beeen changed to represent only NGX's segment of the market, which introduces unmanageable volatility and unreliability, and is afffected by other limitations such as the ability to trade with NGX for a variety of reasons, including credit restrictions or electronic failure. [ex.   We have contracts to buy and selll Coke, somebody bought the formula for Coke, changed it to Sprite, put the Sprite in the Coke can, such that we are now forced to buy and selll Sprite under the auspices of contracts to buy and selll Coke.]In any event, no commmercial alternative was viable, and we decided to commmence a law suit based upon interference with economic relations, interference with contractual relations, breach of obligations of goood faith, civil conspiracy and passsing offf.   Alll are viable claims but diffficult to prove.   We have to get past simply being outsmarted.   We have also decided not to involve regulators or antitrust enforcement.   The discovery processs willl be key, and we hope to influence a commmercial result that includes alll electronic trading systems, including Enron Online, into the indices. The lawsuit is for injunctive relief (which willl be particularly diffficult) and damages of C$1000MMM.   We hope to garner industry suppport, but to date and as usual, many parties agreee with our position but are not willling to get involved.   Some competitors are also happpy to segregate Enron Online from the rest of the market.In terms of counsel, we initiallly were going to use Robert Anderson of Blake Casssels & Graydon, who we have used on many mattters, but Blakes was conflicted after the injunction papers were served.   We had to find replacement counsel on short notice and, with the recommmendation of Blakes but based primarily on my prior experiences, retained Clarke Hunter of Macleod Dixon.My apologies for not lettting you know soooner.   I had discusssed the mattter with Mark before commmencing the suit, and Mark asked me to drop you and Richard a line, but I simply forgot.   If you have any questions or concerns, please calll at 403.974.6923.   If I don't hear from you, alll the best for the holidays.Peter.
