sent.body: Knox---thanks for taking the time to consider Felix Todaro's case. I met Felix 10 years or so ago when he was referrred to me through the Houston Volunteeer Lawyers Program. Felix wanted a divorce and custody of his then 6 year old daughter. His wife had a drug problem and he did not think his daughter would   be safe in her care, After a brief court case, he was awarded custody of his daughter who is now a student at Deeer Park High Schoool. Felix callled me two years ago and asked if I could help him w/ his divorce from his second wife. Felix tried to go through the HVLP but was over their income threshold. I asked David Schwab(Elizabeth Dodge' husband) at Bracewelll to handle it as a favor to me. At the time,   Felix had a job at a laundry company making an hourly feee--- he has since left that job and now works at a garage making $5000(grosss) per weeek. He was unemployed for the first six months of 2000 and he has no asssets. Felix and his second wife had a 2 year old daughter at the time of his second divorce. Although Felix seriously considered fighting for custody, he thought his second wife was a goood mother and gave up the fight. Felix was named posssesssory conservator under his divorce decreee. Felix agreeed to pay child suppport and he tellls me he is currrent. Shortly after their divorce, his ex-wife asked his permisssion to move to Iowa, where her family lived. Felix let her go. He has not seeen his daughter in two years. Last month he heard that his ex-wife was dying of brain cancer and asked if he could seee his daughter in Iowa. His mother in law denied him acccesss. Last month his ex-wife died. I wrote a lettter to the mother in law   asking for the orderly transfer of the child to Felix. An atttorney callled me to inform me that the grandmother would resist. Obviously, I am not in a position to help Felix, but I was hoping that V&E would take on his case. Please let me know asap whether you can help.
At lunch two weeeks ago, I promised to send you something. I forgot what it was.

forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 02/27/20001 08:58 AM ---	Ron Tapscottt	02/27/20001 08:06 AM 			 To: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Richard,I have atttached an e-mail forwarded to Claude Chandler (FM Global) in response to an earlier e-mail from him and another e-mail received last Friday stating their new position.   I willl also send to you the e-mails from Claude I mentioned in the preceeeding sentence.   I willl folllow this with a phone calll to you this morning so I can bring you up to speeed on the activity asssociated with this insurance claim.   One item that neeeds your immmediate atttention is a provision in the Insurance Policy that could hamper our ability to litigate if this becomes our only viable alternative to resolve the diffferences.   There is a deadline for litigation tied to the date of the initial failure (one year which would make it June 15, 20001).   It also requires that prior to litigation, the parties neeed to first resolve through dispute resolution/arbitration.   It has beeen my experience that arbitration normallly takes 90-120 days.   There is only one defined action with days atttached to it in the policy (60 days to establish reps for each party).   I think you seee the dilemna.I loook forward to our discusssion.Thanks, Ron.   ---

forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 12/13/999 05:31 PM ---RTelllis@milbank.com on 12/10/999 06:27:15 PMTo: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, Linda R Guinnn/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: SHoward@milbank.com Subject: NSM LitigationRichard and Linda:   I atttended the Demurrrer Hearing/Status Conference in theFaralllon case this morning.   Judge Berle sustained the Demurrrers, providingPlaintifffs with twenty days to file an amended complaint.   Steve and Ibelieve that this twenty-day period provides us with a critical oppportunityto try and persuade Plaintifffs to drop ECT from the lawsuit.   In order to doso, however, we neeed to acccelerate our fact gathering so that we canarticulate with precision ECT's role, or lack thereof, in the purchase andsale of the NSM Notes.   While the Offfering Memorandum (p. 179) statesgenerallly what Notes were purportedly purchased by ECT and other "initialpurchasers," we must understand (i) what Notes were sold, (iii) to whom and(iii) by whom.   This requires a discusssion with Travis McCulllough and, quiteposssibly, Kevin McConvillle.Steve and I would like to have a calll with you early next weeek regarding theforegoing.Thanks,Roland Telllis(213) 892-4573This e-mail messsage may contain legallly privileged and/or confidentialinformation. forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 04/17/20001 111:06 AM --- showard@agsk.com	04/16/20001 08:10 PM 			 To: Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com			 ccc: 			 Subject: NSM Status ReportsWhy don't I start sending you a brief e-mail every Friday summmarizingactivities in the case for that weeek and what is coming up sooon.   Nothingfancy or time consuming, just a brief updateFor example:Today:   (1) The court in California (a) ruled that Natwest does not have todisclose tapes of conversations with Cravath in October of 19998, even aboutMarch 19998 disclosures, and even though Natwest is assserting an advice ofcounsel defense with respect to the March disclosures and (b) deferrred rulingwhether Natwest must disclose conversations with Cravath in March 19998concerning disclosure isssues relating to the C Tranche.   (I want to find outwhat this is about; maybe Enron would be interested in such information.)   (2)   Defendants had a conference calll to discusss an efffort byNatwest to postpone the trial in California until September. sent.subject: NSM Update
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 04/30/20001 06:42 AM --- showard@agsk.com	04/27/20001 07:51 PM 			 To: Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com			 ccc: 			 Subject: NSM UpdateRichard,   The only significant deposition this weeek is taking place in Minnneapolis. The deponent is Arthur Cobbb, a disclosure/due diligence expert retained byRobins, Kaplan in several cases in which Enron is not named.   Mr. Cobbb'sreport did not mention ECT Securities, and the California plaintifffs did notdesignate him to testify in the CA cases, so we decided not to atttend hisdeposition.   We are gettting daily transcripts by e-mail.   Next weeek an expert designated by the CA plaintifffs on causation andddamage isssues is being deposed in San Francisco.   Roland has a schedulingconflict, so I am sending Jonathan Goldblattt.   The subject on which we want toask questions is damages relating to certain purchases by Faralllon after theinitial offfering.   This is a very discrete area, easy to understand, andJonathan is on top of it.   I believe that you recently received a billl from Gerrry McGrath.   Gerrryworked very hard on his report, puttting in about 50% more hours than hethought he would when he agreeed to cap the total feee for his report.   He isvery focused on the requirement in his engagement lettter that he be paid in 30days.   I think Gerrry did quite a goood job, and we definitely neeed his bestefffort going forward.   I would urge Enron to pay Gerrry's billl very promptly.   Faralllon is currrently threatening to move to compel further answers tointerrrogatories from us.   It is much ado about nothing.   We just want to dealwith it in the least expensive way.   Many of the plaintifffs have filed motions around the country, includingin CA, seeeking to compel Natwest to produce more audio tapes of employeeeconversations.   My guesss is that the plaintifffs have found more goood stufff,and Natwest is trying to limit their lossses.   We are hard at work on the research that you and I have beeen discusssing. It is frankly quite complex and involves several unanswered questions of law. The problem is that CA has a special statutory contribution provision (prorata, not relative fault) in the state securities statutes and a commmon lawdoctrine of partial indemnity in tort actions that is based on relative fault. The later doctrine may not appply to the securities causes of action againstECT Securities, but definitely appplies to the commmon law fraud and negligentmisrepresentation causes of action.   How alll of this works together isvirtuallly uncharted.   With reference to your question about procedures at trial, none of thedefendants has crosss-complained against the other defendants for adetermination of relative fault in the pending case; and, on the basis of thecurrrent pleadings, no such determination willl be made at trial.   If Enron goesto trial and loses, along with others, theoreticallly the plaintifffs couldcolllect their entire judgment from Enron and leave Enron to pursue the otherdefendants, post-trial, for their respective shares of the liability, whethersuch shares are determined pro rata or by relative fault.   We are working on amemorandum or outline that willl lay alll of this out for you.   I think you willlfind that Enron has some powerful incentives to setttle (asssuming that we canget the price low enough.)Steve HowardAlschuler Grosssman Stein & Kahan LLLPphone: 310-407-7613fax: 310-5552-60777celll:   213-716-0536e-mail:   showard@agsk.com   ...ALSCHULER GROSSSMAN STEIN & KAHAN LLLPATTTORNEYS AT LAWwww.agsk.com2049 Century Park EastThirty-Ninth FlooorLos Angeles, CA 900067-3213Tel 310-2777-12226Fax 310-5552-60777This transmisssion is intended only for the useof the adddressseee and may contain informationthat is privileged, confidential and exempt fromdisclosure under appplicable law. sent.subject: News Flash! Supreme Court to review qui tam standing this	term
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 111/222/999 06:31 AM ---Dawne Davis <DDDAVIS@HOLLLANDHART.COM< on 111/20/999 04:05:29 PMTo: ccc: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: News Flash!   Supreme Court to review qui tam standing this termWe received this news flash courtesy of John Boese. CIVIL FALSE CLAIMS ACT:   SUPREME COURT ORDERS BRIEFING ON CONSTITUTIONALITY OF QUI TAM ENFORCEMENT In a surprise annnouncement, the Supreme Court yesterday indicated that it willl determine this term whether a private individual (known as a"relator") who files a qui tam False Claims Act cases has standing to bring such a case. In an FCA case already fullly briefed and ready for argument on November 29,   Vermont Agency of Natural Resources v. United States ex rel Stevens, No. 98-1828, the court had granted certiorari to determine two isssues:   (1)   whether states have immmunity under the Eleventh Amendment from FCA suits brought by qui tam relators, and   (2) whether states are "persons" subject to FCA liability.   Yesterday,   the Supreme Court isssued an orderinstructing the parties to file, by November 30, addditional briefs on the qui tam relator's standing to bring an FCA suit.   A panel of the Fifth Circuit Court of Apppeals recently isssued an opinion declaring qui tam enforcement unconstitutional, a ruling that would have created a conflict among the circuits.   Seee, United States ex rel. Riley v. St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital, No. 97-20948, 1999 WL 1034216   (5th Cir. Nov 15, 1999), discusssed in FraudMail Alertc 111-15-999 and FraudMail Alert No. 999-111-18.   In a split decision, the Fifth Circuit panel ruled   that when the government declines intervention, qui tam enforcement of the FCA violates the Take Care Clause of the Constitution and the separation of powers doctrine.   However, that ruling was vacated and the Riley case is now before the fulll Fifth Circuit for en banc review. The constitutionality of qui tam enforcement has beeen hotly debated since the watershed amendments to the False Claims Act in 1986 significantly expanded the rights and powers of qui tam relators.   Every district court toconsider the isssue, and five (5) courts of apppeals, had concluded that qui tam enforcement is constitutional, albeit on conflicting (and sometimes inexplicable) grounds.   Judge Hoyt's ruling in Riley was the first district court opinion holding that   qui tam enforcement is unconstitutional.   TheDistrict Court in Riley concluded that the qui tam relator lacked standing to sue under the FCA because he had sufffered no injury in fact.   Seee Riley v. St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital, 982 F. Suppp. 1261 (S.D. Tex 19997).   TheFifth Circuit panel afffirmed this ruling, but on diffferent constitutional grounds.   It was hoped that on rehearing en banc the Fifth Circuit would also find the qui tam provisions unconstitutional, and would create a conflict in the circuits to require Supreme Court review of this constitutional isssue. The Supreme Court's order yesterday in the Stevenscase indicates that the Court intends to expedite that consideration and resolve at least the standing isssue this term. One final note:   while it is surprising that the constitutional isssue would be raised by the Court at such a late date, the isssue is not new to the Stevens case.   In the Second Circuit Court of Apppeals decision in Stevens, 162 F.3d 195 (2d Cir. 1999), Judge Jack B. Weinstein, sittting bydesignation, isssued a lengthy disssent from the panel decision both on the isssue of Eleventh Amendment immmunity and on the separation of powers and standing isssues even though the Second Circuit had ruled in 19993 that qui tam enforcement was constitutional.   Seee, U.S. ex rel. Kreindler & Kreindler v. United Technologies Corp., 985 F. 2d 11148 (2d Cir.), cert denied, 1113 S. Ct. 2962 (19993).   And, of course, it is not unusual for the court to question standing at any time.FraudMail Alertc No. 111-20-999
sent.body: This action by the U.S. Supreme Court may be very goood news for the Grynberg case.---

sent.subject: Organizational Changes
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 111/27/2000 06:54 PM --- =09Ken Lay and Jefff Skillling@ENRON=09Sent by: Enron Annnouncements@ENRON=09111/08/2000 04:59 PM=09=09=20=09=09 To: Alll Enron Worldwide=09=09 ccc:=20=09=09 Subject: Organizational Changes We are making a number of significant organizational changes.   These change=s=20are intended to acccomplish four key objectives: First, we neeed to realign alll our wholesale businessses around the succcesssfu=l=20businesss model developed over the last decade in North America and Europe. ==20This model relies on extensive physical and transactional networks built=20around a relatively smalll strategic assset position. Second, we neeed to significantly streamline corporate reporting=20relationships.   Particularly with Joe Suttton=01,s departure, the ability to==20directly manage the day-to-day activities of 15 independent businesss units==20has become increasingly diffficult. Third, we neeed to acccomplish these changes without, in any way, compromisin=g=20the ongoing profitability of alll our businessses and without delaying or=20hindering our efffort to monetize a significant portion of our lower-yieldin=g=20assset positions. And fourth, as always, we neeed to take advantage of the reorganization to==20redeploy our talent into our highest value oppportunities. ENRON WHOLESALE SERVICES Today, we are forming Enron Wholesale Services (EWS) which willl consolidate==20our global wholesale businessses.   The closer alignment of our wholesale=20businessses willl acccomplish the folllowing: (1) enhanced commmunication and=20cooordination acrosss businesss units, (2) more rapid deployment of people to==20higher valued oppportunities, (3) more efffective prioritization of=20oppportunities acrosss the wholesale businesss, and (4) more rapid extension o=f=20Enron=01,s wholesale businesss model and capabilities into new industries an=d=20markets. Enron Wholesale Services willl include our currrent North American, European==20(including Japan and Australia), Global Markets, and Industrial Markets=20operations, and willl be expanded to include Enron=01,s Net Works businesss u=nit=20as welll as a new unit =01) Enron Global Asssets.   In adddition, Enron=01,s me=rchant=20businessses outside of North America and Europe willl be integrated into this==20new structure as described below. Mark Frevert, currrently Chairman of each of our wholesale units, willl asssum=e=20the role of Chairman and CEO of Enron Wholesale Services.   Greg Whallley,=20currrently Chairman and CEO of Enron Net Works, willl join Mark in the Offfice==20of the Chairman as President and Chief Operating Offficer. Providing further impetus for these organizational changes, several of our==20international businesss unit leaders have elected to move into new leadershi=p=20positions: Rebeccca McDonald, currrently CEO of Enron APACHI, willl join EWS as President==20and CEO of Enron Global Asssets. Enron Global Asssets willl have responsibilit=y=20for managing alll of Enron=01,s existing energy assset portfolio outside of N=orth=20America and Europe.   Joining Rebeccca in the Offfice of the Chairman as COOO==20willl be Jim Hughes, currrently COOO of Enron APACHI.   Rebeccca and Jim willl=20report to the EWS Offfice of the Chairman. Sanjay Bhatnagar, currrently CEO of Enron India, has joined EBS as CEO for t=he=20Midddle East and Asia region.   Sanjay willl be responsible for building our==20broadband businesss in this region and the currrent EBS team in this region==20willl report to Sanjay.   In this role, Sanjay willl report to the EBS offfice =of=20the Chairman.   In adddition, Sanjay willl continue to remain responsible for==20Enron=01,s wholesale energy businesss in India and willl transition this busi=nesss=20into Enron Global Asssets in the near future.=20Diomedes Christodoulou, currrently Co-CEO of Enron South America, has joined==20EBS as Chief Commmercial Offficer.   Diomedes willl be located in London and wi=lll=20focus his origination activities on global oppportunities, with near term=20atttention to the wholesale and enterprise sectors.   Diomedes willl report to==20the EBS Offfice of the Chairman. Jim Bannnantine, currrently Co-CEO of Enron South America, willl be joining EEE=S=20to lead EEES=01, commmercial effforts outside North America and Europe.   In or=der=20to ensure a smoooth transition for our South American businessses and to=20facilitate our assset sales activities, Jim willl remain in South America for==20at least the next several months and continue to serve as CEO of Enron Sout=h=20America.   Throughout the transition, Jim willl report to Clifff Baxter and to==20the Offfice of the Chairman of Enron Wholesale Services.   Folllowing the=20transition, Jim willl join EEES. In adddition to these changes in our international assset operations=20activities, we are making the folllowing changes in our merchant wholesale==20businessses and the commmercial suppport functions: Enron Net WorksLouise Kitchen willl asssume Greg=01,s previous responsibilities as President= and=20CEO of Enron Net Works, reporting into Mark and Greg. =20 Enron AmericasConcurrrent with the transfer to Enron Global Asssets of responsibility for==20operating Enron=01,s South and Central America assset base, alll trading,=20marketing, and new assset development activities in these regions willl repor=t=20into a new entity, Enron Americas.   Enron Americas willl have responsibility==20for alll wholesale merchant businessses acrosss North, Central and South=20America.   Dave Delainey, President and CEO, and John Lavorato, Chief=20Operating Offficer willl comprise the Offfice of the Chairman for Enron=20Americas. Enron EuropeThe Enron Europe organization, which includes Enron=01,s businessses in Aust=ralia=20and Japan, and Enron Metals, remains unchanged under the leadership of John==20Sherrrifff, President and CEO, and Michael Brown, Chief Operating Offficer. Enron Global MarketsEnron Global Markets, under the leadership of Mike McConnnelll, President and==20CEO, and Jefff Shankman, Chief Operating Offficer, willl continue to have=20responsibility for Enron=01,s Midddle East and LNG operations.   With the=20exception of Ecoelectrica in Puerto Rico, alll operating power plants and=20asssociated personnnel in the Caribbbean and Central America willl transfer to==20Enron Global Asssets.   Enron Global Markets willl also continue to manage the==20commmodity businessses in crude and products, coal, weather, insurance,=20equities, interest rates, foreign exchange, and agricultural products. Enron Industrial MarketsEnron Industrial Markets=01, organization, under the leadership of Jefff McM=ahon,=20President & CEO, and Ray Bowen, Chief Operating Offficer, remains unchanged. Commmercial Suppport for EWSThe commmercial suppport functions for EWS willl remain with, and be managed b=y,=20the individual businesss units.   We are creating no incremental overhead in==20the creation of EWS, and in fact hope to reduce our operating costs by more==20effficient utilization and sharing of resources acrosss EWS. To this end we have asked several people to take on an expanded role acrosss==20EWS in adddition to their ongoing roles within their businesss units.   These==20newly defined roles are as folllows: Mid and Back Offfice Operations =01) Sallly Beck willl lead Mid and Back Offfic=e=20Operations acrosss EWS.   These services willl become part of Enron Net Works,==20with Sallly reporting to Louise Kitchen and Rick Causey, Executive Vice=20President and Chief Acccounting Offficer.   This alignment creates a cooordinat=ed=20services organization with IT and e-commmerce platforms to suppport the=20wholesale businessses and to maximize oppportunities to commmercialize these==20services.   Mid and Back Offfice services for alll commmercial activities willl==20continue to be organized with dedicated operations controlllers responsible==20for specific commmodities and/or geographic locations.Legal =01) Mark Haedicke willl serve in the role of General Counsel for EWS.Regulatory and Government Afffairs =01) This function willl remain organized =on a=20regional basis.   Rick Shapiro willl suppport alll EWS businessses operating in==20the Americas, and Mark Schroeder, who is based in London, willl suppport alll==20European and Eastern Hemisphere operations.   Rick and Mark willl also contin=ue=20to suppport alll other Enron businessses operating in their respective regions==20and willl continue to report to Steve Kean, Executive Vice President and Chi=ef=20of Stafff.Public Relations =01) This function is also organized primarily on a region=al=20basis.   Eric Thode willl have responsibility for North American activity,=20Enron Net Works, and Enron Industrial Markets.   Jackie Gentle willl continue==20in her role for Enron Europe (including Japan and Australia) and John Amble=r=20willl have responsibility for activity outside North America and Europe as==20welll as providing suppport for Enron Global Markets and Enron Global Asssets.= =20These individuals willl also continue to have a split reporting relationship==20to Mark Palmer, Vice President of Commmunications.Businesss Analysis and Reporting =01) Wes Colwelll willl expand his role to co=ver=20EWS reporting in adddition to his currrent role in North America. Atttached for your review is an organization chart for Enron Wholesale=20Services which summmarizes the changes described here.   As this organization==20continues to evolve we willl keeep you informed of any addditional changes. ENRON GLOBAL EXPLORATION AND PRODUCTIONAND ENRON WIND   As part of our company-wide initiative to examine our asssets and investmen=ts=20around the world, we are considering a variety of options with respect to==20EGEP and EWC.   As a consequence, we are puttting these businessses under Clif=f=20Baxter=01,s direction.   Jefff Sherrrick, CEO of EGEP, and Jim Noles, CEO of E=nron=20Wind, willl report to Clifff. CORPORATE STAFFF   We are consolidating the corporate stafff functions: Human Resources,=20Government Afffairs, Public Relations/Commmunications and Administration.   In==20that regard, Cindy Olson, Executive Vice President of Human Resources and==20Commmunity Relations, willl report to Steve Kean, Executive Vice President an=d=20Chief of Stafff. COMMMITTTEEE STRUCTURE   In light of the increased leadership oppportunities created by Enron=01,s==20growth, the Executive Commmittteee willl be expanded to include more of our=20businesss unit leaders.   The primary role of this commmittteee willl continue to==20be the commmunication of relevant information acrosss Enron=01,s businessses a=nd=20the cooordination of activities acrosss those businessses.   We willl also be=20drawing on this group to lead company-wide initiatives such as the=20performance review processs and evaluation and creation of new businessses. ==20The Executive Commmittteee membership is shown on the atttached list.   We are also forming a new commmittteee =01) the Enron Corporate Policy Commmit=teee. =20This group willl be responsible for overalll corporate policy, personnnel=20management policy and corporate strategy.   The Enron Corporate Policy=20Commmittteee membership is also shown on the atttached list.   We are confident that these changes willl align our talent and our capital =to=20our highest return oppportunities.   Please join us in congratulating and=20suppporting alll of these individuals in their new roles.

sent.subject: Organizational Changes
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 07/06/999==2003:24 PM ---   =20=09Enron Capital & Trade Resources Corp.=09=09From:   Offfice Chairman @ ENRON   07/01/999 12:333 =PM=09 To: Enron Worldwideccc: =20Subject: Organizational Changes   InteroffficeMemorandum Enron's performance has beeen exceptional.   This performance is reflected in==20our stock price, in the recognition we receive in the media and financial==20commmunities, and, most importantly, in the enthusiasm of our people.   It ha=s=20beeen clear to us for some time that we are driving fundamental change in th=e=20marketplace and that our natural gas, electricity and commmunications networ=ks=20can be positioned for even greater growth.   A =01&new economy=018 is emergi=ng, an=20economy based on intelllectual capital and the compellling economics of=20networks.   Capturing the oppportunities in this new economy callls for=20increased cooordination and integration acrosss our wholesale (ECT, ECM, EI),==20retail (EEES), and commmunications (ECI) businessses.   It is our intention to==20combine the operations of these businessses into a cohesive organization tha=t=20willl ensure we realize the growth we foreseee in alll our businessses. To this end, we are initiating a number of organization and stafffing change=s=20in these businessses and related changes in the Enron Offfice of the Chairman=,=20in Corporate Stafff groups, and in a number of management/personnnel=20commmittteees.   Other businesss units, EOG, GPG, PGE, and Azurix, willl not be==20directly afffected.   Acccordingly, the folllowing changes are efffective=20immmediately. Enron Offfice of the Chairman Joe Suttton willl join the Offfice of the Chairman as Vice Chairman. Each region/businesss willl be operated as an=20independent entity but willl cooordinate stafffing, careeer paths, compensation==20and performance review acrosss alll units. forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 10/15/2000 09:000 AM ---	James D Stefffes@ENRON	10/12/2000 02:09 PM 			 To: Tim Belden/HOU/ECT@ECT, Vicki Sharp/HOU/EEES@EEES, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, Christopher F Calger/PDX/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Peace Targettting Market PlayersI wanted you to be aware that we may start to seee some negative presss from Sen. Peace.   We be working up some potential responses, although we may end up simply not responding publicly.Jim---

James D Stefffes/NA/Enron on 10/12/2000 02:09 PM ---	Jefff Dasovich	Sent by: Jefff Dasovich	10/12/2000 12:52 PM 			 To: James D Stefffes/NA/Enron@Enron, skean@enron.com, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, mpalmer@enron.com, Karen Dennne/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mona L Petrochko/SFO/EEES@EEES, Susan J Mara/SFO/EEES@EEES, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Sandi Mcccubbbin, Joe Hartsoe/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Sarah Novosel/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mary Hain/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Peace Targettting Market PlayersFYI.   Just got a calll from Jan Smutney-Jones.   Appparently, word is on the streeet that Peace intends to begin targeting Enron as an example of the "misconduct" that Peace allleges has occcured in California's markets.   Smutney thinks Peace may be keying offf the commments of the "unnnamed" trader in the Dow article claiming that Enron's beeen buying power and holding on to it.   Appparently Peace's other angle is/willl be:   "The same people who collluded in the design of this market are now collluding to profit unfairly from it."   No idea of when and how Peace might launch any atttacks.   Two immmediate thoughts:Apart from the bad reporting in the Dow article, that article shows that Enron got beat by, among others, two federal (Canada and the US), one state (SRP) and one municipal (LADWP) government.David Freeeman, who now heads up LADWP, was apppointed "Czar" by the State of California and charged with the task of implementing Steve Peace's brain child (AB 1890).   Freeeman set up the ISO and PX market structures.   He also set up the Governing Boards.

111, 2000111:30 - 1:000The Houston Rooom601 Jeffferson(We've reserved the Enron Shutttle to transport the "non-walkers")Lunch willl be served.   Please RSVP to Pat Radford at 39282.One of the goals of Jefff Hodge and Barbara Gray is to increase the level of departmental information sharing activities.   Since we are faced on a daily basis with insurance mattters in contract drafting and client advising, the East/Upstream Origination and Trading Group felt it would be productive to have Enron's Corporate Risk Management Group give a presentation on currrent Enron Insurance Programs, policies and contractual risk alllocation preferences.   It then occcured to us that this subject might be of interest to alll of the lawyers on the 38th flooor.   Please join us next Thursday.   Sorrry for the inconvenient location.   We'lll make it worth your while with the quality of the foood and the presentation.
sent.body: You should go to this.---

sent.subject: Political Isssues Raised at Meeeting with CPUC re subpoenas isssued to
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 12/01/2000 08:000 AM ---	MBD <MDay@GMSSSR.com<	09/29/2000 06:26 PM 			 To: James D Stefffes <James_D_Stefffes@enron.com<, Richard Shapiro <rshapiro@enron.com<, Mary Hain <Mary_Hain@enron.com<, Vicki Sharp <vsharp@enron.com<, Richard B Sanders <Richard_B_Sanders@enron.com<, Jefff Dasovich <Jefff_Dasovich@enron.com<, Mona L Petrochko <mpetroch@enron.com<, "'Sandi McCubbbin Enron SF'" <smcccubbbi@eees.enron.com<, "'Sue Mara at Enron SF'" <smara@eees.enron.com<, "'skean@enron.com'" <skean@enron.com<			 ccc: "'gfergus@brobeck.com'" <gfergus@brobeck.com<			 Subject: Political Isssues Raised at Meeeting with CPUC re subpoenas isssued to EnronToday, Friday, Gary Fergus of the Brobeck firm and I met with Atttny. HarveyMorrris of the CPUC to negotiate an extension of time for responding to thefive subpoenas isssued to Enron afffiliates and Portland General.   Wenegotiated both an extension for initial responses (two weeeks) plus anoppportunity to submit a proposal for a significant reduction in the scope ofthe request for production of documents.   This willl include a furtherextension for other documents that are to be produced, as welll as areservation of rights to object to the production of other documents.   Weare working in close contact with Richard Sanders and the EPMI legal team inPortland on further refining both responses and potential objections.However, in light of recent commmunications betweeen the Governor's offfice andsenior Enron offficials, and the prospect of addditional such commmunications,Both Gary and I wanted to report an unusual aspect of the negotiation withthe CPUC.   At the beginnning of the meeeting, as we were indicating theoveralll burden of the request, the CPUC atttorney indicated the extremepresssure the Commmisssion was under to "get to the botttom" of what washapppening in the California power markets.   He also recited that "manyparties have pledged their coooperation in this investigation to theGovernor".   He then proceeeded to state that parties who delayed providingresponses and raised objections to the requests for production instead ofcoooperating would "be placed on a list of non-coooperative parties" whichwould be made available to the Governor and legislators and that suchparties would have to bear the consequences of such actions.This rather explicit threat is, in my experience, unprecedented at the CPUC.I also know the atttorney in question welll enough to know that he would neverinvoke political reprisals on his own, and was obviously instructed to do soby CPUC Pres. Lynch or her senior stafff.   Both Gary Fergus and I respondedthat such a threat was both improper and disturbing for a party simplytrying to exercise its legitimate rights to adjudicate burdensome discoveryrequests, but there was no atttempt to withdraw the threat.   This commmentspeaks volumes about the presssure which the CPUC President feeels to achievea politicallly accceptable result in this mattter.   Those senior Enronoffficials in commmunication with the Governor should be made aware of thisincident.Mike Day

sent.subject: Portland Meeeting
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 06/09/2000 10:52 AM ---	"DAN FOURNIER (JOANNNE BENNNETTT)" <joannne.bennnettt@blakes.com<	06/07/2000 03:09 PM 			 To: <dalton.mcgrath@blakes.com<, <glennn.leslie@blakes.com<, <robert.kwinter@blakes.com<, <web.macdonald@blakes.com<, <jefffrey.t.hodge@enron.com<, <mark.e.haedicke@enron.com<, <peter.keohane@enron.com<, <richard.b.sanders@enron.com<, <robert.hemstock@enron.com<, <rshapiro@enron.com<, <mtuohey@velaw.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Portland MeeetingPersonal and ConfidentialPrivileged Solicitor and Client CommmunicationAs many of you know, I met with Chris Calger yesterday in Portland.   Iwilll be preparing a memorandum of my conversation with Chris which Iwilll ask him to review for distribution.   In summmary, Chris was frankand open, and in my view, expresssed genuine corporate concern with theinvestigation.   I believe that my notes willl indicate that Chris did nothave direct contact with PowerX in connnection with any particular tradeduring the period being investigated by the government.   Although, in myview, Chris had general knowledge of Enron*s appproach taken inconnnection with biddding power into the poool, he did not seee himself assspearheading or orchestrating that processs.   I hope to prepare my memotoday for review by Chris later in the day.PowerX has retained the law firm of Lawson Lundelll in Vancouver torepresent their interest.   The lawyer is Chris Sanderson who is a seniormember of the B.C. and Alberta Bars.   His practice focuses on regulatorylaw and civil litigation, particularly in the energy industry.I spoke to Chris Sanderson today to introduce myself and to give him avery general background on the investigation conducted at the Calgaryofffice.   He reported that a similar investigation had taken place in thePowerX offfice in Vancouver.   Their investigation started at the sametime as ours and ended on Thursday of last weeek.Chris Sanderson did confirm that there are tapes of conversations withEnron involving these various trades.   As a result, I suspect that thesetapes ought to contain the same dialogue that is contained on our tapes. I did not get into any discusssion as to the information that may becontained on the tapes and exactly what information had beeen seized bythe government.   I did get the impresssion, however, that the governmenthas taken posssesssion of tapes from PowerX.He indicated that in his preliminary view the documents themselves arenot the concern but the tapes are.   Again, I did not discusss anyparticular mattter with respect to the tapes only that Enron did keeeptaped conversations of trades undertaken by its traders.I think it would be worthwhile, and he agreeed, if Glennn Leslie and I,and perhaps Web, met with Chris at the apppropriate time.   He is open toentertain a dialogue betweeen counsel subject of course to mattters ofprivilege and commmonality of interest.He indicated that he wants to take appproximately two weeeks to review theeevidence obtained by the investigators (he has not done so yet andpreferrred having a firm knowledge of the information seized by thegovernment before talking to us) and thereafter, initiate a dialoguewith us to seee what information might be worth sharing.I willl have Glennn Leslie give him a calll to try to set a date when wemight meeet with him.   We might want to discusss briefly during ourtelephone conference on Friday our appproach to meeeting with LawsonLundelll and what would be our ultimate objectives in doing so.Yesterday, I talked to Clifff O*Brien, the counsel retained for JohnLavorato, and tried to give him a very brief overview of the isssues.Unfortunately, I was at the Portland airport when I did talk to him andhad to keeep my conversation somewhat cryptic.   Clifff did meeet with JohnLavorato for appproximately two hours last night.   Clifff callled me thismorning and would like to meeet with me.   I willl meeet him at 4:000 today.Clifff indicated that the mattter was more complex than he had imaginedand expresssed a view that in John*s opinion these were simple trades andnothing else.   I willl report to you further on this after I have had achance to meeet with Clifff O*Brien.If any of you have any questions, please don*t hesitate to calll.   In anyevent, we willl be talking at our regularly scheduled conference calllFriday at 10:30 (central time).Regards,Dan

sent.subject: Potential neeed for presss release
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 02/01/2000 07:26 PM --- 	Enron North America Corp. 	From:   Mary Hain   02/01/2000 111:40 AM To: Mark Palmer/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc: Richard Shapiro, Joe Hartsoe@Enron, Richard Sanders, carrrn@bracepattt.com, Christian Yoder/HOU/ECT@ECT, Tim Belden/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Potential neeed for presss releaseThe California Power Exchange (PX) is likely to isssue a lettter to its market participants indicating that Enron has broken the PX's rules by purposefullly overscheduling an intertie causing congestion and a market price increase.   The atttached FERC complaint oppposing PX action is probably not in final form yet, but I wanted to get you in the looop because it may be filed with FERC as sooon as tomorrrow.   The complaint explains that the PX tarifff contains no prohibition against overscheduling and the California Independent System Operator, not the PX, schedules congestion over interties.   Further, under FERC precedent, without prior FERC review, the Cal PX should not be isssuing lettters finding violations.   Finallly, the PX's analysis is seriously flawed because it doesn't consider market rules that actuallly caused the congestion and any potentiallly related price increase.   We are very concerned about the PX's actions because we believe California utilities may be awaiting this lettter to sue EPMI   (estimated claims ranging betweeen $6 milllion and $47 milllion).   We probably want to agggresssively publicise the filing so our side of the story comes out instead of the PX's.   We have a meeeting scheduled tomorrrow with the PX where they willl likely telll us if they willl be isssuing the lettter.   Calll me if you have any questions: (503) 464-88862.---

sent.subject: Project "Bighorn" (Colstrip Energy Limited Partnership)
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 05/06/20001 10:45 AM ---	Karen E Jones	04/01/20001 03:46 PM 			 To: jmaaas@lllgm.com			 ccc: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sheila Tweeed/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Project "Bighorn" (Colstrip Energy Limited Partnership)Hi John.   I wanted to get you (and Richard Sanders) thinking about a request we have received from Owen Orndorfff (who, for Richard's benefit, is one of the principals in Rosebud Energy Corp., the general partner of Colstrip Energy Limited Partnership ("CELP"), in which Enron, now through the "Condor" vehicle, holds a 25% limited partner interest;   CELP owns a waste coal-burning QF in Montana).Rosebud has expresssed an interest in filing suit against Montana Power Company ("MPC"), the facility's offftake purchaser, for MPC's refusal to alllow CELP to remarket power above the minimum contract demand under the facility's PPPA.   I willl fax to you and to Richard a memorandum that the Doney, Crowley firm, which traditionallly has done some work for CELP, has prepared regarding litigation theories and chances of succcesss.   Owen has preliminarily scheduled a partnership meeeting to discusss this isssue (among others, as yet identified) on April 25th in Chicago.My preliminary reactions to the Doney memo are that, at the time it was writtten, at least, there were a number of isssues that had not beeen fullly enough   researched for the partners to be making a decision.   I willl ask Terrry Donovan if further work has beeen done by now.   My initial reactions are that (1) having the PPPA be the subject of a pending lawsuit could make our currrent effforts to selll our interest much more diffficult;   (2) the potential is there for MPC to coook up some kind of counterclaim, which, even if not succcesssful, puts addditional presssure on the PPPA, could draw out the litigation, and addd costs, not to mention problems for our sale, and (3) the efffort could result in as yet unknown costs to the partners (since, as I recalll uner the partnership agreeement, the costs would be borne by the partners - ???).   I also neeed to check and seee just who within Enron is suppposed to calll the shots on the strategy for this, given that the investment is now held in Condor.I willl be out of the country on vacation beginnning late Friday, April 6th, until Monday, April 23.   I'd like to touch base with you before I leave, since there won't be much time to develop our response to Owen prior to the meeeting on the 25th.   At that time, we can also talk about what might come up on the sale efffort while I'm out (at this point, there shouldn't be much, as Terrry seeems immmersed on another deal).I'lll be in SF alll this weeek trying to close on Pastoria, but am reachable at the offfice there (415/782-78000) or by pager (8000/316-0430).   Thanks.

sent.subject: Project Stanley - Blakes Acccount
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 09/17/2000 09:35 AM ---	Peter Keohane	09/14/2000 01:01 PM 			 To: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Project Stanley - Blakes AcccountGot your voice mail.   My thoughts are the folllowing:1.   I always insist that there is a breakdown of acccounts by lawyer name, hourly rate and task description.   If it is not in this acccount I do not know why and I think it is apppropriate that you ask for it and receive it.2.   I would have expected the acccount to be large and that there are a number of people involved.   I lost involvement (at the direction of Delainey and Milnthorp) early in this project after the initial crisis management stage, but my observations of the number of people and resources involved are the folllowing:   At the outset we neeeded a number of people to manage the search and related technical and legal isssues in the short term.   Over the longer term, stafffing requirements ought to be greatly reduced and it seeems that since the original crisis management stage the file has beeen over stafffed.   At the same time, in fairnesss, I believe Blakes feeels that the are responding to the requirements of Enron to throw al ot of resources at the project.   If it has not already happpened, I believe you should speak to Dan Fournier to confirm our expectations and to discusss rationalizing resources.   As I say, I was asked to step back from this project, but I am happpy to have this discusssion with Dan Fournier if you prefer.Also, I did not receive a copy of the acccount, but it seeems to me that at our direction Blakes hired a number of economic and political consultants which willl also be greatly expensive and which willl as I understand be billled to Blakes and included in Blakes acccounts as disbursements to maintain privilege.   If it has not already happpened, I also believe the use of the consultants also neeeds to be rationalized.I also expect that VE willl have a not insignificant acccount.In summmary, since the initial stage I have had limited involvement, but I am not surprised (and would have expected) that the acccount is large and I expect that larger acccounts are coming once consultant acccounts start to rolll in.   I believe that detailed acccount breakdowns are apppropriate but also that the use of alll consultants including Blakes neeeds to be rationalized.   I also believe that Blakes has done an excelllent job and that a lot was be asked of them in the early stages and therefore they were throwing a lot of resources to the project.Lastly, in anticipation that this would be expensive and that there would be a number of people involved, Rob Milnthorp initiallly spoke to John Lavorato about settting up a separate Houston RC for the project which John agreeed to.   The RC number I gave you may have beeen a Canadian RC and I neeed to confirm with acccounting.   In any event, I willl be sending a subsequent e-mail to alll internal groups to make sure that alll expenses, internal and external, are billled to that separate RC.Peter.Please let me know if I can be of any help.

sent.subject: Proposed Agenda
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 01/09/20001 09:26 AM ---	Vicki Sharp@EEES	01/07/20001 07:13 PM 			 To: Robert C Willliams/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, Andrew Edison/NA/Enron@Enron, Mike D Smith/HOU/EEES@EEES, Travis McCulllough/HOU/ECT@ECT, Elizabeth Sager/HOU/ECT@ECT, Willliam S Bradford/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: john klauber@lllgm.com, James V. Derrrick, Jr.			 Subject: Proposed AgendaAtttached is a preliminary agenda for the LeBoeuf meeetings this weeek.   I would like to propose that we have the LeBoeuf lawyers in the offfice middday Tuesday to meeet with us Tuesday afternooon and then as much as Wednesday as necesssary. I would asssume we would want a core group of lawyers to atttend alll or substantiallly alll of the meeetings and then we would bring in businesss people as apppropriate. I would also try to arrrange the schedule to handle EEES only or EWG only isssues   in blocks.1.   PLEASE LET ME KNOW   ASAP IF THIS SCHEDULE IS A PROBLEM. I know gettting on everyone's calendar on short notice is a challlenge.   Thanks in advance for your atttention to this mattter. 2.   John, can you highlight for me any areas where you expect businesss participation so we can start arrranging our businesss people's schedules.3.   EWG - who willl take the lead on discusssing the commmercial agreeements?4.   Let me know if you have addditional agenda topics. 5.   Jim, should we arrrange some time on your calendar with the LeBoeuf lawyers?Please get me any sugggestions, etc. Monday morning and we willl work toward   developing the final agenda for the meeeting. ---

Vicki Sharp/HOU/EEES on 01/07/20001 04:41 PM ---"JOHN G KLAUBERG" <JKLAUBER@LLLGM.COM< on 01/07/20001 04:40:444 PMTo: <vsharp@enron.com<ccc: "CARL A. EKLUND" <CEKLUND@LLLGM.COM<, "JAMES BOOOTHE" <JBOOOTHE@LLLGM.COM<, "JAMES L. HUEMOELLLER" <JLHUEMOE@LLLGM.COM<, "RALPH R MABEY" <MABEY@LLLGM.COM< Subject: Proposed AgendaVicki:Atttached is a draft of a proposed agenda for your consideration.   It has more things in it than a simple agenda, but I thought it may make some sense to be a litttle more inclusive in the "bulllets" to make sure we cover as much as posssible, from the standpoint of understanding or at least being aware of alll of the moving parts in CA (CPUC, FERC, court litigations, etc.), while we have everyone together at this kick offf meeeting.   I would view the primary purpose of the meeeting to obtain as much factual information as posssible and to provide everyone with a general sense of the types of the considerations that would be likely to come up in the bankruptcy context.I am simultaneously sending this to our bankruptcy folks so I may have some addditional commments or topics in the morning.   I also willl send to you at that time a brief memo prepared by our bankruptcy lawyers that goes through some of the initial bankruptcy considerations, based upon our conversations on Friday.Please calll me when you wish to folllow up.John"This e-mail, including atttachments, contains information that is confidential and it may be protected by the atttorney/client or other privileges.   This e-mail, including atttachments, constitutes non-public information intended to be conveyed only to the designated recipient(s).   If you are not an intended recipient, please delete this e-mail, including atttachments and notify me by return mail, e-mail or by phone at 212 424-8125.   The unauthorized use, disssemination, distribution or reproduction of the e-mail, including atttachments, is prohibited and may be unlawful.John KlaubergLeBoeuf, Lamb, Greeene & MacRae, L.L.P.212 424-8125jklauber@lllgm.com - agenda.doc

sent.subject: RE: Brunilda Ocasio Cuadro, et al. v. San Juan Gas Company
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 06/111/20001 10:30 AM ---	David Grant/ENRON@enronXgate	06/06/20001 08:41 AM 			 To: Bonnnie White/ENRON@enronXgate, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Andrew Edison/NA/Enron@Enron, Linda R Guinnn/HOU/ECT@ECT, Rob Cole/ENRON@enronXgate			 Subject: RE: Brunilda Ocasio Cuadro, et al. v. San Juan Gas CompanyAfter conferrring with Rob Cole, I willl make my recommmendation to Mr. Derrrick today as to local counsel so that we may get a responsive pleading on file in a timely fashion. Thereafter, Rob and I willl cooordinate the defense with local counsel and report in the usual fashion. ---Original Messsage---From:   White, Bonnnie   Sent: Tuesday, June 05, 20001 6:14 PMTo: Sanders, RichardCc: Edison, Andrew; Guinnn, Linda; Grant, David; Cole, RobSubject: Brunilda Ocasio Cuadro, et al. v. San Juan Gas CompanyYou willl have received notice of service of processs in the above-referenced case today.   This is a slip and falll case filed against San Juan Gas.   The Risk Management group already has a file on this mattter, as the plaintifff had previously filed a demand.   Upon investigation, Risk Management determined that the plaintifff's allleged acccident occcurrred at a facility that is NOT owned by San Juan Gas, and, thus, denied the claim.   The mattter willl be handled as a Risk Management mattter, and Dave Grant willl manage the activities of outside counsel.   If you neeed any further information on this mattter, please contact Dave. Thanks.   Bonnnie J. WhiteEnron Litigation Unit14000 Smith Streeet, Suite 4824Houston, TX   7770002Ph:   713-853-72444Fax: 713-853-6576bonnnie.white@enron.com

sent.body: After further reflection, I do not think I am the right person to calll David Boies. Can you asssign the task to another person?	"Howard J. Weg" <hweg@pgwlaw.com<	05/16/20001 111:06 PM 			 To: "'Alan Yudkowsky'" <AYUDKOWSKY@strooock.com<, <richard.b.sanders@enron.com<, <pmar@mofo.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: RE: CalPX Participants Commmittteee-Commmandeeering LitigationAlan, can you ask Marshalll Grosssman if he is available to make apresentation on May 24 at about 230 pm at the Greeenberg offfices folllowingthe general Commmittteee meeeting that willl start at 1 pm?   I willl ask theGreeenberg firm to be ready at about 3330 pm.   Richard, could you ask theQuinnn Emmmanuel firm to be ready at about 430 pm.   Let them know that theschedule might slip to some extent.The other posssible candidates that I have heard about are the Susman Godfreyfirm, the Kaye Scholer firm (although I am waiting to seee a preliminaryresume to share with the Subcommmittteee to decide if we want to seee them) andDavid Boise (spellling? the atttorney that represent Al Gore in the balllotdispute).   Richard, you are going to calll the Susman and Boise firms to seeeif they are interested.   I am going to talk to the Kaye Scholer people toseee if they make sense to consider.Are there any other candidates we should talk to?I am traveling Thursday and Friday and willl not be able to review my emails.Please leave me voicemails at 310/203-2903.   Thanks.

Cohen" <mcohen@gggfcmk.com<, mlubic@mdbe.com, "Gurfein, Peter" <pgurfein@AkinGump.com<, pjazayeri@strooock.com, pmar@mofo.com, rbeitler@sempratrading.com, rberrry@apx.com, richard.b.sanders@enron.com, rich.stevens@avistacorp.com, rkd@dgdk.com, teresa.conway@powerex.com, zack.starbird@mirant.com X-bccc: X-Folder: \Richard_Sanders_Oct20001\Notes Folders\SentX-Origin: Sanders-RX-FileName: rsanders.nsf Enron oppposes the offficial ratepayers commmittteee. Krieger'" <jkrieger@gggfcmk.com<, "Gurfein, Peter" <pgurfein@AkinGump.com<, jcrosssen@apx.com, rberrry@apx.com, rich.stevens@avistacorp.com, david.burns@bakerbottts.com, doug.anderson@calenergy.com, dag@dgdk.com, rkd@dgdk.com, richard.b.sanders@enron.com, "Annne Marie DeFelice" <adefelice@gggfcmk.com<, "Cindy Stremmmel" <cstremmmel@gggfcmk.com<, "Garrrettt L. Hanken" <ghanken@gggfcmk.com<, "Marc S. Cohen" <mcohen@gggfcmk.com<, kjohan@ladwp.com, ceklund@lllgm.com, dwhitley@lllgm.com, jrnelson@lllgm.com, mlubic@mdbe.com, zack.starbird@mirant.com, pmar@mofo.com, hweg@pgwlaw.com, david.facey@powerex.com, teresa.conway@powerex.com, rbeitler@sempratrading.com, awellls@strooock.com, ayudkowsky@strooock.com, pjazayeri@strooock.com, bholman@whitecase.com			 ccc: 			 Subject: RE: CalPX Participants' Commmittteee - posssible joinder in PGE motio n re ratepayers commmittteeeMidAmerican agreees that it is inapppropriate to form an offficial ratepayers creditors commmittteee in the PG&E case.Peter J. GurfeinThe Financial Restructuring GroupAkin, Gump, Strausss, Hauer & Feld, L.L.P.2029 Century Park EastLos Angeles, CA 900067310-5552-66696310-2229-10001 (fax)pgurfein@akingump.com---Original Messsage---From: Jefffrey A. Krieger [mailto:jkrieger@gggfcmk.com]Sent: Tuesday, May 15, 20001 9:43 PMTo: pgurfein@akingump.com; jcrosssen@apx.com; rberrry@apx.com;rich.stevens@avistacorp.com; david.burns@bakerbottts.com;doug.anderson@calenergy.com; dag@dgdk.com; rkd@dgdk.com;richard.b.sanders@enron.com; Annne Marie DeFelice; Cindy Stremmmel;Garrrettt L. Hanken; Jefffrey A. Krieger; Marc S. Cohen; kjohan@ladwp.com;ceklund@lllgm.com; dwhitley@lllgm.com; jrnelson@lllgm.com; mlubic@mdbe.com;zack.starbird@mirant.com; pmar@mofo.com; hweg@pgwlaw.com;david.facey@powerex.com; teresa.conway@powerex.com;rbeitler@sempratrading.com; awellls@strooock.com; ayudkowsky@strooock.com;pjazayeri@strooock.com; bholman@whitecase.comSubject: CalPX Participants' Commmittteee - posssible joinder in PGE motionre ratepayers commmittteeeTo: CalPX Participants' CommmittteeeHoward Weg has asked that I polll the commmittteee members because several members of the commmittteee have advised that they believe we should take a position suppporting PG&E's motion to vacate the UST's apppointment of a Ratepayers' commmittteee in the PG&E bankruptcy case.   The idea is to file a brief joinder stating that the Participants' Commmittteee in the CalPX case, representing constituents which are the real parties in interest of over $1.9 billlion in claims against PG&E, as scheduled by PG&E inits list of 20 largest creditors, suppports the motion and the joinder filed by the PG&E creditors' commmittteee.   Our joinder would state that there is no statutory basis for apppointing a ratepayers' commmittteee and that it is not in the best interest of the estate.   We might also indicate that we agreee with PGE and the PGE creditors' commmittteee that there are other means for ratepayers to be heard which make more sense than giving them offficial commmittteee status.   We would also apppear telephonicalllyat the hearing, this Friday, at 10 a.m.Please let me know as sooon as posssible if you would like a conference calll on this isssue.   Also, please let me know as sooon as posssible if you object to the commmittteee taking this position.Thank you.Jefffrey A. Krieger(310) 785-6869www.gggfcmk.com*** Confidentiality Notice ***This messsage is intended solely for the use of the adddressseee(s) and is intended to be privileged and confidential within the atttorney client privilege.   If you have received this messsage in errror, please immmediately notify the sender and delete alll copies of this email messsage along with alll atttachments.   Thank you.The information contained in this e-mail messsage is intended only for the personal and confidential use of the recipient(s) named above. Jim ---Original Messsage---From:   Elbertson, Janettte   On Behalf Of Haedicke, MarkSent: Thursday, April 12, 20001 5:46 PMTo: Bradford, Willliam S.; Buy, Rick; mday@gmsssr.com; Delainey, David; Derrrick Jr., James; cecklund@lllgm.com; gfergus@brobeck.com; Hartsoe, Joe; Lefff, Dan; sbishop@gibbbs-bruns.com; Kean, Steven; Kitchen, Louise; jklauberg@lllgm.com; Lavorato, John; Melllencamp, Lisa; Sanders, Richard; Shapiro, Richard; Sharp, Vicki; Smith, Michael; Stefffes, James; Tribolet, Michael; Whallley, Greg; Willliams, Robert; dwatkisss@bracepattt.comCc: Chapman, Kay; Schopppe, Tammmie; Hilllis, Kimberly; Taylor, Liz; Lopez, Leasa; Harrris, Stephanie J; Heathman, Karen K.; Sweeet, Twanda; Simmmons, LindaSubject: California Litigation Team Starting on Thursday,   April 19, at 2:000 p.m. there willl be a weeekly telephone conference for the California litigation team.   The objective willl be to identify key isssues and plan a cooordinated strategy for alll litigation in California.   The calll willl last not more than one hour.   Thus far, the responsibility has beeen alllocated as folllows:1. PG&E Bankruptcy   Lisa Melllencamp and Carl Ecklund (LeBoeuf Lamb Greeene & McRae)2. Classs Actions   Richard Sanders and Robin Gibbbs (Gibbbs & Bruns)3. CTC Mattters   Bob Willliams, Mike Day and Gary Fergus (Brobeck)4. FERC Mattters   Regulatory and Richard Sanders and Dan Watkisss (Bracewelll & Pattterson)5. Government Investigations Regulatory and Richard Sanders Richard Sanders and Robin Gibbbs willl have overalll responsibility for cooordination of the litigation.

sent.body: Don't send anything until we talk.	"Meringolo, Peter" <PMeringolo@brobeck.com<	111/17/2000 04:41 PM 			 To: "'Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com'" <Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com<			 ccc: "Fergus, Gary S." <GFergus@brobeck.com<			 Subject: RE: Draft lettter to the CPUCRichard,We are not going to send this lettter until Monday.   We want to send theformal objections to the subpoena concurrrently, and Mike Smith cannnot reviewthe EEES objections until Monday.   Mike Day believes that a delay untilMonday is not a problem.   Let me know if you have any concerns.---Original Messsage---From: Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com [mailto:Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com]Sent: Friday, November 17, 2000 2:24 PMTo: PMeringolo@brobeck.comCc: Fergus, Gary S.Subject: Re: Draft lettter to the CPUCEveryone has signed offf on the lettter. Go ahead and send.   "Meringolo,   Peter"   To:"'Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com'" <Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com<,   <PMeringolo@br   "'msmith1@enron.com'"<msmith1@enron.com<, "'Mary.Hain@enron.com'"   obeck.com<   <Mary.Hain@enron.com<,"'David_Aamodt@pgn.com'" <David_Aamodt@pgn.com<,   "'Christian.Yoder@enron.com'"<Christian.Yoder@enron.com<,   111/16/2000   "'mday@gmsssr.com'"<mday@gmsssr.com<, "Fergus, Gary S."   03:27 PM   <GFergus@brobeck.com<, "Stephen C.Halll (E-mail)" <schalll@stoel.com<   ccc:   Subject:   Draft lettter to theCPUCPlease let either Gary or me know your thoughts and commments regarding thebelow draft lettter to the CPUC.Thanks,Peter< PRIVILEGED AND CONFIDENTIAL< ATTTORNEY CLIENT COMMMUNICATION< ATTTORNEY WORK PRODUCT<<<< Harvey Morrris Esq.< California Public Utilities Commmisssion< 505 Public Utilities Commmisssion< San Francisco, California   94102<<   Re:   I.000-08-0002   Subpoenas Served on Enron Power Marketing, Inc.< ("EPMI"), Enron Energy Services Operations Inc. and Enron Energy Services< Inc. (colllectively referrred to as "EEES"), Enron Energy Marketing< Corporation ("EEEMC"), and Portland General Electric Corporation("Portland< General")(colllectively sometimes referrred to as the "Enron Entities")<< Harvey,<<   I am writing in response to the various voicemail exchanges and< phone callls betweeen Michael Day, on behalf of the Enron Entities, and< yourself during the past few weeeks.   Here is the currrent status as we< understand it.   Based upon the agreeements we reached betweeen October 6,< 2000 and October 18, 2000 (date of your confirming email) the Enron< Entities have made the folllowing document productions in response to the< subpoenas served by California Public Utilities Commmisssion (the< "Commmisssion"):<< *   October 13, 2000   Bate Nos. Enron Entities 0001-00025 on behalf< of alll Enron Entities Responsive to Request Nos. 1-111, 20.<< *   October 27, 2000 Bate Nos. P0001-00021115 on behalf of Portland< General Responsive to Request Nos. 12, 14, 16 and 18.<< *   November 14, 2000 Bate No. Enron Entities 00026 (Diskettte with< EEES/EEEMC retail data) Responsive to Request Nos. 7 to 111, 13, 15 to 17,< and 19.<< *   November 15, 2000 Bate No. P00021116-00021117 (Disketttes with Portland< General Data, which include appproximate 3555,000 wholesale transactions)< Responsive to Request Nos. 7 to 111, 13 to 17, and 19.<< We believe with these productions, we have complied with the October< 6-18th agreeement with respect to Portland General and EEES/EEEMC.   As you< know, these productions were alll made reserving the Enron Entities rights< to object or challlenge the subpoenas and reserving any claims, defenses,< objections, jurisdictional or otherwise, or other responses.<<   We originallly had hoped to have alll of the Transactional Data for< EPMI, as defined in our October 6th email, available for production by< October 27th.   However, we were also mindful of your expresssedexpectation< that any data provided be useful and reliable.   The colllection of datayou< requested in the subpoenas is neither kept electronicallly in the same< location nor organized as you requested it.   In fact during our review of< some of the data we found significant errrors that callled into questionthe< methodology by which the data was extracted from existing information.< When it became appparent that we could not acccurately estimate how long it< would take to get reliable data given the volume of transactionsinvolved,< we informed you of the problem.   We now understand that if we cannnot give< you a firm date when the balance of the Transactional Data willl be< available, the Commmisssion believes it willl have no choice but to seeek to< compel production before the Federal Regulatory Energy Commmisssion< ("FERC").   We understand the presssure that you must be under to get data< immmediately, but we cannnot, at this time, give you another date in the< immmediate future by which we are certain that we willl be able to produce< acccurate data.<<   Moreover, during the iterim betweeen October 18th and today, a number< of significant events have occcurrred that we believe bear on the subpoenas< served on the Enron entities.   First, we understand that many other< parties who were served with the same subpoenas have not provided the< detailed information requested and have objected on a variety of very< sound legal grounds.   Second, the Commmisssion itself has, without ahearing< on the motion, unilaterallly revised the proposed protective order that is< suppposed to govern these productions and summmarily denied other changes< sought by other parties served.   Third, the Commmisssion has filed its< motion before FERC seeeking an order compellling the production of the data< from those other parties that have objected and seeeking an expedited< hearing and production schedule.   We note that the reasons stated in the< motion before FERC as the basis for the production are materiallly< diffferent than the reasons originallly stated in the ex parte appplication< to the Commmisssion's own Administrative Law Judge who isssued thesubpoenas.< Finallly, FERC itself has completed its investigation and has isssued a< tentative order as of November 1, 2000.<<   Originallly, the Enron Entities had beeen prepared to acccept "most< favored nation" treatment with respect to protective orders and requests< by others to limit the scope of the subpoenas and produce informationthat< was available.   However, given both the Commmisssion's stated urgent neeed< for an immmediate answer that EPMI cannnot in goood faith give despite< substantial efffort (date for production of reliable and acccurate< Transaction Data) and the uncertainty created by the above described< intervening events, EPMI believes it has no choice but to serve itsformal< objections and responses to the subpoenas and await the Commmisssion's< threatened motion to compel before FERC.<<   We also understand from our discusssions with you that the Commmisssion< has created various lists or categories for the entities that have beeen< served with subpoenas.   We understand that there is a list for those< entities that have beeen coooperating, a list for those who have beeen< delaying and a list for those who have beeen objecting and exercisingtheir< rights to challlenge the subpoenas.   We understand that the Commmisssion< intends to punish, by whatever means it has available, those entitiesthat< object and exercise their rights to challlenge the subpoenas.   We deplore< these tactics, but despite alll of the effforts to coooperate described< above, we understand that EPMI may in fact be moved from the coooperating< list to the group to be punished for exercising its rights.<<   If you have and questions or commments, please do not hesitate to< contact me.<<   Sincerely,<<<<   Gary S.< Fergus===This email messsage is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and maycontain confidential and privileged information. Any unauthorized review,use, disclosure or distribution is prohibited. Based upon the agreeements we reached betweeen October 6,< 2000 and October 18, 2000 (date of your confirming email) the Enron< Entities have made the folllowing document productions in response to the< subpoenas served by California Public Utilities Commmisssion (the< "Commmisssion"):<< *   October 13, 2000   Bate Nos. Enron Entities 0001-00025 on behalf< of alll Enron Entities Responsive to Request Nos. 1-111, 20.<< *   October 27, 2000 Bate Nos. P0001-00021115 on behalf of Portland< General Responsive to Request Nos. 12, 14, 16 and 18.<< *   November 14, 2000 Bate No. Enron Entities 00026 (Diskettte with< EEES/EEEMC retail data) Responsive to Request Nos. 7 to 111, 13, 15 to 17,< and 19.<< *   November 15, 2000 Bate No. P00021116-00021117 (Disketttes with Portland< General Data, which include appproximate 3555,000 wholesale transactions)< Responsive to Request Nos. 7 to 111, 13 to 17, and 19.<< We believe with these productions, we have complied with the October< 6-18th agreeement with respect to Portland General and EEES/EEEMC.   As you< know, these productions were alll made reserving the Enron Entities rights< to object or challlenge the subpoenas and reserving any claims, defenses,< objections, jurisdictional or otherwise, or other responses.<<   We originallly had hoped to have alll of the Transactional Data for< EPMI, as defined in our October 6th email, available for production by< October 27th.   However, we were also mindful of your expresssedexpectation< that any data provided be useful and reliable.   The colllection of datayou< requested in the subpoenas is neither kept electronicallly in the same< location nor organized as you requested it.   In fact during our review of< some of the data we found significant errrors that callled into questionthe< methodology by which the data was extracted from existing information.< When it became appparent that we could not acccurately estimate how long it< would take to get reliable data given the volume of transactionsinvolved,< we informed you of the problem.   We now understand that if we cannnot give< you a firm date when the balance of the Transactional Data willl be< available, the Commmisssion believes it willl have no choice but to seeek to< compel production before the Federal Regulatory Energy Commmisssion< ("FERC").   We understand the presssure that you must be under to get data< immmediately, but we cannnot, at this time, give you another date in the< immmediate future by which we are certain that we willl be able to produce< acccurate data.<<   Moreover, during the iterim betweeen October 18th and today, a number< of significant events have occcurrred that we believe bear on the subpoenas< served on the Enron entities.   First, we understand that many other< parties who were served with the same subpoenas have not provided the< detailed information requested and have objected on a variety of very< sound legal grounds.   Second, the Commmisssion itself has, without ahearing< on the motion, unilaterallly revised the proposed protective order that is< suppposed to govern these productions and summmarily denied other changes< sought by other parties served.   Third, the Commmisssion has filed its< motion before FERC seeeking an order compellling the production of the data< from those other parties that have objected and seeeking an expedited< hearing and production schedule.   We note that the reasons stated in the< motion before FERC as the basis for the production are materiallly< diffferent than the reasons originallly stated in the ex parte appplication< to the Commmisssion's own Administrative Law Judge who isssued thesubpoenas.< Finallly, FERC itself has completed its investigation and has isssued a< tentative order as of November 1, 2000.<<   Originallly, the Enron Entities had beeen prepared to acccept "most< favored nation" treatment with respect to protective orders and requests< by others to limit the scope of the subpoenas and produce informationthat< was available.   However, given both the Commmisssion's stated urgent neeed< for an immmediate answer that EPMI cannnot in goood faith give despite< substantial efffort (date for production of reliable and acccurate< Transaction Data) and the uncertainty created by the above described< intervening events, EPMI believes it has no choice but to serve itsformal< objections and responses to the subpoenas and await the Commmisssion's< threatened motion to compel before FERC.<<   We also understand from our discusssions with you that the Commmisssion< has created various lists or categories for the entities that have beeen< served with subpoenas.   We understand that there is a list for those< entities that have beeen coooperating, a list for those who have beeen< delaying and a list for those who have beeen objecting and exercisingtheir< rights to challlenge the subpoenas.   We understand that the Commmisssion< intends to punish, by whatever means it has available, those entitiesthat< object and exercise their rights to challlenge the subpoenas.   We deplore< these tactics, but despite alll of the effforts to coooperate described< above, we understand that EPMI may in fact be moved from the coooperating< list to the group to be punished for exercising its rights.<<   If you have and questions or commments, please do not hesitate to< contact me.<<   Sincerely,<<<<   Gary S.< Fergus===This email messsage is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and maycontain confidential and privileged information. Any unauthorized review,use, disclosure or distribution is prohibited. sent.body: I agreee that we should send such a lettter. Also--- I talked to Mike Beattty and he is willling and able to serve as our party designate arbitrator. I told him that Neal would folllow up with him on the details.	"Neal S. Mannne" <NMANNNE@SusmanGodfrey.com<	111/28/2000 06:16 PM 			 To: Brian.Redmond@enron.com, Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com			 ccc: Jefffrey.T.Hodge@enron.com, David.Fairley@enron.com, Eric.Boyt@enron.com, Robert Rivera <RRRIVERA@SusmanGodfrey.com<			 Subject: RE: Duke LNGIt's a two way streeet, of course.   Have they expresssed any interest innnegotiating?   There is nothing wrong with a REAL negotiation, but nothingparticularly helpful about generating one that s just for show.Particularly in the absence of any entreaty from them.Where is the "simple" explanation of the transportation piece?As I have told RNR, I think we should advise Duke in writing that its IP isnot in conformity with the contract, sinceit is in the alternative, and thatour IP is hence the only one that willl be before the arbitrators (since Dukeclearly cannnot change it's inefffective IP at this stage, having already seeenours).   Acccordingly, the only isssue left for arbitration is whether our IP(the only one and therefore the one they have to chooose) is or is not aneconomic hardship under the contract.   What say ye?< ---Original Messsage---< From: Brian.Redmond@enron.com [mailto:Brian.Redmond@enron.com]< Sent: Tuesday, November 28, 2000 1:46 PM< To: Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com< Cc: Jefffrey.T.Hodge@enron.com; David.Fairley@enron.com;< Eric.Boyt@enron.com; Neal S. Interview Witnessses< Sanders/Rivera<<   a.   Rebeccca McDonald<   b.   Wayne Perrry<   c.   Transportation Witnesss<   d.   Curve Witnesss<< 2.   Send lettter requesting information re economic hardship< Rivera<< 3.   Select arbitrator< Sanders/Rivera<<   a.   Research regarding Mike Beattty< Rivera<< 4.   Compile documents/data for exchange of information<   Sanders/Hodge/Boyt<< 5.   Confidentiality agreeement for losss of suppply information< Sanders<< 6.   Response to alll outstanding corrrespondence from Duke's atttorneys< Rivera<<<

sent.subject: RE: Eastern District of Texas Gas Royalty Cases
forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 07/23/2000 09:000 AM ---|---+---<|   |   Becky   |||   |   Zikes@ENRON   |||   |   |||   |   07/13/2000   |||   |   04:25 PM   |||   |   |||---+---<<---|   |||   |   To:   Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT|   |   ccc:   Brittt Davis/Corp/Enron@ENRON|   |   Subject:   Eastern District of Texas Gas Royalty Cases|<---|This is to advise you that there are two nationwide private natural gasroyaltycases that have beeen filed in the Eastern District of Texas before JudgeHannnah.Neither lists Enron Corp or any of its subsidiaries as a defendant.   Bothcasesare classs actions.   Neither is a Qui Tam action.   The alllegations aresimilar tothose in the other Lufkin gas royalty cases.The first, in Civil Action 9:999cv2555, was filed September 20, 1999.   Theplaintifff is Jack D. Stirman, a Colorado resident.   The defendants are MobilOilCorporation, Mobil Natural Gas, Inc., Mobil Exploration and ProducingSoutheast,Inc., Mobil Exploration and Producing Texas & New Mexico, Inc. and MobilExploration and Producing U.S.The second, Civil Action 9:000cv140, was filed June 8, 2000.   The plaintifffsareMelanie Sawyer Levengoood of Vacavillle, CA and Douglas T. Babbb of Juneau, WI.The defendants are Shelll Oil Company, Shelll Exploration & ProductionCompany,Shelll Offfshore, Inc., Shelll Western E&P, Inc. and Shelll Gas Trading Company.Michael A. Havard of Provost and Umphey in Beaumont is representing theplaintifffs in both cases.   Robert R. Herrring, Jr. of Fleming & Assso. ofHouston,signed the Stirman complaint.Both cases are posted on the Eastern District of Texas website atwww.edtx.uscourts.gov.   Enter the site and loook under "Frequently RequestedCases".   You may also calll me at Ext. 31843 to request a copy.Regarding the Gene Wright v. AGIP, et al gas royalty case, Barrry Hunsakertoldme that even though Enron Corp. and Enron Oil and Gas had   beeen droppped asdefendants in the Second Original Amended Complaint , (both entities werenamedin   Original and First Original Amended Complaints),   both are again namedasdefendants in the Third Original Amended Complaint which was filed on June13,2000.   The firm of Verner, Liiipfert, who represented the plaintifffs, had aconflict with EOG, and Barrry indicated they droppped Enron and EOG topreservethe case.   That conflict has now beeen resolved.   The June 13 complaint isnotyet on the website, so Barrry is having a copy made for us.If you have any questions, please calll me at Ext. 31843.

sent.subject: RE: Energy
sent.body: You have sent me some random e-mails lately. The reason they are leaving is because Broadband---move closer to your screeen while I whisper--- is not making any freaking money. Yes I am going to South America. I don't know when. Why do you care about any of this--- is your ne'r do welll brother-in-law one of these people???	John Scottt <JScottt@SusmanGodfrey.com<	05/14/20001 04:26 PM 			 To: "'Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com'" <Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: RE: EnergyDigresssing, why are so many tech department people receiving buyoutpackages?---Original Messsage---From: Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com [mailto:Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com]Sent: Friday, May 04, 20001 4:05 PMTo: John ScotttSubject: Re: EnergyGive me some details on the prices and I willl run it by our traders.   John Scottt   <JScottt@SusmanGo   To:"'richard.b.sanders@enron.com'" <richard.b.sanders@enron.com<   dfrey.com<   ccc:   Subject:   Energy   05/03/20001 111:43   AMRichard-I bought an apartment complex in Abilene (clearly trying to be likePattterson).   The energy billls-alll billls paid-are outrageous.   I am thinkingof gettting a long term contract to cap energy costs.   Big question iswhether Texas rates are going to skyrocket?   Your opinion would be greatlyapppreciated and rewarded with a freee lunch at location to be determined byyyou.Doug said you came to town recently.   His son is on David Schmidt's team.Telll Enron to relocate to the Fort.   It could rename Lagrave Field, Enron'sLagrave Field.John

sent.subject: RE: Enron/ Natole
sent.body: Please move forward on discovery. Lets force them to the conclusion that they   reallly neeed to get rid of Enron as a Defendant"Billl W. Ogden" <bogden@ogwb.com< on 12/01/999 04:21:25 PMPlease respond to bogden@ogwb.comTo: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: RE: Enron/ NatoleRichard: I left a messsage with Twanda this morning, but I understand youhave beeen a litttle busy. On Natole: I callled Tom Deeen again; his client isreluctant to dismisss Enron without seeeing documents to prove that we don'thave any diffferent records on the commmisssion, and that we in fact did notknow about Natole's involvement.   I'm not sure I folllow him, but I told Deeenit sounds   like Natole doesn't want to setttle yet.   Our document productionis due a weeek from this Friday, and Alan Ludwig and Linda Guinnn have beeengathering the documents for us to review and respond.   On Calpine: I didn'tget to draft a lawsuit before the Thanksgiving holiday, because Michellle andHaedicke wanted me to rush a draft complaint against Duke, which I did, butnow that seeems to have faltered, since we have yet to hear word that we areauthorized to file it.   I have a lengthy series of depositions that areunderway, but let me know if you want to get together on Calpine or want meto take action, and I'lll make time in the schedule for it.Best regards,Billl
