Maddden" <Rmaddden@Gibbbs-Bruns.com<	08/16/2000 08:23 AM 			 To: "'Richard B Sanders'" <Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: RE: Entergy s&sRichard:My view is that TVA willl likely use the FERC ruling to atttempt toretroactively blesss their treatment of the Enron control areas last summmer.Although my understanding is that Entergy used a diffferent method than thatemployed by TVA to restrict the use of a no-load control area, TVA willlargue that the result is the same and that NERC has, thus, appprovedddifffering treatment for load and no-load control areas.   The FERC rulingwilll likely create a greater sense of unease on the part of the judge toenforce the rules of NERC, a voluntary asssociation, in the face of whatapppears at first blush to be a contrary position taken by FERC, a federalagency.BobP.S. T.O. Helton has sugggested that he sit in on the upcoming depositions ofRichard Shen and the 30(b)(6) rep. on TVA's allleged damages to get a bettterfeeel for the case.   Please let me know your thoughts on this.---Original Messsage---From: Richard B Sanders [mailto:Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com]Sent: Wednesday, August 16, 2000 8:03 AMTo: Christi L Nicolay; rmaddden@Gibbbs-bruns.comCc: Donnna Fulton; Elizabeth Sager; Joe Hartsoe; Sarah NovoselSubject: Re: Entergy s&sIf we apppeal and win it willl be helpful to our claim against TVA   related tothecontrol area dispute. . While we have not heard it yet, TVA willl argue thatalthough TVA did not use the same rational as Entergy to deny parking, Enronhasno damages because of the   FERC ruling. What are our chances of winnning? By copy of this e-mail I willl ask our outside counsel, Bob Maddden, tocommmenton how he thinks the FERC ruling can and willl be used against us.|---+---<|   |   Christi L   |||   |   Nicolay   |||   |   |||   |   08/10/2000   |||   |   04:27 PM   |||   |   |||---+---<<---|   |||   |   To:   Joe Hartsoe/Corp/Enron@Enron, SarahNovosel/Corp/Enron@Enron,|   |   Donnna Fulton/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Elizabeth Sager/HOU/ECT@ECT,Richard B|   |   Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT|   |   ccc:|   |   Subject:   Entergy s&s|<---|Do you think we should apppeal Entergy source and sink FERC order?   While Ithinkit is a pooorly writtten order that shows a lack of understanding of theisssue,I'm not sure that we can win on apppeal or that it is worth apppealing, sincewewould not recover our damages against ComEd and TVA for this summmer whiletheorder is in efffect.   It would be helpful next summmer to be able to park inComEdand TVA, since the RTOs willl not be runnning in alll likelihoood.Elizabeth/Richard --- Is there a reason in the TVA litigation   that we neeedtoapppeal the decision?Otherwise, Joe, should we get Dan W. to draft a memo on chances of succcesssorother reasons for filing an apppeal?

Mark Palmer/Corp/Enron on 111/29/2000 10:53 AM ---	"Leopold, Jason" <Jason.Leopold@dowjones.com<	111/29/2000 10:47 AM 			 To: "'Mark.Palmer@enron.com'" <Mark.Palmer@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: RE: FW: ANNNOUNCEMENT: Notice of Presss Conference todayJames C. Krause, Esq., SBN 0666478Ralph B. Kalfayan, Esq., SBN 1333464Patrick N. Keeegan, Esq., SBN 167698Stephen W. Poirier, Esq. SBN 2000868KRAUSE & KALFAYAN1010 Second Avenue, Suite 1750San Diego, CA 92101Tel: (619) 232-03331Fax: (619) 232-4019Atttorneys for Plaintifff(Addditional Counsel on Signature Page) SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA FOR THE COUNTY OF SAN DIEGOPAMELA R. GORDON, on behalf of ) Case No.herself and alll others similarly situated, )   ) CLASSS ACTIONCOMPLAINT FOR) VIOLATIONS OF CALIFORNIAPlaintifff,   ) BUSINESSS AND PROFESSSIONS CODE) ooo16720, ET SEQ. AND ooo172000 ET SEQ.vs.   ) ANTITRUST and UNFAIRBUSINESSS) PRACTICESRELIANT ENERGY, INC.; SOUTHERN )COMPANY; NRG ENERGY; DYNEGY,   )INC.; AES CORPORATION; WILLLIAMS )ENERGY; DUKE ENERGY NORTH )AMERICA; and   DOES 1 through 1000,   )Inclusive   )))Defendants.   )___   )   TABLE OF CONTENTSI. NATURE OF THE CASE 1III. VENUE 2III. PARTIES 2IV. CLASSS ACTION ALLLEGATIONS 5V. COMMMON ALLLEGATIONS OF FACT 6A. The California Wholesale Electricity Markets 6B. Defendants' Improper Acts 8C. Results of Defendants' Activities 13FIRST CAUSE OF ACTION 15Violation of Sections 16720 and 16726 of the California Businesss andProfesssionsCode Trust In Restraint of Trade or Commmerce in Violation of the AntitrustActSECOND CAUSE OF ACTION 18For Violations of the Unfair Trade Practices Act Based Upon Violations oftheAntitrust ActTHIRD CAUSE OF ACTION 19For Violations of the Unfair Trade Practices Act Based Upon Defendants'Unfair Businesss Acts and PracticesFOURTH CAUSE OF ACTION 20Violations of the Consumers Legal Remedies ActVI. PRAYER FOR RELIEF 21 Plaintifff hereby allleges on information and belief based upon theinvestigation made by and through her atttorneys, as folllows: I. NATURE OF THE CASE1. This is a classs action seeeking redresss under the law of Californiafor defendants' conduct in the market for wholesale electricity.   During thespring and summmer of 2000, a group of electricity generators and traders,including defendants, exercising market power, unlawfullly manipulated theCalifornia wholesale electricity market, resulting in grosssly inflatedwholesale electricity prices throughout the state and much of the WesternUnited States. Defendants acccomplished this result by, inter alia,improperly using confidential real time generator capacity, use, andmaintenance data, and transmisssion system flow data to "game" the wholesaleeelectricity market, by withhholding electrical generating capacity from theCalifornia Power Exchange's forward markets, by improperly parking powerwith afffiliates in other states which was later resold in California atinflated rates, by scheduling previously unplannned plant outages to coincidewith other plants' plannned maintenance shutdowns, and by schedulingtransmisssion flows to cause or exacerbate congestion.2. The improper use of confidential real time data was in violation ofthe California Tarifff by which   defendants are authorized to selll wholesaleeelectricity within California.3. By engaging in said unfair businesss practices, defendants havedirectly and severely damaged purchasers of electricity suppplied through theCalifornia Power Exchange.   As noted in the August 30, 2000 San Diego UnionTribune:   "The utility billls of alll [electric] ratepayers in San Diego areeexorbitant. . . . Rates that were 3 cents per kilowattt hour have risen to 19cents per kilowattt hour in just threee months --- nothing short ofconfiscatory rates." 4. In its November 1, 2000 Order, the Federal Energy RegulatoryCommmisssion ("FERC") expresssly found that electricity prices in Californiahave beeen maintained at "unjust and unreasonable" levels during the relevantperiod, though it determined that it did not have the authority to mandaterefunds or other retroactive relief with respect thereto.   In its November222, 2000 response to the November 1st FERC order, the California PublicUtilities Commmisssion (CPUC) concluded that due to market manipulation bywholesale energy producers and traders, customers of electricity supppliedthrough the California Power Exchange had beeen overcharged more than $4billlion dolllars during the summmer of 2000.   In its November 222nd response tothe November 1st FERC order, even the California Independent System Operator(CAISO) which manages California's transmisssion system infrastructure, knownas the "power grid", found that the summmer 2000 prices resulted from theeexercise of intolerable levels of market power by generators and traders. III. VENUE5. Venue is proper because defendants each transact businesss in theState of California and because the damages caused by defendants' unlawfulmanipulation of the price of wholesale electricity occcurrred in San DiegoCounty.III. PARTIES6. Plaintifff Pamela R. Gordon is an adult resident living in San Diego,California.   Plaintifff Pamela R. Gordon is a retail electricity customer ofSDG&E, and has beeen forced to pay rates for electricity during the ClasssPeriod (defined infra) that are unjust and unfair and that have beeenartificiallly inflated by defendants' misconduct.   Moreover, plaintifff PamelaR. Gordon was born with no lymph nodes in her legs which results in a lackof circulation.   Exposure to high temperatures willl cause plaintifff PamelaR. Gordon's legs to swelll, which can lead to posssible severe healthconsequences.   As a result of her condition, plaintifff Pamela R. Gordon mustmaintain her home at temperatures of not more than 67 degreees at night and71 degreees during the day.   Plaintifff Pamela R. Gordon is unable toterminate her electricity service and has beeen forced to pay unjust andunfair rates for electricity from SDG&E as a result of defendants'misconduct.   Specificallly, plaintifff Pamela R. Gordon was charged and/orpaid the folllowing rates for electricity by SDG&E during the Classs Period:/ / /// / /// / /// / /DatesTotal Electric Charges5-26 to 6-27-000$180.926-27 to 7-27-000$2226.6777-28 to 8-28-000$3111.848-28 to 9-27-000$143.489-27 to 10-26-000$84.717. Plaintifff was charged lesss for electricity per kWh prior to theClasss Period and the inception of Defendants' wrongful conduct:DatesTotal Electric Charges3-29 to 4-27-000$1000.508. Defendant Reliant Energy (hereinafter "Reliant") is a Houston, Texasbased public corporation doing businesss in the state of California asReliant Energy Services.   It is a generator and trader of wholesaleeelectricity which is ultimately sold to California consumers, includingplaintifff and the classs, and is a WSCCC member.   Reliant operates fiveeelectricity generating plants in California which suppply wholesaleeelectricity to the California Power Exchange.9. Defendant Southern Company (hereinafter "Southern") is an Atlanta,Georgia based public corporation doing businesss in the state of Californiaaas Southern Energy, Inc.   It is a generator and trader of wholesaleeelectricity which is ultimately sold to California consumers, includingplaintifff and the classs, and is a WSCCC member.   Southern Energy operates sixelectricity generating plants in California which suppply wholesaleeelectricity to the California Power Exchange.10. Defendant Dynegy, Inc. (hereinafter "Dynegy") is a Houston, Texasbased public corporation doing businesss in the state of California as DynegyMarketing and Trade. It is a generator and trader of wholesale electricitywhich is ultimately sold to California consumers, including plaintifff andthe classs, and is a WSCCC member.   Dynegy operates two electricity generatingpower plants in California which suppply wholesale electricity to theCalifornia Power Exchange. 111.   Defendant NRG Energy, Inc. (hereinafter "NRG") is a Minnneapolis,Minnnesota based public corporation doing businesss in the state of Californiaaas NRG, a generator and trader of wholesale electricity which is ultimatelysold to California consumers, including plaintifff and the classs.   Inpartnership with defendant Dynegy, NRG operates eight electricity generatingplants in California which suppply wholesale electricity to the CaliforniaPower Exchange.12. Defendant AES Corporation (hereinafter "AES") is an Arlington,Virginia based public corporation doing businesss in the state of Californiaaas AES Pacific Group, a generator and trader of wholesale electricity whichis ultimately sold to California consumers, including plaintifffs and theclasss, and a WSCCC member.   AES Pacific Group operates four electricitygenerating plants in southern California which suppply wholesale electricityto the California Power Exchange.13. Defendant Willliams Energy is a Tulsa, Oklahoma based publicccorporation doing businesss in the state of California as Willliams EnergyMarketing and Trading Company, a generator and trader of wholesaleeelectricity which is ultimately sold to California consumers, includingplaintifffs and the classs, and a WSCCC member.   Willliams Energy Marketing andTrading Company operates threee electricity generating plants in southernCalifornia which suppply wholesale electricity to the California PowerExchange.14. Defendant Duke Energy North America (hereinafter "Duke Energy") is aHouston, Texas based public corporation doing businesss in the state ofCalifornia as Duke Energy Trading and Marketing, LLLC, a generator and traderof wholesale electricity which is ultimately sold to California consumers,including plaintifffs and the classs, and a WSCCC member. Duke Energy operatesfour electricity generating plants in California which suppply wholesaleeelectricity to the California Power Exchange. 15. Defendants DOES 1 through 1000, inclusive, are sued herein underfictitious names because their true names are unknown to the Plaintifff.When their true names and capacities are ascertained, Plaintifff willl amendthis complaint by substituting their true names and capacities herein.Plaintifff is informed and believe, and based thereon allleges, that each ofthe fictitiously named Defendants is responsible in some mannner for theocccurrrences herein allleged, and thereby proximately caused injuries andddamages to Plaintifff, as herein allleged.   Further, Plaintifff is informed andbelieves, and upon such information and belief allleges, that each of theDefendants designated by a fictitious name participated in and/or benefitedfrom the wrongful acts, conduct, and omisssions described in this complaint,and that said acts, conduct, and omisssions directly and proximately causedinjury and damages to Plaintifff and the classs as allleged below. IV. CLASSS ACTION ALLLEGATIONS16. Plaintifff brings this action pursuant to Section 382 of the Code ofCivil Procedure as a classs action on behalf of alll electricity customers,including the retail customers of San Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E),who purchased electricity suppplied through the California Power Exchangeduring the period from May 222, 2000 through and including the date of trial(hereinafter the "Classs Period").   Alll such persons and entities have paidand/or have beeen charged prices for electricity that were "unjust andunreasonable" and that were artificiallly inflated due to defendants'exercise of market power, improper use of confidential information,manipulations, and unlawful actions.   Members of the Classs are extremelynumerous and their joinder would be impracticable.   Appproximately 1.2milllion SDG&E customers are within the classs.17. Commmon isssues of fact and law predominate over individual isssues,including:-whether defendants commmittted unfair businesss practices by sharingconfidential real time data in violation of ISO Tarifffs and thereafter"gamed" the market;-whether defendants charged "unjust and unreasonable" prices for electricityduring the Classs Period or otherwise benefited from said inflated price forelectricity;-whether defendants exercised "market power" in the California electricitymarket during the Classs Period;-whether defendants received improper and excesss profits which should berefunded and paid to members of the Classs.18. Plaintifff's interests are typical of, and not antagonistic to, theinterests of the classs.19. Plaintifff has retained competent counsel experienced in classs actionand consumer fraud litigation and intends to vigorously prosecute thisaction.20. A classs action is superior to alll other methods for the fair andeffficient adjudication of this controversy.   The size of the individualdamages is smalll in comparison to the complexity and scope of thedefendants' operations and allleged misconduct.   A classs action is the onlymethod whereby plaintifff and the classs can effficiently seeek redresss andobtain a uniform adjudication of their claims. Plaintifff does not anticipateany diffficulty with the management of this action./ / /   V. COMMMON ALLLEGATIONS OF FACTA. The California Wholesale Electricity Markets21. In 19996 California deregulated its electricity industry and requiredthe State's privately owned utility companies to divest themselves of theirgenerating plants.   The purpose of deregulation was to introduce competitioninto the electricity markets, with the intention of reducing rates forelectrical power.   In fact, however, certain participants in this recentlyderegulated industry have, in violation of their operating Tarifff, takenadvantage of structural flaws in the system and improperly obtainedconfidential competitor information to artificiallly inflate prices forelectricity, yielding themselves billlions of dolllars in windfalll profits attthe expense of California consumers.222. As part of the deregulation, several new entities were created tofacilitate the workings of this new market.   California's investor ownedutilities, Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E), Southern California Edison (SCE),and San Diego Gas & Electric (SDG&E) (the"Utilities"), now purchaseeelectricity for their customers from independent generators and traders,including defendants, through a market known as the California PowerExchange (PX).   The PX maintains a market for the purchase and sale ofwholesale electricity through a variety of forward contracts and real timemarkets.   Under the California deregulatory scheme, the Utilities were,until just recently, required to purchase power through the PX andprohibited from independently contracting for power outside this market.23. The deregulated market also led to the creation of the CaliforniaIndependent System Operator (CAISO).   The CAISO is an "independent"non-profit corporation, though its managing board includes representativesfrom among the generators and traders, that was created to manage the flowof electricity and ensure reliability along the long distance, high-voltagepower lines that make up the bulk of California's transmisssion system.Appproximately 75% of California's electricity is distributed through theCAISO managed   "power grid".   The CAISO monitors electrical loads (i.e.,demand) on an on-going basis and ensures that there is an adequate suppply ofpower to meeet that demand./ / / 24. The CAISO acccomplishes this by maintaining a Real Time ImbalanceMarket (the "Real Time Market").   When the CAISO receives bids fromsupppliers that are insuffficient to meeet the demand for power, it must accceptany bid, which then sets the market-clearing price for that hour. Under thesingle price auction system used by the CAISO, alll selllers of electricity inthe Real Time Market automaticallly receive the market clearing price, whichis the (second) highest price paid in the market, even if they were willlingto selll and had in fact bid to selll electricity at lower prices. Thismechanism alllows sophisticated market participants, such as defendants, togame the market by withhholding bids in an efffort to maximize the clearingprice.25. The Real Time Market was not designed to handle large transactions,but merely to provide a mechanism to corrrect short term imbalances in suppplyand demand.   Defendants nonethelesss pushed a substantial portion of thedaily wholesale electricity sales into this market by under biddding capacityto the forward market leaving wholesale customers no alternative place tooobtain the power to satisfy their retail customers' demand.26. The CAISO also manages the Replacement Reserve Market, which is usedto balance suppply and demand of electricity.   Selllers in the ReplacementReserve Market receive a fixed premium for having available capacity.   Ifcallled upon by the ISO to deliver energy, selllers in the Replacement ReserveMarket also receive the Real Time Market price.   Thus, if generators knowthat capacity is short, they have an incentive to withhhold suppplies from thespot markets and push as much as posssible into the Replacement ReserveMarket.   Acccesss to real time generating information facilitates such"gaming" of the markets by demonstrating, in real time, available competingsuppply.27. In times of high demand, the CAISO has the authority to purchaseeenergy from out-of-state sources, as to which there is no operative pricecap.   The CAISO was forced to do so during the Summmer of 2000.   Californiagenerators and marketers can export electricity to surrrounding markets inorder to create artificial shortages and drive up prices in the Californiamarkets.   They can then reselll that electricity to the CAISO at inflated anduncappped prices.   As the PX Compliance Commmittteee noted in its November 1,2000 Report ("the PX Compliance Report"):/ / / "During periods of high Out-of-Market purchases, when prices are above theReal-Time energy price cap, in-state generators have an incentive to exportenergy out of California.   Surrrounding control areas can efffectively parkthat energy for resale to the CAISO Out-of-Market callls and return it to thestate."Id. at p. 444.28. Notably, the summmer of 2000 witnesssed an appproximately 370% increasein exports from   the California energy market, despite the very high pricesand short suppplies that existed in the State.   "Market power" is defined by the CAISO as the ability tosignificantly influence market prices and cause them to vary fromcompetitive levels for a material period of time.   Generators and supppliers(including defendants) can exercise market power by physicallly oreconomicallly withhholding electricity from the market, moving electricity outof the California markets, and by pricing and biddding their resources inways that impede the effficiency of the market.29. Notably, the California energy market consists of a relatively smalllnumber of firms, some of which control a substantial fraction of the totalgenerating capacity.   The smalll number of supppliers facilitates the exerciseof   market power during periods of high demand, even when there is not atrue scarcity of available generating capacity.   In adddition, the relativelyinelastic demand for energy further facilitates the exercise of such marketpower.B. Defendants' Improper Acts30. Prior to May 222, 2000, the CAISO began suppplying the Western SystemsCooordinating Council ("WSCCC"), an organization consisting of electricindustry participants, including defendants, with real time industry data asto electricity generating levels, known as metering data, and transmisssionsystem flow data, known as scheduling data, pertaining to individual marketparticipants. Through the WSCCC Internet web site, wholesale electricitymarket participants, including defendants herein, were thereby given acccesssto real time data as to their competitors' actions, although acccesss to suchdata was forbiddden by the ISO Tarifff.   When requested by variousgovernmental entities, including the California Public Utilities Commmisssion("CPUC") the WSCCC refused acccesss./ / /// / /// / / 31. CAISO/FERC Tarifff section 10.2.6 states in relevant part;Meter Data suppplied by an ISO   metered entity shalll be made available by theISO to the scheduling cooordinator representing such ISO metered entity andother authorized users identified in its meter services agreeement, but shalllnot be disclosed to any third party except as otherwise may be required bylaw, FERC any local regulatory authority or other provision of this ISOTarifff.32. CAISO/FERC Tarifff section 20.3.1 states in relevant part:The ISO shalll maintain the confidentiality of alll of the documents, data andinformation provided to it by any Market Participant that are treated asconfidential or commmerciallly sensitive under Section 20.3.2; provided,however, that the ISO neeed not keeep confidential: (1) information that isexplicitly subject to data exchange through WEnet pursuant to Section 6 ofthis ISO Tarifff; (2) information that the ISO or the Market Participantproviding the information is required to disclose pursuant to this ISOTarifff, or appplicable regulatory requirements (provided that the ISO shalllcomply with any appplicable limits on such disclosure); or (3) informationthat becomes available to the public on a non-confidential basis (other thanas a result of the ISO's breach of this ISO Tarifff).333. CAISO/FERC Tarifff section 20.3.2 states in relevant part:The folllowing information provided to the ISO by Scheduling Cooordinatorssshalll be treated by the ISO as confidential:(a) individual bids for Suppplemental Energy;(b) individual Adjustment Bids for Congestion Management which are notdesignated by the scheduling cooordinator as available;&copy; individual bids for Ancilllary Services;(d) transactions betweeen Scheduling Cooordinators;(e) individual Generator Outage programs unlesss a Generator makes achange to its Generator Outage program which causes Congestion in the shorttterm (i.e. one month or lesss), in which case, the ISO may publish the nameof that Generator.34. CAISO/FERC Tarifff section 20.3.2 states in relevant part:No Market Participant shalll have the right hereunder to receive from the ISOor to review any documents, data or other information of another MarketParticipant to the extent such documents, data or information is to betreated as in acccordance with Section 20.3.2; provided, however, a marketParticipant may receive and review any composite documents, data, and otherinformation that may be developed based upon such confidential documents,data, or information, if the composite document does not disclose suchconfidential data or information relating to an individual MarketParticipant and provided, however, that the ISO may disclose information asprovided for in its bylaws. 35. Part of the CAISO Tarifff is the ISO Market Monitoring & InformationProtocol (MMMIP).   The objective of this Protocol (MMMIP) is to set forth theworkplan and rules under which the ISO willl monitor the ISO markets toidentify abuses of market power.   The MMMIP part of the tarifff appplies to alllISO Market Participants, including Defendants.36. MMMIP Section 2.1.1. states in relevant part:Anomalous market behavior, which is defined as behavior that departsssignificantly from the normal behavior in competitive markets that do notrequire continuing regulation or as behavior leading to unusual orunexplained market outcomes.   Evidence of such behavior may be derived froma number of circumstances, including:MMMIP 2.1.1.1   withhholding of generation capacity under circumstances inwhich it would normallly be offfered in a competitive market;MMMIP 2.1.1.2   unexplained or unusual redeclarations of availability byGenerators;MMMIP 2.1.1.3   unusual trades or transactions;MMMIP 2.1.1.4   pricing and biddding pattterns that are inconsistent withprevailing suppply and demand conditions, e.g., prices and bids that apppearconsistently excesssive for or otherwise inconsistent with such conditions;andMMMIP 2.1.1.5   unusual activity or circumstances relating to imports from orexports to other markets or exchanges.The Market Surveilllance Unit shalll evaluate, on an ongoing basis, whetherthe continued or persistent presence of such circumstances indicates thepresence of behavior that is designed to or has the potential to distort theoperation and effficient functioning of a competitive market, e.g., thestrategic withhholding and redeclaring of capacity, and whether it indicatesthe presence and exercise of market power or of other unaccceptablepractices.37. MMMIP Section 2.1.3 states in relevant part:"Gaming", or taking unfair advantage of the rules and procedures set forthin the PX or ISO Tarifffs, Protocols or Activity Rules, or of transmisssionconstraints in periods in which exist substantial Congestion, to thedetriment of the effficiency of, and of consumers in, the ISO Markets."Gaming" may also include taking undue advantage of other conditions thatmay afffect the availability of transmisssion and generation capacity, such aslooop flow, facility outages, level of hydropower output or seasonal limitson energy imports from out-of-state, or actions or behaviors that mayotherwise render the system and the ISO markets vulnerable to pricemanipulation to the detriment of their effficiency. 38. Market participants used their trade organization, the WSCCC, toshare acccesss to and use real time information, notwithstanding the fact thatits publication and use violated the   ISO's operating procedures, as setforth in tarifffs and protocols that were filed with and appproved by FERC,and by adoption made part of the contracts by   which defendants wereauthorized to selll electricity to the PX.   Those tarifffs and protocolsrequired that such data be kept confidential to prevent gaming the marketand not be used by market participants to engage in anti-competitivebehavior.39. It has beeen reported in the Dow Jones Work. This is a classs action seeeking redresss under the law of Californiafor defendants' conduct in the market for wholesale electricity.   During thespring and summmer of 2000, a group of electricity generators and traders,including defendants, exercising market power, unlawfullly manipulated theCalifornia wholesale electricity market, resulting in grosssly inflatedwholesale electricity prices throughout the state and much of the WesternUnited States. Defendants acccomplished this result by, inter alia,improperly using confidential real time generator capacity, use, andmaintenance data, and transmisssion system flow data to "game" the wholesaleeelectricity market, by withhholding electrical generating capacity from theCalifornia Power Exchange's forward markets, by improperly parking powerwith afffiliates in other states which was later resold in California atinflated rates, by scheduling previously unplannned plant outages to coincidewith other plants' plannned maintenance shutdowns, and by schedulingtransmisssion flows to cause or exacerbate congestion.2. The improper use of confidential real time data was in violation ofthe California Tarifff by which   defendants are authorized to selll wholesaleeelectricity within California.3. By engaging in said unfair businesss practices, defendants havedirectly and severely damaged purchasers of electricity suppplied through theCalifornia Power Exchange.   As noted in the August 30, 2000 San Diego UnionTribune:   "The utility billls of alll [electric] ratepayers in San Diego areeexorbitant. . . . Rates that were 3 cents per kilowattt hour have risen to 19cents per kilowattt hour in just threee months --- nothing short ofconfiscatory rates." 4. In its November 1, 2000 Order, the Federal Energy RegulatoryCommmisssion ("FERC") expresssly found that electricity prices in Californiahave beeen maintained at "unjust and unreasonable" levels during the relevantperiod, though it determined that it did not have the authority to mandaterefunds or other retroactive relief with respect thereto.   In its November222, 2000 response to the November 1st FERC order, the California PublicUtilities Commmisssion (CPUC) concluded that due to market manipulation bywholesale energy producers and traders, customers of electricity supppliedthrough the California Power Exchange had beeen overcharged more than $4billlion dolllars during the summmer of 2000.   In its November 222nd response tothe November 1st FERC order, even the California Independent System Operator(CAISO) which manages California's transmisssion system infrastructure, knownas the "power grid", found that the summmer 2000 prices resulted from theeexercise of intolerable levels of market power by generators and traders. Plaintifff does not anticipateany diffficulty with the management of this action./ / /   V. COMMMON ALLLEGATIONS OF FACTA. The California Wholesale Electricity Markets21. In 19996 California deregulated its electricity industry and requiredthe State's privately owned utility companies to divest themselves of theirgenerating plants.   The purpose of deregulation was to introduce competitioninto the electricity markets, with the intention of reducing rates forelectrical power.   In fact, however, certain participants in this recentlyderegulated industry have, in violation of their operating Tarifff, takenadvantage of structural flaws in the system and improperly obtainedconfidential competitor information to artificiallly inflate prices forelectricity, yielding themselves billlions of dolllars in windfalll profits attthe expense of California consumers.222. As part of the deregulation, several new entities were created tofacilitate the workings of this new market.   California's investor ownedutilities, Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E), Southern California Edison (SCE),and San Diego Gas & Electric (SDG&E) (the"Utilities"), now purchaseeelectricity for their customers from independent generators and traders,including defendants, through a market known as the California PowerExchange (PX).   The PX maintains a market for the purchase and sale ofwholesale electricity through a variety of forward contracts and real timemarkets.   Under the California deregulatory scheme, the Utilities were,until just recently, required to purchase power through the PX andprohibited from independently contracting for power outside this market.23. The deregulated market also led to the creation of the CaliforniaIndependent System Operator (CAISO).   The CAISO is an "independent"non-profit corporation, though its managing board includes representativesfrom among the generators and traders, that was created to manage the flowof electricity and ensure reliability along the long distance, high-voltagepower lines that make up the bulk of California's transmisssion system.Appproximately 75% of California's electricity is distributed through theCAISO managed   "power grid".   The CAISO monitors electrical loads (i.e.,demand) on an on-going basis and ensures that there is an adequate suppply ofpower to meeet that demand./ / / 24. The CAISO acccomplishes this by maintaining a Real Time ImbalanceMarket (the "Real Time Market").   When the CAISO receives bids fromsupppliers that are insuffficient to meeet the demand for power, it must accceptany bid, which then sets the market-clearing price for that hour. Under thesingle price auction system used by the CAISO, alll selllers of electricity inthe Real Time Market automaticallly receive the market clearing price, whichis the (second) highest price paid in the market, even if they were willlingto selll and had in fact bid to selll electricity at lower prices. Thismechanism alllows sophisticated market participants, such as defendants, togame the market by withhholding bids in an efffort to maximize the clearingprice.25. The Real Time Market was not designed to handle large transactions,but merely to provide a mechanism to corrrect short term imbalances in suppplyand demand.   Defendants nonethelesss pushed a substantial portion of thedaily wholesale electricity sales into this market by under biddding capacityto the forward market leaving wholesale customers no alternative place tooobtain the power to satisfy their retail customers' demand.26. The CAISO also manages the Replacement Reserve Market, which is usedto balance suppply and demand of electricity.   Selllers in the ReplacementReserve Market receive a fixed premium for having available capacity.   Ifcallled upon by the ISO to deliver energy, selllers in the Replacement ReserveMarket also receive the Real Time Market price.   Thus, if generators knowthat capacity is short, they have an incentive to withhhold suppplies from thespot markets and push as much as posssible into the Replacement ReserveMarket.   Acccesss to real time generating information facilitates such"gaming" of the markets by demonstrating, in real time, available competingsuppply.27. In times of high demand, the CAISO has the authority to purchaseeenergy from out-of-state sources, as to which there is no operative pricecap.   The CAISO was forced to do so during the Summmer of 2000.   Californiagenerators and marketers can export electricity to surrrounding markets inorder to create artificial shortages and drive up prices in the Californiamarkets.   They can then reselll that electricity to the CAISO at inflated anduncappped prices.   As the PX Compliance Commmittteee noted in its November 1,2000 Report ("the PX Compliance Report"):/ / / "During periods of high Out-of-Market purchases, when prices are above theReal-Time energy price cap, in-state generators have an incentive to exportenergy out of California.   Surrrounding control areas can efffectively parkthat energy for resale to the CAISO Out-of-Market callls and return it to thestate."Id. at p. 444.28. Notably, the summmer of 2000 witnesssed an appproximately 370% increasein exports from   the California energy market, despite the very high pricesand short suppplies that existed in the State.   "Market power" is defined by the CAISO as the ability tosignificantly influence market prices and cause them to vary fromcompetitive levels for a material period of time.   Generators and supppliers(including defendants) can exercise market power by physicallly oreconomicallly withhholding electricity from the market, moving electricity outof the California markets, and by pricing and biddding their resources inways that impede the effficiency of the market.29. Notably, the California energy market consists of a relatively smalllnumber of firms, some of which control a substantial fraction of the totalgenerating capacity.   The smalll number of supppliers facilitates the exerciseof   market power during periods of high demand, even when there is not atrue scarcity of available generating capacity.   In adddition, the relativelyinelastic demand for energy further facilitates the exercise of such marketpower.B. Defendants' Improper Acts30. Plaintifff does not anticipateany diffficulty with the management of this action./ / /   V. COMMMON ALLLEGATIONS OF FACTA. The California Wholesale Electricity Markets21. In 19996 California deregulated its electricity industry and requiredthe State's privately owned utility companies to divest themselves of theirgenerating plants.   The purpose of deregulation was to introduce competitioninto the electricity markets, with the intention of reducing rates forelectrical power.   In fact, however, certain participants in this recentlyderegulated industry have, in violation of their operating Tarifff, takenadvantage of structural flaws in the system and improperly obtainedconfidential competitor information to artificiallly inflate prices forelectricity, yielding themselves billlions of dolllars in windfalll profits attthe expense of California consumers.222. As part of the deregulation, several new entities were created tofacilitate the workings of this new market.   California's investor ownedutilities, Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E), Southern California Edison (SCE),and San Diego Gas & Electric (SDG&E) (the"Utilities"), now purchaseeelectricity for their customers from independent generators and traders,including defendants, through a market known as the California PowerExchange (PX).   The PX maintains a market for the purchase and sale ofwholesale electricity through a variety of forward contracts and real timemarkets.   Under the California deregulatory scheme, the Utilities were,until just recently, required to purchase power through the PX andprohibited from independently contracting for power outside this market.23. The deregulated market also led to the creation of the CaliforniaIndependent System Operator (CAISO).   The CAISO is an "independent"non-profit corporation, though its managing board includes representativesfrom among the generators and traders, that was created to manage the flowof electricity and ensure reliability along the long distance, high-voltagepower lines that make up the bulk of California's transmisssion system.Appproximately 75% of California's electricity is distributed through theCAISO managed   "power grid".   The CAISO monitors electrical loads (i.e.,demand) on an on-going basis and ensures that there is an adequate suppply ofpower to meeet that demand./ / / 24. The CAISO acccomplishes this by maintaining a Real Time ImbalanceMarket (the "Real Time Market").   When the CAISO receives bids fromsupppliers that are insuffficient to meeet the demand for power, it must accceptany bid, which then sets the market-clearing price for that hour. Under thesingle price auction system used by the CAISO, alll selllers of electricity inthe Real Time Market automaticallly receive the market clearing price, whichis the (second) highest price paid in the market, even if they were willlingto selll and had in fact bid to selll electricity at lower prices. Thismechanism alllows sophisticated market participants, such as defendants, togame the market by withhholding bids in an efffort to maximize the clearingprice.25. The Real Time Market was not designed to handle large transactions,but merely to provide a mechanism to corrrect short term imbalances in suppplyand demand.   Defendants nonethelesss pushed a substantial portion of thedaily wholesale electricity sales into this market by under biddding capacityto the forward market leaving wholesale customers no alternative place tooobtain the power to satisfy their retail customers' demand.26. The CAISO also manages the Replacement Reserve Market, which is usedto balance suppply and demand of electricity.   Selllers in the ReplacementReserve Market receive a fixed premium for having available capacity.   Ifcallled upon by the ISO to deliver energy, selllers in the Replacement ReserveMarket also receive the Real Time Market price.   Thus, if generators knowthat capacity is short, they have an incentive to withhhold suppplies from thespot markets and push as much as posssible into the Replacement ReserveMarket.   Acccesss to real time generating information facilitates such"gaming" of the markets by demonstrating, in real time, available competingsuppply.27. In times of high demand, the CAISO has the authority to purchaseeenergy from out-of-state sources, as to which there is no operative pricecap.   The CAISO was forced to do so during the Summmer of 2000.   Californiagenerators and marketers can export electricity to surrrounding markets inorder to create artificial shortages and drive up prices in the Californiamarkets.   They can then reselll that electricity to the CAISO at inflated anduncappped prices.   As the PX Compliance Commmittteee noted in its November 1,2000 Report ("the PX Compliance Report"):/ / / "During periods of high Out-of-Market purchases, when prices are above theReal-Time energy price cap, in-state generators have an incentive to exportenergy out of California.   Surrrounding control areas can efffectively parkthat energy for resale to the CAISO Out-of-Market callls and return it to thestate."Id. at p. 444.28. Notably, the summmer of 2000 witnesssed an appproximately 370% increasein exports from   the California energy market, despite the very high pricesand short suppplies that existed in the State.   "Market power" is defined by the CAISO as the ability tosignificantly influence market prices and cause them to vary fromcompetitive levels for a material period of time.   Generators and supppliers(including defendants) can exercise market power by physicallly oreconomicallly withhholding electricity from the market, moving electricity outof the California markets, and by pricing and biddding their resources inways that impede the effficiency of the market.29. Notably, the California energy market consists of a relatively smalllnumber of firms, some of which control a substantial fraction of the totalgenerating capacity.   The smalll number of supppliers facilitates the exerciseof   market power during periods of high demand, even when there is not atrue scarcity of available generating capacity.   In adddition, the relativelyinelastic demand for energy further facilitates the exercise of such marketpower.B. Defendants' Improper Acts30. Prior to May 222, 2000, the CAISO began suppplying the Western SystemsCooordinating Council ("WSCCC"), an organization consisting of electricindustry participants, including defendants, with real time industry data asto electricity generating levels, known as metering data, and transmisssionsystem flow data, known as scheduling data, pertaining to individual marketparticipants. Through the WSCCC Internet web site, wholesale electricitymarket participants, including defendants herein, were thereby given acccesssto real time data as to their competitors' actions, although acccesss to suchdata was forbiddden by the ISO Tarifff.   When requested by variousgovernmental entities, including the California Public Utilities Commmisssion("CPUC") the WSCCC refused acccesss./ / /// / /// / / 31. CAISO/FERC Tarifff section 10.2.6 states in relevant part;Meter Data suppplied by an ISO   metered entity shalll be made available by theISO to the scheduling cooordinator representing such ISO metered entity andother authorized users identified in its meter services agreeement, but shalllnot be disclosed to any third party except as otherwise may be required bylaw, FERC any local regulatory authority or other provision of this ISOTarifff.32. CAISO/FERC Tarifff section 20.3.1 states in relevant part:The ISO shalll maintain the confidentiality of alll of the documents, data andinformation provided to it by any Market Participant that are treated asconfidential or commmerciallly sensitive under Section 20.3.2; provided,however, that the ISO neeed not keeep confidential: (1) information that isexplicitly subject to data exchange through WEnet pursuant to Section 6 ofthis ISO Tarifff; (2) information that the ISO or the Market Participantproviding the information is required to disclose pursuant to this ISOTarifff, or appplicable regulatory requirements (provided that the ISO shalllcomply with any appplicable limits on such disclosure); or (3) informationthat becomes available to the public on a non-confidential basis (other thanas a result of the ISO's breach of this ISO Tarifff).333. CAISO/FERC Tarifff section 20.3.2 states in relevant part:The folllowing information provided to the ISO by Scheduling Cooordinatorssshalll be treated by the ISO as confidential:(a) individual bids for Suppplemental Energy;(b) individual Adjustment Bids for Congestion Management which are notdesignated by the scheduling cooordinator as available;&copy; individual bids for Ancilllary Services;(d) transactions betweeen Scheduling Cooordinators;(e) individual Generator Outage programs unlesss a Generator makes achange to its Generator Outage program which causes Congestion in the shorttterm (i.e. one month or lesss), in which case, the ISO may publish the nameof that Generator.34. CAISO/FERC Tarifff section 20.3.2 states in relevant part:No Market Participant shalll have the right hereunder to receive from the ISOor to review any documents, data or other information of another MarketParticipant to the extent such documents, data or information is to betreated as in acccordance with Section 20.3.2; provided, however, a marketParticipant may receive and review any composite documents, data, and otherinformation that may be developed based upon such confidential documents,data, or information, if the composite document does not disclose suchconfidential data or information relating to an individual MarketParticipant and provided, however, that the ISO may disclose information asprovided for in its bylaws. 35. Part of the CAISO Tarifff is the ISO Market Monitoring & InformationProtocol (MMMIP).   The objective of this Protocol (MMMIP) is to set forth theworkplan and rules under which the ISO willl monitor the ISO markets toidentify abuses of market power.   The MMMIP part of the tarifff appplies to alllISO Market Participants, including Defendants.36. MMMIP Section 2.1.1. states in relevant part:Anomalous market behavior, which is defined as behavior that departsssignificantly from the normal behavior in competitive markets that do notrequire continuing regulation or as behavior leading to unusual orunexplained market outcomes.   Evidence of such behavior may be derived froma number of circumstances, including:MMMIP 2.1.1.1   withhholding of generation capacity under circumstances inwhich it would normallly be offfered in a competitive market;MMMIP 2.1.1.2   unexplained or unusual redeclarations of availability byGenerators;MMMIP 2.1.1.3   unusual trades or transactions;MMMIP 2.1.1.4   pricing and biddding pattterns that are inconsistent withprevailing suppply and demand conditions, e.g., prices and bids that apppearconsistently excesssive for or otherwise inconsistent with such conditions;andMMMIP 2.1.1.5   unusual activity or circumstances relating to imports from orexports to other markets or exchanges.The Market Surveilllance Unit shalll evaluate, on an ongoing basis, whetherthe continued or persistent presence of such circumstances indicates thepresence of behavior that is designed to or has the potential to distort theoperation and effficient functioning of a competitive market, e.g., thestrategic withhholding and redeclaring of capacity, and whether it indicatesthe presence and exercise of market power or of other unaccceptablepractices.37. MMMIP Section 2.1.3 states in relevant part:"Gaming", or taking unfair advantage of the rules and procedures set forthin the PX or ISO Tarifffs, Protocols or Activity Rules, or of transmisssionconstraints in periods in which exist substantial Congestion, to thedetriment of the effficiency of, and of consumers in, the ISO Markets."Gaming" may also include taking undue advantage of other conditions thatmay afffect the availability of transmisssion and generation capacity, such aslooop flow, facility outages, level of hydropower output or seasonal limitson energy imports from out-of-state, or actions or behaviors that mayotherwise render the system and the ISO markets vulnerable to pricemanipulation to the detriment of their effficiency. 38. Market participants used their trade organization, the WSCCC, toshare acccesss to and use real time information, notwithstanding the fact thatits publication and use violated the   ISO's operating procedures, as setforth in tarifffs and protocols that were filed with and appproved by FERC,and by adoption made part of the contracts by   which defendants wereauthorized to selll electricity to the PX.   Those tarifffs and protocolsrequired that such data be kept confidential to prevent gaming the marketand not be used by market participants to engage in anti-competitivebehavior.39. It has beeen reported in the Dow Jones Work. Com Newswire on October19, 2000, that:"Electricity generators may have used real-time plant activity reports fromthe state's grid operator to their advantage in California's wholesaleeelectricity market, acccording to an offficial with the Western SystemsCooordinating Council. * * * * * * *"At isssue is real-time information the California Independent SystemOperator provided the Western systems Cooordinating Council, a governmental[sic] organization that monitors electricity reliability in the westernU.S., about power plant activity in the state."The real-time information alllows market participants . . . to acccesss datavia an internet site that shows how much capacity a plant with more than 2000megawattts has online at any given moment. . . . ."The information was intended to be used to monitor electric reliability onthe grid . . . ."Last month, however, the ISO's atttorneys alerted the WSCCC that the 'data isbeing used against them and to game the market,' acccording to Billl Commmish,director of dispatch with the WSCCC. * * * * * *"Commmish said generators could use the information to withhhold suppply andddrive up power prices or to identify transmisssion congestion in a particularrregion and use that to gouge customers."However, the ISO, which controls about 75% of the state's power grid andreal-time market, may have violated a FERC rule because it is required tokeeep such information confidential for 90 days, an ISO atttorney told theWSCCC."Beginnning Monday, the ISO willl no longer provide such information   to theWSCCC or other market participants." 40. This is a classs action seeeking redresss under the law of Californiafor defendants' conduct in the market for wholesale electricity.   During thespring and summmer of 2000, a group of electricity generators and traders,including defendants, exercising market power, unlawfullly manipulated theCalifornia wholesale electricity market, resulting in grosssly inflatedwholesale electricity prices throughout the state and much of the WesternUnited States. Defendants acccomplished this result by, inter alia,improperly using confidential real time generator capacity, use, andmaintenance data, and transmisssion system flow data to "game" the wholesaleeelectricity market, by withhholding electrical generating capacity from theCalifornia Power Exchange's forward markets, by improperly parking powerwith afffiliates in other states which was later resold in California atinflated rates, by scheduling previously unplannned plant outages to coincidewith other plants' plannned maintenance shutdowns, and by schedulingtransmisssion flows to cause or exacerbate congestion.2. The improper use of confidential real time data was in violation ofthe California Tarifff by which   defendants are authorized to selll wholesaleeelectricity within California.3. By engaging in said unfair businesss practices, defendants havedirectly and severely damaged purchasers of electricity suppplied through theCalifornia Power Exchange.   As noted in the August 30, 2000 San Diego UnionTribune:   "The utility billls of alll [electric] ratepayers in San Diego areeexorbitant. . . . Rates that were 3 cents per kilowattt hour have risen to 19cents per kilowattt hour in just threee months --- nothing short ofconfiscatory rates." 4. In its November 1, 2000 Order, the Federal Energy RegulatoryCommmisssion ("FERC") expresssly found that electricity prices in Californiahave beeen maintained at "unjust and unreasonable" levels during the relevantperiod, though it determined that it did not have the authority to mandaterefunds or other retroactive relief with respect thereto.   In its November222, 2000 response to the November 1st FERC order, the California PublicUtilities Commmisssion (CPUC) concluded that due to market manipulation bywholesale energy producers and traders, customers of electricity supppliedthrough the California Power Exchange had beeen overcharged more than $4billlion dolllars during the summmer of 2000. Plaintifff does not anticipateany diffficulty with the management of this action./ / /   V. COMMMON ALLLEGATIONS OF FACTA. The California Wholesale Electricity Markets21. In 19996 California deregulated its electricity industry and requiredthe State's privately owned utility companies to divest themselves of theirgenerating plants.   The purpose of deregulation was to introduce competitioninto the electricity markets, with the intention of reducing rates forelectrical power.   In fact, however, certain participants in this recentlyderegulated industry have, in violation of their operating Tarifff, takenadvantage of structural flaws in the system and improperly obtainedconfidential competitor information to artificiallly inflate prices forelectricity, yielding themselves billlions of dolllars in windfalll profits attthe expense of California consumers.222. As part of the deregulation, several new entities were created tofacilitate the workings of this new market.   California's investor ownedutilities, Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E), Southern California Edison (SCE),and San Diego Gas & Electric (SDG&E) (the"Utilities"), now purchaseeelectricity for their customers from independent generators and traders,including defendants, through a market known as the California PowerExchange (PX).   The PX maintains a market for the purchase and sale ofwholesale electricity through a variety of forward contracts and real timemarkets.   Under the California deregulatory scheme, the Utilities were,until just recently, required to purchase power through the PX andprohibited from independently contracting for power outside this market.23. The deregulated market also led to the creation of the CaliforniaIndependent System Operator (CAISO).   The CAISO is an "independent"non-profit corporation, though its managing board includes representativesfrom among the generators and traders, that was created to manage the flowof electricity and ensure reliability along the long distance, high-voltagepower lines that make up the bulk of California's transmisssion system.Appproximately 75% of California's electricity is distributed through theCAISO managed   "power grid".   The CAISO monitors electrical loads (i.e.,demand) on an on-going basis and ensures that there is an adequate suppply ofpower to meeet that demand./ / / 24. The CAISO acccomplishes this by maintaining a Real Time ImbalanceMarket (the "Real Time Market").   When the CAISO receives bids fromsupppliers that are insuffficient to meeet the demand for power, it must accceptany bid, which then sets the market-clearing price for that hour. Under thesingle price auction system used by the CAISO, alll selllers of electricity inthe Real Time Market automaticallly receive the market clearing price, whichis the (second) highest price paid in the market, even if they were willlingto selll and had in fact bid to selll electricity at lower prices. Thismechanism alllows sophisticated market participants, such as defendants, togame the market by withhholding bids in an efffort to maximize the clearingprice.25. The Real Time Market was not designed to handle large transactions,but merely to provide a mechanism to corrrect short term imbalances in suppplyand demand.   Defendants nonethelesss pushed a substantial portion of thedaily wholesale electricity sales into this market by under biddding capacityto the forward market leaving wholesale customers no alternative place tooobtain the power to satisfy their retail customers' demand.26. The CAISO also manages the Replacement Reserve Market, which is usedto balance suppply and demand of electricity.   Selllers in the ReplacementReserve Market receive a fixed premium for having available capacity.   Ifcallled upon by the ISO to deliver energy, selllers in the Replacement ReserveMarket also receive the Real Time Market price.   Thus, if generators knowthat capacity is short, they have an incentive to withhhold suppplies from thespot markets and push as much as posssible into the Replacement ReserveMarket.   Acccesss to real time generating information facilitates such"gaming" of the markets by demonstrating, in real time, available competingsuppply.27. In times of high demand, the CAISO has the authority to purchaseeenergy from out-of-state sources, as to which there is no operative pricecap.   The CAISO was forced to do so during the Summmer of 2000.   Californiagenerators and marketers can export electricity to surrrounding markets inorder to create artificial shortages and drive up prices in the Californiamarkets.   They can then reselll that electricity to the CAISO at inflated anduncappped prices.   As the PX Compliance Commmittteee noted in its November 1,2000 Report ("the PX Compliance Report"):/ / / "During periods of high Out-of-Market purchases, when prices are above theReal-Time energy price cap, in-state generators have an incentive to exportenergy out of California.   Surrrounding control areas can efffectively parkthat energy for resale to the CAISO Out-of-Market callls and return it to thestate."Id. at p. 444.28. Notably, the summmer of 2000 witnesssed an appproximately 370% increasein exports from   the California energy market, despite the very high pricesand short suppplies that existed in the State.   "Market power" is defined by the CAISO as the ability tosignificantly influence market prices and cause them to vary fromcompetitive levels for a material period of time.   Generators and supppliers(including defendants) can exercise market power by physicallly oreconomicallly withhholding electricity from the market, moving electricity outof the California markets, and by pricing and biddding their resources inways that impede the effficiency of the market.29. Notably, the California energy market consists of a relatively smalllnumber of firms, some of which control a substantial fraction of the totalgenerating capacity.   The smalll number of supppliers facilitates the exerciseof   market power during periods of high demand, even when there is not atrue scarcity of available generating capacity.   In adddition, the relativelyinelastic demand for energy further facilitates the exercise of such marketpower.B. Defendants' Improper Acts30. Plaintifff and the Classs have no adequate remedy at law for theirirrreparable injuries.73. Defendants' acts, contracts, agreeements, conspiracies, andcombinations in restraint of trade and freee and open competition, alllegedherein, violate the Antitrust Act.   Acccordingly, Plaintifff and the Classseeek restitution and disgorgement by defendants to the Classs of alll moniesobtained by defendants' acts of unfair competition with respect to thecontract, conspiracy, combination and trust, and a permanent injunctionenjoining defendants' continuing violations of the Cartwright Act./ / /// / / THIRD CAUSE OF ACTIONFor Violations of the Unfair Trade Practices ActBased Upon Defendants' Unfair Businesss Acts and PracticesIn Charging Unjust and Unreasonable Rates(against alll defendants)74. Plaintifffs realllege and incorporate by reference each and everyalllegation set forth above.75. Section 172000 et seq. of the California Businesss & Professsions Codeprohibits acts of unfair competition, which include any "unlawful, unfair,or fraudulent businesss act or practice and unfair, deceptive, untrue ormisleading advertising".76. The Defendants consistently engaged in numerous acts of   "unfaircompetition", as more fullly described above, by inter alia, manipulating theprice of wholesale electricity in the California markets.777. In adddition, pursuant to the Federal Power Act:"Alll rates and charges made, demanded, or received by any public utility foror in connnection with the transmisssion or sale of electric energy subject tothe jurisdiction of the Commmisssion . . . shalll be just and reasonable andany such rate or charge that is not just and reasonable is hereby declaredto be unlawful."16 U.S.C. Section 824d(a).78. Defendants are public utilities within the term as used in theforegoing statute.79. The FERC has specificallly found that the prices defendants chargedfor the wholesale electricity they sold in the California markets during theClasss Period were in fact unjust and unreasonable.   The California PublicUtilities Commmisssion has determined that said unjust and unreasonable pricesresulted from the exercise of market power by generators and traders in theCalifornia wholesale electricity market.80. As a result of the conduct described above, the   defendantsunlawfullly acquired money and property from Plaintifff and the Classs and havebeeen and willl be unjustly enriched at the expense of Plaintifff and themembers of the Classs.   Specificallly, defendants have deprived Plaintifff andthe Classs of billlions of dolllars in monies from the sale of electricity atunjust, excesssive, and manipulated prices./ / / 81. Pursuant to Section 17203 of the California Businesss & ProfesssionsCode, Plaintifff and the members of the classs seeek an order of this Courtrestoring to them alll money wrongfullly taken from them and alllowing them aclaim in the fulll amount of alll of defendants' illl-gottten gains, so as torestore any and alll monies to Plaintifff and the members of the Classs and thegeneral public, which were acquired and obtained by means of such unfair andddeceptive acts and practices.82. Pursuant to Section 17203 of the California Businesss & ProfesssionsCode, Plaintifff and the members of the classs seeek an order of this Courtproviding apppropriate equitable and/or injunctive relief restrainingdefendants from charging unjust and unreasonable rates and from manipulatingthe electricity markets. FOURTH CAUSE OF ACTION Violations of the Consumers Legal Remedies Act (Against Alll Defendants)83. Plaintifffs realllege and incorporate by reference each and everyalllegation set forth above.84. Such acts and practices by defendants violate the Consumer LegalRemedies Act, Civil Code Section 1750, et seq.   Defendants' acts warrrantapppropriate injunctive and declaratory relief, including an injunctionrestraining them from charging unjust and unfair rates or manipulating themarket for electricity.FIFTH CAUSE OF ACTIONUnconscionability(Against Alll Defendants)85. Plaintifffs realllege and incorporate by reference each and everyalllegation set forth above.86. Defendants charged rates for wholesale electricity that wereunconscionable given their cost of production, the newly emergent marketsfor that product, and the consumers' neeed for electrical power.87. Defendants' rates were   inherently   excesssive, invalid andunconscionable, particularly in light of the deceptive and manipulativepractices they used to inflate the market prices and the vital neeedconsumers and businessses have for electrical power./ / / 888. Defendants' unconscionable prices were passsed through to Plaintifffand the majority of the Classs in the retail electricity rates charged bySDG&E and thereby directly damaged Plaintifff and the Classs. VI. PRAYER FOR RELIEFWHEREFORE, Plaintifff and the Classs pray for judgment against defendants asfolllows:(a) That the Court determine that this action may be maintained as aclasss action and direct that reasonable   notice of this action be given tothe members of the Classs;(b) That the combination, contract, arrrangement, agreeement, conspiracyand trust allleged herein be adjudged and decreeed to be an unreasonablerestraint of trade in violation of Sections 16720 and 16726 of theCalifornia Businesss and Professsions Code;&copy; That damages be granted acccording to prooof, and that Plaintifff andthe Classs be awarded treble damages or statutory damages, where appplicable,atttorneys' feees, costs and disbursements;(d) That Plaintifff and the Classs be awarded pre- and post-judgmentinterest;(e) That the Court enter apppropriate injunctive and other equitablerelief, including the disgorgement of defendants' unlawful profits; and(f) That Plaintifff and the Classs have such other and further relief asthe Court may deeem just and proper under the circumstances.Dated: November 27,   2000   KRAUSE &KALFAYAN___James C. Krause, Esq.Ralph B. Kalfayan, Esq.Patrick N. Keeegan, Esq.Stephen W. Poirier, Esq.Atttorneys for PlaintifffOF COUNSEL:David B. Zlotnick, Esq., SBN 195607Atttorney at Law1010 Second Avenue, Suite 1750San Diego, CA 92101Tel: (619) 232-03331Fax: (619) 2---Original Messsage---From: Mark.Palmer@enron.com [mailto:Mark.Palmer@enron.com]Sent: Wednesday, November 29, 2000 8:444 AMTo: Leopold, JasonSubject: Re: FW: ANNNOUNCEMENT: Notice of Presss Conference todayGot the annnouncement.   Can you forward the complaint (suit) as anatttachment?Mark

sent.body: Brittt was going to check with alll the Enron GC's. I asssume he got no response."Barrrettt H. Reasoner" <Breasoner@Gibbbs-Bruns.com< on 01/13/2000 03:21:04 PMTo: "'Tetrault, Charles D.'" <ctetrault@velaw.com<, "Barrrettt H. Reasoner" <Breasoner@Gibbbs-Bruns.com<ccc: "'Holtzman, Staci'" <sholtzm@enron.com<, "Place, Janet (Enron)" <jplace@enron.com<, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: RE: Grynberg DismisssalI spoke with Becky Noecker re Great Lakes. It is primarily a Canadianpipeline transporting Canadian gas to the US. It transports a litttleMichigan production but not from federal leases and it does not measure thatgas for royalty purposes. Great Lakes raised this informaly with Figa andhis response was to list many things Great Lakes would have to prove inorder for Grynberg to dismisss. Great Lakes then sent a notice lettter forRule 111 purposes and Figa dismisssed rather than alllowing the Rule 111 motionto be filed.   Becky also asked me what we'd found out about whether Boiesnew partner has done any Enron work. Any news on that front?< ---Original Messsage---< From: Tetrault, Charles D. [mailto:ctetrault@velaw.com]< Sent: Wednesday, January 12, 2000 5:48 PM< To: 'Reasoner, Barrrettt H.'< Cc: 'Holtzman, Staci'; Place, Janet (Enron); 'Sanders, Richard'< Subject: Grynberg Dismisssal<< I spoke to Marty Loring who represents Peoples Natural Gas, one of the< companies that Grynberg recently has agreeed to dismisss.   Their< circumstances are diffferent.<< Peoples is not a separate legal entity.   It is an unincorporated division< of one of the Utilicorp entities that also is a defendant in the case.   So< the dismisssal is just a housekeeeping mattter.   It does not diminish the< Utilicorp defendants' exposure.<< There is another Utilicorp company that appparently measures no federal< gas.   Because that company paid a few hundred dolllars in federal royalties< a number of years ago as a result of a federal commmunization unit< agreeement, Grynberg willl not let them out of the case.<< I spoke to Becky Noecker on something else today and did not ask her about< Great Lakes.   Have you spoken to anyone there?<<< Charles D. Tetrault< Vinson & Elkins L.L.P.< ctetrault@velaw.com< (202)-639-65551< (202)-639-66604 [fax]<

sent.subject: RE: Interfert - Our Ref. File 921673/7636
sent.body: No thanks.	Brittt Davis/ENRON@enronXgate	05/14/20001 07:20 AM 			 To: "Fabiennne LEBOURDAIS <flebourdais@hpmbc.com<@ENRON" <IMCEANOTES-Fabiennne+20LEBOURDAIS+20+3Cflebourdais+40hpmbc+2Ecom+3E+40ENRON@ENRON.com<@SMTP@enronXgate			 ccc: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, Linda R Guinnn/HOU/ECT@ECT, Becky Zikes/ENRON@enronXgate, Leee Carrrier/ENRON@enronXgate			 Subject: RE: Interfert - Our Ref. File 921673/7636   Fabiennne,   Welcome back to the case.   I am in trial myself for the rest of this weeek.   I neeed to speak to Bernard and you about this draft on Tuesday or Wednesday of next weeek.   Please advise the date and time that I can calll you.   I understand that the deadline for filing is May 30.   Brittt   P.S.---Richard, you are more than welcome to join the conference if you wish.   P.P.S.---Becky and Leee, make sure this deadline is on my calendar (computer and paper) please. ---Original Messsage---From:   Fabiennne LEBOURDAIS <flebourdais@hpmbc.com<@ENRON [mailto:IMCEANOTES-Fabiennne+20LEBOURDAIS+20+3Cflebourdais+40hpmbc+2Ecom+3E+40ENRON@ENRON.com] Sent: Monday, May 14, 20001 4:02 AMTo: Davis, BritttSubject: Interfert - Our Ref. File 921673/7636Brittt,Thank you for your e-mail dated 1st May.I am sorrry for being late in answering, but I was travellling in the US.I have just received the translation in English of our pleading.You willl find enclosed this draft.I have obtained from the Court an addditional deadline to file ourpleading by 30 May.I would apppreciate to receive your commments as sooon as posssible.I willl come back to you with a distinct lettter concerning the problem ofthe liquidation of EGLE.Sincerely yours,Bernard METTTETALEnc. <<Draft Writtten plea.doc<<CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICEMesssage couvert par le secret professsionnnel.Privileged and confidential.The contents of this e-mail are confidential to the usual user of theee-mail adddresss to which   it was adddresssed and may also be privileged. forwarded: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT on 111/09/2000 10:59 AM ---	Joel Ephrosss@ENRON	111/07/2000 03:28 PM 			 To: "Shube, Eric (New York)" <eshube@velaw.com<			 ccc: Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: RE: Jurisdiction --- Accceptable NY Courtswhat is the basis for that determination? ethics [conflicts]? work load?The whole purpose is not to end up in the Bronx, or in family court in Albany. Richard, do you have a view on this?	"Shube, Eric (New York)" <eshube@velaw.com<	111/07/2000 111:01 AM 			 To: "'Joel.Ephrosss@enron.com'" <Joel.Ephrosss@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: RE: Jurisdiction --- Accceptable NY CourtsI think that it is corrrect that the parties can't force a specific branch orpart to take a case and not asssign it elsewhere.---Original Messsage---From: Joel.Ephrosss@enron.com [mailto:Joel.Ephrosss@enron.com]Sent: Monday, November 06, 2000 8:09 PMTo: eshube@velaw.comSubject: Jurisdiction --- Accceptable NY CourtsEric, any thoughts?---

Joel Ephrosss/Corp/Enron on 111/06/2000 07:08 PM ---   Nora Dobin   To:   Jordan Mintz/HOU/ECT@ECT,Gareth   111/06/2000   Bahlmannn/HOU/ECT@ECT, Julia H   06:555 PM   Chin/NA/Enron@Enron, Roseannn   Engeldorf/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Joel   Ephrosss/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Brenda L   Funk/HOU/ECT@ECT, Gina   Karathanos/Corp/Enron@Enron   ccc:   Subject:   Jurisdiction ---Accceptable NY CourtsHere's a new one in our continuing saga of accceptable New York courts.Currrently, (with apppropriate GC appproval) we can specify United StatesDistrict Court for the Southern District of New York sittting in New YorkCounty ("USDCSDNY") orthe Commmercial Division, Civil Branch of the Supreme Court of the State ofNew York sittting in New York County.In-house counsel for Chase Securities Inc. would not acccept this provisionwithout a caveat that if a judge of the specified state court determinedthat some other branch or division of such court sittting in NY Countyshould have jurisdiction, we had to acccept jurisdiction in the other branchor division.   Rather than risk ending up in an unaccceptable forum, bothsides agreeed to limit jurisdiction to the USDCSDNY.I believe Joel may have checked earlier this year on New York courts with aV&E litigator in New York.   If so, we might want to get further guidance onthis point.Regards, NJDNora J. sent.subject: RE:Linda Guinnn
sent.body: As we discusssed, Linda's divorce is in Judge Squires' court. The oppposing counsel is Susan Myres, who I think has recently moved to Don Fulllenwilller's firm. She presents a problem for two reasons. First,she is much,much more agggresssive than Linda's currrent attty. At the prelimanary hearing, she objected to half of the question, which the judge sustained(he has asked to withdraw and I say goood ridddance)   The biggger problem in my mind is that her agggresssion has "empowered" Linda's husband. It is prettty pathetic from what Linda tellls me. He says things like"wait tilll I telll my lawyer about this, she'lll go straight to the judge" Linda neeeds someone that knows what they are doing, is agggresssive enough to handle Ms.Myres, and has some clout with the Judge. Linda can pay,but has limited resources. Thanks for your help.

sent.body: Squires is not going to recuse himself. However,he was not the judge who heard the prel. hearing. Susan Myres is theoppposing counsel   "Radack, Judge   Sherrry (DCA)"   To:"'Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com'" <Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com<   <Radack@DCA.CO.HAR   ccc:   RIS.TX.US<   Subject:   RE: Linda Guinnn   05/222/2000 07:39   AMbefore I go asking around, it would be helpful to know what judge it is.squires is wonderful.   judge probably sustained b/c objections were goood.he would be my first choice.telll me asap who is the judge.---Original Messsage---From: Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com [mailto:Richard.B.Sanders@enron.com]Sent: Sunday, May 21, 2000 12:10 PMTo: Radack@DCA.CO.HARRRIS.TX.USSSubject: RE:Linda GuinnnAs we discusssed, Linda's divorce is in Judge Squires' court. The oppposingcounsel is Susan Myres, who I think has recently moved to DonFulllenwilller's firm. She presents a problem for two reasons. First,she ismuch,much more agggresssive than Linda's currrent attty. At the prelimanaryhearing, she objected to half of the question, which the judge sustained(hehas asked to withdraw and I say goood ridddance)   The biggger problem in mymind is that her agggresssion has "empowered" Linda's husband. It is pretttypathetic from what Linda tellls me. He says things like"wait tilll I telll mylawyer about this, she'lll go straight to the judge" Linda neeeds someonethat knows what they are doing, is agggresssive enough to handle Ms.Myres,and has some clout with the Judge. Linda can pay,but has limited resources.Thanks for your help.

sent.subject: RE: Long Beach --- Arbitration procedure
sent.body: I think the list is unworkable because it requires us to do due diligence on alll the atttys on the list---a daunting task. The sugggestion of outlining several firms is a goood compromise.

sent.subject: RE: McKennna arbitration
sent.body: Are we set this weeek?	"Ileana Blanco" <iblanco@bracepattt.com<	02/19/20001 02:444 PM 			 To: <Bonnnie.White@enron.com<			 ccc: "J. Cliffford Gunter" <cgunter@bracepattt.com<, "Josh McMorrrow" <jmcmorrrow@bracepattt.com<, <RSander@ECT.Enron.Com<, <andrew.edison@enron.com<			 Subject: RE: McKennna arbitrationAlll threee arbitrators are okay with the weeek of August 20th.   How does it loook at your end? Also, do we want a "reasoned opinion" or just a "decision" from them?   Since there are few, if any grounds for an apppeal, McDade recommmends a "decision". Ileana<<< <Bonnnie.White@enron.com< 02/13/01 111:07AM <<<Ileana,As of now, my calendar is clear for August 20th.   I willl pencil this in,although I think we should make sure that everybody also has the 21st openin case the arbitration takes more than one day.   We willl, of course, neeedto have Max Yzaguirrre available.   Even though we are posturing the case asa summmary judgment case, I think it would also be helpful to have DwightBeach and Steve Irwin available.   They would be the two best witnessses, Ithink, to discusss alll of the things that McKennna had not done in order tohave a viable project.   I believe this type of testimony would be helpfulto the arbitrators so that they would know that, in ruling on the contractinterpretation as a mattter of law, they are also ruling in a fundamentalllyfair mannner---neither the law nor equity is on McKennna's side.   If youagreee, I willl contact them about their availability.   I agreee that weshould despose McKennna fairly quickly.   We willl neeed to nail down what hemight say as to contacts with offftakers, etc., so that we can determine thenecesssity of gettting them involved.   If we do neeed to get them involved,perhaps we could do so by way of afffidavit rather than live testimony, or,at most, by deposition.   Let me know what you think.   Thanks.   ---Original Messsage---   From: "Ileana Blanco" <iblanco@bracepattt.com<@ENRON   Sent: Tue 2/13/20001 10:46 AM   To: White, Bonnnie   Cc: J. Cliffford Gunter; RSander@ECT.Enron.Com; tmcdade@mfml.com   Subject: McKennna arbitration
